Bill of Rights Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because the Bill will
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the Constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this and any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustifiable power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
Restrict Rights to those specified by the Bill
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject a Bill of Rights in this or any other form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Honourable Senators may be aware that last year I established a working party to report to me on the causes and incidence of invalidity retirement from Commonwealth employment. I expect to have that report soon but in the meantime I have recently discussed with officials a number of matters that have been considered by the working party and I have found some cause for concern.

In particular I am concerned that the rate of invalidity retirement, which has been relatively stable for a few years following a dramatic upsurge in the late 1970's, show signs of increasing again. Moreover, there are marked differences between States and between employing organisations in the rates of invalidity retirement that cannot be readily explained. It is particularly evident in relation to Victoria which has consistently higher rates than apply in other States.

I wish to advise Senators that I have in the last few days asked the Commonwealth's Acting Commissioner for Superannuation to undertake immediately a random sample survey of persons now receiving invalidity pensions under the Scheme to enable me to reach conclusions on the extent to which invalidity pensioners are earning incomes from employment.

This step is preparatory to Government's consideration of a range of steps that might be taken to contain the rate of invalidity retirement and to make the invalidity side of this scheme operate in a more uniform and acceptable fashion. I am now foreshadowing that a number of measures will be adopted to achieve this goal; some will be simply administrative in nature and others will require minor changes in legislation. Departments and Authorities concerned will be asked to put together the administrative measures as quickly as possible.

For example, the Acting Commissioner has agreed that the information his Office provides to persons being retired on invalidity pensions will be expressed more specifically in two ways. All new pensioners are currently advised that their fitness for re-employment may be reviewed from time to time. In future those persons whose incapacity has been identified by the Commonwealth medical officer as being such that their health may later recover will be explicitly advised that they will be listed for early medical review. Also, it will be made clear to all new pensioners that if they change residential locality after retirement, this will not ordinarily constitute grounds for refusing an offer of re-employment in their former locality unless the change of locality occurred primarily for medical reasons which are still relevant.

An example of the matters that would involve changes to legislation is a proposal to allow trial periods of re-employment of invalidity pensioners who may have been found restored to fitness or whose fitness is being assessed. Under current legislation, there is a cumbersome procedure to prevent pensioners who have re-entered Commonwealth employment on a temporary basis from drawing both pension and salary. This procedure could in some circumstances produce an unintended result for the person concerned and act as a disincentive to re-employment trials. The proposed new arrangements would permit temporary suspension of pension, in part or in whole as appropriate, with automatic restoration if the employment trial fails. It will have attractions for both employers and pensioners.

Other measures that have been recommended as providing a positive approach to the basic problem go to means of improving occupational health in the Australian Public Service and Commonwealth employment, and increasing the emphasis placed on rehabilitation. This approach is in keeping with advice received from other sources such as the RSI Task Force.

The overall aim is to reduce the rate and cost of ill health retirements mainly through improvements in the invalidity retirement processes and in the procedures for handling invalidity pensioners whose health becomes restored.

The ACTU has made valuable contributions to the deliberations of the working party and I will be discussing with them a number of issues that remain to be resolved, prior to formulating proposals for other measures that would require legislative amendments. I will keep Honourable Senators informed of the progress of these considerations.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs:
(a) the role of the Parliament in relation to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and the National Companies and Securities Commission; and
(b) the role of the Parliament in relation to the operation and effectiveness of companies and securities legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have a short tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities was established by agreement between the State and Federal Governments in December 1978. It was established as part of a co-operative scheme designed to provide for regulation of the companies and securities industries. Consequently each government which is party to the Formal Agreement establishing the scheme is represented in the Council by its Minister of State responsible for the laws relating to company and the regulation of the securities industry.

The objectives of the co-operative scheme as outlined in the Formal agreement are to promote (i) uniformity in law and administration; (ii) commercial certainty; (iii) a reduction in business costs; (iv) greater efficiency of the capital markets; and (v) greater investor confidence through the provision of suitable investor protections. Consequently, the Agreement provides that `the administration of company law and the regulation of the securities industry within each State and Territory in accordance with the scheme established under this agreement shall, to the maximum extent practicable, be carried out by the entities and personnel of the State or Territory administration but those entities and personnel shall in the performance of those functions, be subject to direction by the National Commission'.

The National Commission is, of course, the National Commission on Companies and Securities which was established by Commonwealth legislation and, subject to the direction of the Ministerial Council, has responsibility for the `entire area of policy and administration with respect to company law and the regulation of the Securities industry'.
However, this arrangement has been the subject of considerable criticism by both practitioners and parliamentarians. In April of last year, the Confederation of Australian Industry commented

`After five years, the experiment in co-operative federalism in the form of the National Companies and Securities Scheme appears to have failed. The Scheme has not brought commercial certainty, nor has it brought about a significant reduction in business costs.

The final defect of the Scheme concerns the nature of the Scheme itself. The Ministerial Council . . . has undermined the principle of ministerial responsibility. The collective responsibility of the Ministerial Council means that no individual minister is responsible to the electors. In addition, the requirement that legislation amendments be approved by a simple majority of ministers has slowed down the legislative process, and sometimes has resulted in only `common denominator' proposals being advanced. (Source: Report by Confederation of Australian Industry, `Business Regulation-Areas for Reform', April 1985, at pp. 28-29)
The Australian Financial Review noted that this comment was `symptomatic of a general dissatisfaction with the present Federal States Consortium.'

In recent years this shortcoming has been the subject of Parliamentary criticism on both sides of the House. Apart from myself in recent years, Senators Durack and Peter Rae, among others, expressed concern about the possibility that the Parliament was being asked to `rubber-stamp' legislation which was initiated under the co-operative scheme. Senator Peter Rae in particular objected to the idea that the Parliament might be placed `in a position of being a mere cypher for giving imprimatur in legislative form to the decisions of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.' For the Australian Democrats, Senator Jack Evans accepted `that there is a very real hazard in the delegation of such powers to a ministerial council, which has no responsibility to any parliament in this country.' And the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, commented in 1984 that the co-operative scheme was `an almost wholly unsatisfactory way of responding to the very real needs of the Australian business community'. Senator Gareth Evans also suggested that one way to resolve some of the difficulties arising out of the co-operative scheme might be to refer to a Senate Committee. The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Tate, has recently similarly expressed his frustrations with the inability of the Senate properly to consider such legislation.

The object of the present motion is to address some of these widely expressed concerns by referring to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee the question of what role the Parliament should play in relation to legislation. This reference will enable the Committee to address issues such as:
(a) Role of the Parliament in relation to the Ministerial Council
* Capacity/incapacity of the Parliament and its Committees to make amendments to legislation approved by the Ministerial Council.
* Capacity/incapacity of persons and organisations affected by co-operative scheme legislation to influence legislation being enacted by Parliament.
(b) Role of the Parliament in relation to the NCSC
* Accountability/lack of accountability of the NCSC to the Parliament through the relevant Commonwealth Minister.

* Exercise of discretionary power by the NCSC; capacity of the NCSC to modify the terms of legislation (e.g. see Companies Act 1981 a.215c and Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 s.58); possibility of a rule-making power subject to parliamentary disallowance.

The object is not to review the efficiency or desirability of any particular provision enacted under the co-operative scheme. It is to examine the constitutionality in the broadest sense of that term of the scheme itself: to examine the structure of the scheme and to determine whether or not the operation of such a co-operative scheme is compatible with the notion of parliamentary control, ministerial responsibility and ministerial accountability to the Parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL (REPRESENTATION OF THE PEOPLE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Australia has a well earned reputation among western liberal democratic countries for leading the way in the adoption of advanced electoral procedures. But the many excellent features of Australian electoral systems also make it easy to overlook some serious defects.

Although most of the requirements for representative and responsible government are in place, there is substantial evidence of the failure of our electoral systems to provide the parliament that voters desire.

Figures for the 1984 House of Representatives elections show that 4,101,769 or 47.3% of all those who voted formally-marked first preferences for candidates who were not elected. For every 10 people who voted for candidates who were elected, there were 9 who did not.

This is despite the clear intent of sections 7 and 24 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth that the composition of each House should be determined by all the people. The test of any electoral legislation must that this intention is put into an acceptable practical form.

In recent times most of our effort has been devoted to determining who shall vote and to keeping the ratio of electors to politicians in some sort of uniformity. The real purpose of democratic elections, however, to enable the greatest possible number of people to be represented in government, appears to be entirely overlooked. Unless the elector's vote helps to elect a candidate of his choice, that vote is wasted and the voter is disenfranchised.

It is surprising, therefore, that almost no-one expresses any concern that nearly half the voters in single member electorates fail to gain political representatives of their choice. This is despite the fact that of the last ten House of Representatives elections, only those of 1972 and 1974 gave parties seats in reasonable agreement with their voting support.

The present single member electorate system exacerbates this situation for a variety of reasons. First, with only one seat to be filled from each electorate, it is inescapable that only one group of voters in each electorate can have the representation they want. While it is suggested that each local member represents and works for all the voters in his electorate whether they voted for him or her, I believe that representatives and constituents will find new opportunities under proportional representation to enhance that relationship. Representatives will be able to serve their electorate better if the electorate in question is based on a large community of shared life and interest.

The availability to electors of several members in an electorate could give greater likelihood of a person being able to contact a member with specialised knowledge of a given problem or with adequate sympathy for a particular point of view, or willingness to give proper attention to a constituent. It is well known that some members are more attentive than others to the needs of their electorate and that some members, for example, Ministers, are unable to give as much time for constituent problems as others.
I also believe that the scope of members to act together on issues affecting their area regardless of personal loyalty would be greatly enlarged to the benefit of the entire country.

The fact that many seats are `safe' for one or other of the parties also encourages governments to favour some electorates and to neglect others. Obviously, it is more important for a government to build up goodwill by spending money in marginal electorates than in those that are safe, especially those that are safe for its opponents. Under proportional representation, a party seeking to win government would need to win seats in every electorate.

A further advantage of proportional representation is that gerrymandering is virtually impossible. The difficulty of gerrymandering successfully increases with the number of seats per electorate and is an important reason for recommending that each electorate should retain at least five members.

It has been argued that gerrymandering can be largely eliminated by fair electoral distribution. While the impartial distribution of electoral boundaries for single member electorates is fair to the parties there is no possibility of finding one that is fair to voters.

The main criticisms of quota-preferential systems relate to the alleged tendency of such systems to lead to instability and to place individuals or small parties in positions where they can wield disproportionate influence in Parliament. This criticism is made despite the fact that relatively few candidates outside the major parties have been elected under the Tasmanian Hare-Clark system, the longest-running proportional representation system in the world, even though the quota in its 7 member electorates is only 12.5%.

It has also been suggested that proportional representation would make coalition almost inevitable and single party government unlikely. Whether coalition governments are desirable or not, the fact that Australia has had coalition federal government for about 35 of the past 50 years, shows that they are not prevented by a single member district system. We can be sure, however, that a coalition formed within a quota-preferential system would be consistent with opinion in the community and, therefore, likely to have more real strength than a single party government lacking popular support.

Replacement of the present single member electorate systems for the House of Representatives by a quota-preferential system would have both immediate and longer-term effects. From the first election the proportion of voters directly represented by candidates of their choice would be much higher. Along with this, the winning of seats by parties would be closely related to the voters for the parties. It would probably take more time for parties, members, candidates and voters to adjust fully to the new situation.
The full benefit to the parties and ultimately to the community, would be realised only when some of the practices associated with the present system were dropped.

In particular, it would be necessary for the parties to learn that substantial benefits for them could result from encouraging voters to choose freely within, as well as between, parties. The present system and the practice of single endorsement that goes with it inevitably mean that there are occasions when substantial numbers of potential party supporters are unhappy about the candidates endorsed by their parties. With a multi-member system any errors of judgment by those responsible for pre-selection need not have catastrophic consequences for the parties.

If the voters were offered a choice between several candidates of each party, they would indicate clearly which of the candidates they preferred, thus, among other things, providing the parties with valuable information.

From the national point of view, the most important benefit would be that Parliament would consist of people whom the voters would recognise as those they had chosen. On this basis, we might realistically expect a trend towards replacement of the present widespread distrust of the parliamentary system by respect for elected politicians and confidence in the institution of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- As I recall, I was in the middle of replying in the second reading debate on the Trade Practices Revision Bill. I think I was in the process of making two particular points when the debate was interrupted. The first was that the Bill had not been, as was asserted by a number of speakers opposite, rushed in some rude and abrupt way through the Parliament without a proper opportunity for consultation with the people affected in industry or anybody else. As I have had occasion to say previously, this is a very long-standing debate that has been going on about the trade practices legislation. It goes back to the Green Paper at the beginning of 1984. It has been the subject of enormously wide ranging industry representations. Legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives as early as 9 October 1985, with passage taking place on 19 November last year. Amendments were introduced into the House but they were essentially of a minor kind. The nature of those amendments was to take account of criticisms levelled by the Law Council of Australia. It was a responsive approach that was being adopted by the Government, and one that demands applause rather than the churlish criticism we had during the course of the second reading debate. The Bill that is now before us, although resubmitted to the Parliament, of course, after it was split into two parts, is nonetheless essentially the same as that which has been in the public domain in precisely this legislative form since October 1985-some seven months. It has already been extensively debated, of course, in both Houses.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that I was concerned to make in my second reading reply-a number of other specific matters can be picked up during the Committee stage-was in response to Senator Macklin's rather extraordinary conspiracy theory about the way in which the procedures have been handled in this matter. We have had a suggestion from him that the character of the identification of this Bill as a money Bill is misconceived; it is the product of some active campaign of deception; it is designed in some fashion to limit the capacity of the Senate to amend the Bill; and, generally speaking, some unholy precedent is being set for which everybody involved should be profoundly ashamed. I think that that would characterise the essence of Senator Macklin's contribution.

I say simply that there is no foundation whatsoever for a theory of the kind that Senator Macklin has erected. The description of this Bill as a money Bill, one requiring a message from the Governor-General and so on, is a product of an abundance of caution-one might even be tempted to say a superabundance of caution-on the part of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, which has taken the view that this is a money Bill by virtue of that clause which extends the operation of section 170 of the principal Act, clause 73 of the Bill now before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no message on 170.

—Whether or not there was a message, historically on section 170, I do not know, but I am advised that the operation of section 170 dealing with legal and financial assistance is being extended by clause 73 to make assistance available to parties to proceedings under section 163a-that is, the declarations provision-to the extent that it did extend the operation of section 170 in that way, it has the potential for increased funding for legal and financial assistance. It has been the consistent view, I am told, again, by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, that any provision dealing with entitlements to legal aid involves appropriations. This is not a new view, I am further told, in that the previous Trade Practices Amendment Bill was also transmitted to the Senate by a message received sort of formula.
—But not in 170, to which you refer.

—I am not in a position to respond to the allegation of selectivity in the approach to this matter. It may be that the superabundance of caution which has been demonstrated on this occasion has not been precisely reflected on every single previous instance. All I know is that I queried the description of this Bill in these terms. I was told that, for better or worse, that was the view that the Office of Parliamentary Counsel took. There was no question of any political input into this decision. It was just one that was made on entirely technical grounds. It would not seem that anything much follows from that decision having been made in those terms. The capacity of the Senate to amend legislation of this kind is limited only by the Constitution in respect of those money Bills which have to do with appropriations for the ordinary annual services of the Government. It is not the case that this Bill, on any view-even the most superabundantly cautious-could possibly be so described. In fact, my understanding is that the only Bills that are so described as a matter of course are the Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 3) each year and the Supply Bill (No. 1). As such, there would not seem to be any incapacity at all on the part of the Senate to amend this in any way that it saw fit. Of course I hope that it will not do so, but in terms of the technical capacity to do so, there does not seem to be any such limit.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the characteristics of a really good conspiracy theory is that it never dies. Every conclusive answer given to allegations made counts simply as further proof of the deviousness and dexterity of the conspirators in question. I do not know whether anything that I have said will satisfy Senator Macklin in this respect. All I can say, once again, is that I assure him absolutely and unequivocally that there is no hint of deviousness in the mind of the political perpetrators of this legislation, that is, the members of the Government. To the extent that there is any desire to treat the Bill in some way that is not terribly obvious to the rest of us, the responsibility for that decision should not be regarded as something to be sheeted home to the Government. It is a product of an abundance of caution-and quite proper caution-on the part of Parliamentary Counsel. I hope with those remarks we can now proceed to the second reading division on this very important piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 7, paragraph 17 (b), after proposed new sub-section 46 (7), add the following sub-section:
`(8) For the purposes of sub-section (7), an inference may be drawn from the conduct of a corporation only in the absence of any other reasonable explanation for the conduct.'.

When we were debating the Trade Practices Amendment Bill this matter was raised at the Committee stage. At that time I moved an amendment to add additional words to the end of proposed new sub-section 46 (7). What we are proposing in essence with the amendment now circulated is the same as we proposed, with some slight changes, in that previous debate. But instead of adding words to the end of sub-clause (7) we are now proposing that there be a separate sub-clause (8). I go over again the reasons for the amendment. First of all the Opposition is concerned about section 46 as a whole. We made our reasons for that clear in the previous debate. In essence, we are concerned about the concern that has been expressed by a wide range of organisations in the community, not just by business organisations but organisations such as the Law Council of Australia, which are very concerned about section 46 and in particular about section 46 (7). We share that concern in relation to section 46 (7). In our view and in the view of organisations such as the Law Council of Australia it is not clear that the predatory purpose inference in proposed new sub-section 46 (7) will be taken only in the cases referred to in section 46. If we are not clear on that point-if there is an uncertainty about the meaning of section 46 and in particular sub-section (7)-we are putting into law a dangerous clause. It will be unclear, confusing and difficult. Therefore, we are proposing that there be a clarification of sub-section (7) in the form of sub-section (8) to make it clear that predatory purpose, as mentioned in section 46 (7), can be inferred only from conduct inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion.

As I recall, in the earlier debate on this matter the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, in response to my raising of this point, said that he agreed with the spirit of what the Opposition was proposing, but that he would not agree to the actual proposed amendment because he felt that in some ways that would cut across the common law and across the ability of the courts to make judgmental decisions in these areas. On further consideration it seems to the Opposition that that is not a reasonable argument against the proposal that we are making to insert into the Trade Practices Act a new sub-section to make quite clear what we all seem to agree is the intent and purpose of section 46 (7) but which is not clear in section 46 (7) itself. To remove that potential danger of uncertainty and confusion for the clients of this Bill when it is passed, namely the business community generally, we think it is very important that that clarification be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — This amendment is in very similar terms to the amendment to proposed new sub-section 46 (7) that Senator Short moved on a previous occasion. I have already given him a full Government response to that. We had a debate about it in this place on 13 March at pages 1032 to 1033 of Hansard. I had also given a similar response in shorter compass to Senator Michael Baume earlier in the debate on that same day, which appears at page 950 of Hansard. I do not think under the circumstances that it is necessary to go over the arguments again. The change of language that is involved in this new formulation of the provision does not appear on my reading of it in the last couple of minutes-that is as much notice as we have had of this further exercise-to be significantly different and it is not claimed to be significantly different by its mover.

SPEECH.PARA: I will quickly summarise the points in opposition that we would make without going into elaborate detail. In the first place this provision would make proof more difficult than is the case at the moment. Any conduct having possible competitive implications could not be relied upon, and that would result in the enforcement of section 46 being made extremely difficult. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has conceded that there have been difficulties in establishing that corporations have had the anti-competitive purpose required under section 41. Insofar as helping to remove those difficulties, we believe that this sort of provision would very much accentuate them. The particular point that we make most strongly is that it does, notwithstanding suggestions to the contrary from Senator Short, impose more restrictions than is the case under the existing common law rules.

The common law does allow a court to draw inferences as to purpose or intent from objective conduct as distinct from relying solely on direct evidence of subjective intent. The amendment would really only permit inferences to be drawn from objective conduct which is susceptible of only one possible interpretation. So this amendment very dramatically limits the field of available evidence which the court can have regard to in making a decision as to whether there has been the necessary anti-competitive purpose. The amendment would remove the court's ability to balance out the probabilities of possible different interpretations of the reasons behind the conduct from which the inference has been drawn.

I know that Senator Short says it is still possible for the court to somehow make an on balance judgment on the basis of the evidence before it, but I genuinely believe that the way in which he has constructed his amendment so dramatically narrows the focus of permissible matters to which the courts can have regard that that is simply not so. If we are talking about objective evidence as distinct from subjective intent directly before the courts, the way in which this amendment is cast, limiting as it does the scope of that evidence to that which is susceptible of no other reasonable explanation, I think makes it impossible for the court to perform the kind of on-balance judgment which in practice we believe is necessary if this is to be a useful provision at all. Therefore, for those reasons, which I spelt out at more length in my earlier contribution to this debate, I urge the Senate to oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), like the rest of us, is feeling a little tired, but his was not a particularly inspired response to Senator Short's amendment. The other alternative is that maybe it is not as bad as Senator Evans is trying to make us believe. Frankly I cannot see a great deal of harm in the way the clause is now proposed to be worded. Certainly there was some concern back on 13 March about the wording that was proposed but it seems to be neither a particularly harmful amendment nor one that in fact is going to achieve much at all.
—You misunderstood. It is devastating in its impact.
—If it is so devastating perhaps when Senator Evans was standing up making his speech about it he could have sounded a little more convinced and been a little more convincing.
—You told me you were going to oppose it, you dope.
—I beg your pardon.
—You told me you were going to oppose it. You told me that you were not impressed by the arguments advanced in this place.

—I was even less impressed by Senator Evans's arguments opposing it. If my state of mind guarantees the enthusiasm of the Minister's speech heaven help the rest of the business with which we deal in this place. Of course, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has raised the question of inference and has raised it quite justifiably. Since I am in a cranky mood today, and was in a cranky mood to start with before the Minister stood up and burbled on, I am moved, shall we say, to support the wretched amendment in order to get on with something more important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — With respect, that was one of the most stupid and comprehensively dopey speeches I have ever heard in this place. If we are going to be reduced in a debate of this kind to the banal proposition that the strength of one's commitment to a particular change to legislation is based on one's assessment of the enthusiasm with which a particular speech is made addressing the issue we might as well pack our bags, walk out and leave it to the clowns of this Parliament-the Hodgmans of the Senate, if we have any-to conduct our debates for us.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Haines is unable to appreciate the significance of the change that is being made to the practical effectiveness of section 46, by a provision in these terms limiting the capacity, as it would, of the courts to have regard to a variety of pieces of evidence which put together can properly lead it to produce a conclusion that there has been the necessary anti-competitive conduct; if she cannot appreciate the extent to which the courts' range of focus would be narrowed by a provision in these terms; if she cannot appreciate the extent to which particular categories of evidence would be excluded from the courts' consideration she has abandoned any credible claim to represent the interests of any particular small business community which she claims to represent, because this is a clause of enormous significance to that community in particular. It has been gutted and filleted in its practical operation in the past because of the enormous ability litigants have had, and the courts have had too, in satisfying the language, the criteria that have to be satisfied in this particular clause. If she cannot appreciate the extent to which that gutting and filleting of proposed new sub-section 46 would be further accomplished by this particular innocuous-looking but in fact quite significant amendment that is being moved by Senator Short she really ought to reconsider whether she is appropriately representing the interests of those she wants to represent in this place.

I urge Senator Haines to look carefully at the merits of this-about which she had no difficulty in the last debate on this Bill and about which she had no apparent difficulty in the discussion we had 10 minutes before this debate commenced. I urge her to have another look at it and re-examine the merits of the particular proposal. I do not mind a debate being conducted on the merits but it does reach the height of absolute absurdity when one is having responses made on some assessment of the way in which a particular amendment is addressed by a spokesman for another party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition certainly will be supporting Senator Short's amendment to clause 17 of the Bill which, indeed, he moved on behalf of the Opposition. That little further outburst from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has not helped to clarify the position. The Government has proposed and has achieved, unfortunately with the support of the Australian Democrats, an amendment to the existing section 46 of the Act regarding the proof of a predatory purpose. The Opposition, when we debated this matter during debate on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill some weeks ago, opposed that effort by the Government because we were concerned that it was doing more and going further than simply restating the ordinary common law rules about proof of any purpose. The Government's proposed addition to section 46 of the principal Act reads:

SPEECH.PARA: ``(7) Without in any way limiting the manner in which the purpose of a person may be established for the purposes of any other provision of this Act, a corporation may be taken to have taken advantage of its power for a purpose referred to in sub-section (1) notwithstanding that the existence of that purpose is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.''.

We pointed out that in fact the law of evidence has always enabled inferences to be drawn from conduct as to purpose or intention or state of mind or object or whatever and that on the face of it this addition to section 46 did not seem to be making any difference to the ordinary existing rules of evidence. If the Government had come in here and said `yes, that is right, it does not make any difference to it' we probably would have accepted its assurance-bearing in mind the new rules of statutory interpretations where a Minister's statement as to what a particular clause was intended to mean could be quoted in court. However, the Government did not do that. Indeed, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in answers he has given to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills-we have had this debate and I do not want to go over it again-made it perfectly clear that the Government's object was to change the existing rules of evidence in relation to this matter. For that reason our concern then was very much excited and we moved to delete this clause because we could not see that there should be any change in the existing rules of evidence which are adequate to cover the situation.

The Government has seen fit to include this proposed new sub-section. Therefore, it has intended to make some change. In those circumstances a very serious question does arise which has been pointed out by the business law section of the Law Council of Australia in comments which it has made. Those comments are freely available, no doubt even to the Minister representing the Attorney-General in this place. Under that heading of `Business Law' the Law Council document, which was issued some time ago, states:

To the extent that a court has always been entitled to infer purpose from conduct the new 46 (7) only repeats the common law and is consequently unnecessary. If the new 46 (7) is to be included it must clearly establish that the requisite predatory purpose cannot be inferred merely from the inevitable consequences of genuinely competitive conduct.
That is what the real concern is. The document continues:
For example, profitable but low pricing by existing efficient competitors which prevents less efficient competitors from entering the markets should not be interpreted as an abuse of market power.

I think that the Australian Democrats would agree with that as well. However, once one passes this amendment that raises the question of whether as the Law Council says `profitable but low pricing by existing efficient competitors' may then be said by virtue of existing section 46 (7) to prove or establish a predatory purpose. So the Law Council suggested-and this is what Senator Short's amendment seeks to do-that we make it clear that the predatory purpose may be inferred only from conduct which is inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion.

The Law Council suggested that the amendment would overcome what is clearly the intention of the Government in bringing in new sub-section 46 (7). It is intended to change the rules. It will raise serious questions, and in fact, place an evidentiary burden of proof on defendants in these cases. That seems to be what this Government intends; and this is what the Opposition believes the Democrats are concerned about. In the light of the fact that the amendment to sub-section 46 (7) has been passed, we believe it is imperative that the further amendment Senator Short has moved should be added to clear up that particular question, which may well be an unintended consequence on the new additional 46 (7).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because, like Senator Haines, I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I must say that I thought the point she raised did not merit the sort of response that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) representing the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) gave her, particularly in the context of the Committee's report, which surely merits some more coherent and proper response. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, for example, having got a response from the Attorney-General on this matter, said very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: While the Committee recognises that it is always open to a court to draw inferences from conduct it suggests that new sub-section 46 (7) goes beyond this accepted principle in permitting inferences to be drawn from the effects of the corporation's conduct.
It then concludes:

. . . some doubt remains whether this is an appropriate case for imposing an evidential burden on the defendant and whether, if it is, the corporation should face the task not merely of rebutting inferences drawn from its own conduct but also of adducing evidence to counter inferences drawn from the conduct of others.
Accordingly the Committee continues to draw clause 16 to the attention of the Senate in the hope of promoting a fuller consideration . . .
For a Committee which the Senate recognises is under the `control' at least in nominal terms, of the Government-it has a majority on that Committee with the Chairman--

TALK.START.PARA: —It has never behaved in a partisan way.

—Exactly. It has never, as Senator Haines said, behaved as if it were under the control of the Government. I take that point. The fact is that this Committee is clearly expressing its concern about this matter. It is a Committee, which in nominal terms, has a Government dominance. To that extent I think the Committee's views should be taken very seriously indeed and should be responded to appropriately. I must say that I am concerned that Senator Haines was not responded to appropriately. I am even more concerned about the consequences of changes which would emerge if this sub-section were amended.

SPEECH.PARA: This is where I must say I am totally at odds with the Government because in response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee the Attorney- General made this extraordinary claim in which he said immense danger would be involved in omitting sub-section 46 (7). Perhaps we could hear from the Minister whether this danger exists in the mind of the Attorney-General-whether it is a guilty one or not-and whether it would exist in the event of Senator Short's amendment being passed. I object strongly to the way the Attorney-General endeavoured to stand over this place by making this remark to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. He argued that:
to amend clause 16 at this stage to omit proposed new sub-section 46 (7) might have-

`particularly serious consequences, since an amendment to remove from the Bill provisions already introduced into Parliament would almost certainly lead courts to the construction that the omissions were deliberately designed to negate what they would have provided for. The courts would, because of this, hold that `corporate purpose' could not be inferred and could only be proved by direct unequivocal evidence emanating from the highest level of management. This would make s.46 unworkable for all practical purposes . . .'

Either my friends and colleagues who are lawyers are all incompetent or else this is a disgraceful attempt improperly to stand over this place, to say that we have to proceed with this because the consequences of not proceeding with it will render this unworkable for all practical purposes. We have heard that kind of bunk from the bureaucracy in the past. When we were in government we used to get it, that if we did not fix something up or go down the track that the bureaucracy had set, we would destroy the legislation. Quite frankly, I refuse to be stood over in that way and I hope that the Senate refuses to be stood over in that way. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee certainly took a position where it refused to be stood over. It said:

If the Government were, for example, to introduce a Bill containing a clause stating `Thou shalt not murder' and the Bill were to be amended in the course of its passage to omit the clause, it would be appropriate for a court to conclude that the Parliament did not wish murder to be made the subject of a penal sanction. However, in the present case the mere omission of new sub-section 46 (7) should leave the common law, and the power of the courts to draw inferences from conduct, untouched, rather than having the positive and contrary effect argued for by the Attorney-General of negating all possibility of drawing such inferences.

This is the important point; the common law remains untouched. I admit that I find it extraordinary that any government would seek to pressurise this place with this kind of arrant nonsense. Perhaps the Government can deny that it is arrant nonsense. I would be interested to hear its argument. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee report continues:

If the Attorney-General were correct as to the effect of the omission of proposed new sub-section 46 (7) this would, as a general proposition, enable the Executive to fetter to a considerable extent the Parliament's freedom to action in relation to legislation. In a case where a court did consider it appropriate to refer to the legislative history of a Bill under section 15AB of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 one would imagine that all that would be necessary to prevent the court adopting the construction advanced by the Attorney-General would be a clear statement in the course of debate by the parties opposing the amendment of their reasons for doing so. The rejection of an amendment which is, for example, considered unnecessary given the current state of the law could hardly be construed as an attempt to alter that current state of the law in the contrary direction.

There, I think, we have a clear and proper statement. I would be grateful if the Minister representing the Attorney-General would indicate why this extraordinary attempt to stand over this chamber was made, whether, in fact, he stands by this remarkable advice from the Attorney-General and whether it was authorised by the Government. I would suggest that to remove any suggestion of this nonsense from the Attorney-General's Department-the Attorney-General has to take responsibility for it-and to make sure that it is not allowed to remain around this place, obviously the simplest and proper solution is to accept Senator Short's very sensible amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish just to respond to a couple of points that Senator Gareth Evans made in his response to my earlier remarks because it seems to me that what he has done is put forward a completely internally contradictory argument. To do so I need to refer to the previous debate we had in this place on 13 March. The basic reason for the amendment that the Opposition has moved today is really as a result of the concern widely expressed by a wide range of organisations-very reputable bodies throughout the whole of the business community-about the meaning of proposed new section 46. Amongst those many representations, perhaps the one that puts it most clearly is that of the Law Council of Australia. In a media release of 11 February, it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 46 is to be changed to prohibit corporations from engaging in competitive behaviour in a market where the corporation has a substantial degree of market power. The amendment should clearly establish that the predatory purpose of a corporation cannot be inferred merely from the inevitable consequences of genuinely competitive conduct. For example, profitable but low pricing by existing efficient manufacturers which prevents less efficient competitors from entering the market should not be interpreted as an abuse of market power. The Act should make it clear that predatory purpose can be inferred only from conduct inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion.
On the basis of that argument, which the Opposition accepts, we have moved this amendment today. In the same debate on 13 March, I stated-as reported at page 946 of Hansard-amongst other things--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where were you first quoting from?

—The quotation I have just given was from a media release of the Law Council of Australia of 11 February. I also read it into the Hansard on 13 March. The Minister will find it on page 949. In the same debate-here I refer to page 946 of Hansard-I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it worries me-
that is in relation to section 46-
that this clause is interpretable in more than one way . . . the many submissions that have been put to us all;-
that is, the Government as well as the Opposition and the Democrats-
that is, the claim that the amendments proposed to section 46, and to section 84,-
let us restrict it to section 46 at this stage-
will have the effect of stifling entrepreneurial activity and limiting competitive behaviour.
I then stated:

I ask Senator Evans for a clear statement that nothing in the proposed section is intended to affect normal vigorous competition and that the proposed section is intended to protect competition, not individual competitors.
The Minister said, for which I thanked him:

Yes, I am perfectly happy to give the Senate such an assurance. The whole philosophy of this legislation is to promote vigorous competition. The purpose of this clause is to protect the competitive process. It is not to protect individual competitors who may find themselves put to the wall by a proper and vigorous exercise of competitive forces in the market-place. Senator Short offered a very apt description of how legislation of this sort should be construed and I am happy to give the assurance in the terms in which he sought it.

That statement made by the Minister, really supporting what I think our amendment is trying to do, was also very supportive of the concern that the Democrats have had with this legislation and that we have had with this legislation-that is, that the interests of small business be protected as well as those of large business, and that the Act should not be amended in a way which is disadvantageous to small business.

The life-blood of small business is the competitive process and entrepreneurship. The Minister is saying that the Act should be interpreted in such a way as to support those things, yet he does not seem to be prepared to accept my amendment, and in fact, in response to Senator Haines's comments, the Minister said that my amendment would be disastrous. The Minister cannot have it both ways. Either this amendment fundamentally changes what the Government has told us is the spirit of section 46-namely, to promote entrepreneurship and vigorous competition-or it does not. We have accepted in good faith the Minister's argument that it is a competitive clause and not an anti-competitive clause. I cannot understand his refusal to accept this amendment. It seems to me that he is being totally inconsistent and contradictory in his two arguments. For that reason, I feel even more strongly than I have felt all along that it is essential that this sub-section goes into the Act to make it absolutely clear what we are talking about. If the Minister does not put that sub-section in, he will perpetuate the confusion, uncertainty and the lack of business confidence that the business community, large and small, is telling us it has with the Act as it is presently drafted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Let me give some examples of the way in which the effect of section 46 might be effectively undermined were Senator Short's amendment to be passed. In giving such examples and in making that argument I do not wish to be accused again by Senator Michael Baume of engaging in standover tactics, any more than I think that description is appropriate of Mr Lionel Bowen's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. If one, in a reasoned way, points to havoc that would be caused to a particular legislative scheme by some amendment, that is simply engaging in rational argument; it is not engaging in standover tactics. I have made it clear all along that I am perfectly happy to engage in rational argument on this matter. If my response to Senator Haines was a little vehement earlier on, it was because I believed that she was endeavouring to conduct the argument on a basis that had no regard to the merits of the argument but, rather, the merits of the theatre with which the argument was presented.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyway, let us get past that and back to the merits. Let me give the Senate some examples. Take for example the situation where a supplier is exercising complete control of a particular market, supplying 100 per cent. Take a situation where somebody tries to get into that particular market as a competing supplier, and take a situation where what is happening, objectively able to be established, is that a dramatic price reduction is made by the first 100 per cent supplier already in the market. Assume that on the basis of that dramatic price reduction the intending market entrant comes along and initiates a section 46 action saying that this is an example of effectively predatory conduct under section 46.

As the amendment stands, the court would be obliged, in the absence of clear evidence of subjective intent by the existing supplier, the 100 per cent occupant of the market, to have regard to the objective evidence of the spectacular price drop and would listen to any explanations that might be put in evidence by that particular supplier as to reasons for making that price drop other than to drive out the intending entrant. The court would weigh and balance those explanations and make up its mind as to whether or not this was a predatory exercise justifying section 46 sanctions. That is the way the existing common law would work, and with the direct encouragement that the existing section 46 (7) gives to the court to look at objective evidence and to weigh and balance it, that is the way in which the argument would proceed.

However, if Senator Short's amendment were to be passed, it would only be necessary for the existing market controller to put in evidence some other, on the face of it, reasonable explanation for it to then be impossible for the court to find in favour of the intending market entrant. It would only be necessary for the existing controller of that market to say: `Well, in the interest of good corporate relations with my existing buyers, I thought it was about time that we rearranged our price schedule and dropped our prices by 25 per cent. There has been a bit of recession running in the community at large. A lot of my purchasers are clearly pretty strapped for cash flow at the moment. Our profitability has been pretty good for the last four or five years'-that is not surprising since the firm has been the sole controller of that particular market-`We felt it would be a gesture of good corporate relations which would ensure the better profitability of our purchasers'. Let us assume that that is the explanation that is given. I think that would satisfy Senator Short's description of a reasonable explanation for the conduct.

I query whether on all the evidence before the court, it is at the end of the day the explanation that the court would accept. It would be a matter of the court weighing and balancing that explanation against the clear evidence of the imminent market entry by the new competitor and the evidence of the knowledge that the existing supplier had of that, perhaps some other evidence of previous patterns of business reaction to threats of new entrants and so on. Instead of being able to weigh and balance all of those considerations, as the existing clause would enable a court to do, the mere tendering of a `reasonable explanation' in terms of Senator Short's amendment would make it impossible for the court to go through that balancing act and make that finding. Look at the way in which the language is expressed. An inference may be drawn from the conduct of a corporation only in the absence of any other reasonable explanation for the conduct.

This is why, Senator Haines, I expressed a degree of anxiety about the apparently cavalier indifference-not perhaps indifference-or the view earlier expressed by the Democrats, that this was just words and it did not make any difference to the way in which this section was intended to operate. It does make a difference-potentially one heck of a difference-to the practical utility of this section by those whom we are trying to construct it for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you then go back and leave out section 46 (7) altogether? Then you would not raise this question.

—Perhaps that is something that will have to be considered by the Government. The difficulty has been, though, in the absence of proposed new section 46 (7), making it clear to the courts that they were not confined to purely subjective evidence. If we went back to that situation, we would create a situation which was identified by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee as one of uncertainty properly demanding legislative clarification. All we sought to do so far as proposed section 46 (7) was concerned was introduce that degree of legislative clarification. It was not intended to change the way in which the existing common law operated and in which traditionally, as we have kept saying throughout this debate, the courts have been able to have regard, in the absence of compelling subjective evidence, to objective evidence in order to establish purpose. That is all we are trying to do. That is why it has been put in there, and that is why there is still an argument for keeping it there in a way that does not distort the common law rules, as Senator Short's amendment would do, but rather preserves them intact.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to reply to Senator Michael Baume's concern about the onus of proof issues that are involved. Might I just say, because I do not think this point has been directly addressed in reply before, that we do not see proposed section 46 (7) as in any way reversing the onus of proof. It is a permissive provision only. The court may draw an inference. Moreover, the sub-section is directed only to the way in which the purpose of the corporation may be proved. It is seeking to negative the possible needs for there to be, in the absence of such a provision, direct evidence of purpose coming from the corporation itself. I think that is the only point I want to make. We can go into that in more detail. It is not an onus of proof provision; it is an evidentiary provision, identifying in a clear-cut way the kinds of evidence to which the court can have regard, making it clear that it is not necessary for there to be direct subjective intent evidence but that there can be objective evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean that around the other way, don't you? You keep on using objective and subjective. I think you are using them around the wrong way.
—I do not think so.
—You keep saying that the courts in the past have been looking at subjective evidence and now they are going to be allowed to look at objective evidence.

—There has been a view around, from the one or two cases in which this section has been run and the way the courts then responded to it and certainly in the way that litigants have regarded it, for better or worse, that what one needed to get a section 46 action going was some direct evidence of the state of mind of the particular alleged predator; that is, subjective evidence. That has been the argument. There has been the fear that in order for a section 46 action to proceed one really had to have that kind of evidence, that if corporations, if they were not silly enough to put their proposition on paper or set it in a speech somewhere that they were going to drive out this intending newcomer and one was just left with evidence of dramatic price reductions or some other behaviour of that kind, one could not get to first base. That was the kind of concern-that if one had only objective evidence of actual behaviour and no subjective evidence of actual intent in that very direct way, one was lost. That is why, with a bit of urging from various committees and so on that looked at this, we tried to clarify it in order to give section 46 some legs.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Australian Democrats to think again; I ask Senator Short to think again. I think we are trying to achieve the same result. We want this to be a vigorous competition-preserving piece of legislation. We do not see this as in any way undermining that objective. We are concerned that section 46 operates sensibly, that the courts be able to have regard to all the evidence that is relevant, to balance, to weigh up in the ordinary way, and make a decision at the end of the day whether or not there has been this kind of predatory purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for dealing with the matter of reverse onus. However, I would like to point out that element of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report that seems to me to be worthy of comment. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) suggested in his response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee that below average cost pricing would not of itself-and I think the Minister went to the point of describing how someone engaging in below average cost pricing could get out of a situation under Senator Short's amendment-be sufficient to enable an inference as to purpose to be drawn. In other words, he was saying: `Look, this legislation is pretty reasonable. It would not just have to be below average cost pricing to require the court to draw an inference'. The point is that the explanatory memorandum appears to be in some conflict with what the Minister says on this matter. The explanatory memorandum says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where a corporation with the requisite market power is, in the absence of countervailing evidence that its pricing was not aimed at destroying actual or potential competition, selling at below average variable cost there may be grounds for inferring that it is taking advantage of its power for a prescribed purpose.

Despite the Minister's assurance, the explanatory memorandum clearly says that in the absence of countervailing evidence there may be grounds for inferring that it has taken advantage of its power for a proscribed purpose. It seems to me that a pretty substantial burden is being passed on to a corporation in terms of providing the countervailing evidence. It seems to me that Senator's Short's amendment that this inference may be drawn only in the absence of other reasonable explanations of conduct will simply help the court-quite properly, I think-in making certain that the wishes of the Attorney-General, that these things would not of themselves be sufficient to enable an inference of purpose to be drawn, are met. It seems to me that, in effect, Senator Short's amendment assists the Attorney-General's interpretation of this matter which appears to be in some kind of conflict with the much more direct proposition which is put in the explanatory memorandum. I must say that while I take the point that we are talking here about an evidentiary burden rather than a totally reverse onus, it still is the general view of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee that such evidentiary burdens should be kept to a strict minimum unless absolutely necessary. I must say that I cannot see in this case why this general rule should be avoided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Durack, who is in charge of the carriage of the Trade Practices Revision Bill for the Opposition, will say a couple of words after me. I just want to make a couple of points in response to what the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, said. Firstly, he said several times in his last remarks that the whole purpose of what the Government was doing with section 46 was to clarify intent. The point I make and the point the Opposition makes is it may have been his intention to clarify intent but it has not happened. The members of the community who will have to live with this Act are confused. They are asking the Minister to do what he said he was going to do, which was to clarify intent. In the minds of the business community the Minister has not achieved that.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point is that I cannot see any reason in the comments that the Minister has made as to why the courts will not still have to exercise a subjective judgment of the type the Minister is saying they ought to have the right to exercise. Of course they will still have to weigh things in the balance at the end. The inclusion of sub-section (8) in proposed new section 46 will not lessen the requirement on them to make a judgment. That is what the legal process is about. I can see no reason why this proposal would actually restrict the courts in the exercising of their final judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the Minister that we postpone further consideration of this clause for the time being. It seems as though there is fairly basic agreement between all of us in relation to what we want to achieve. I have been looking at what Senator Gareth Evans said in this place when we dealt with the same issue in the previous Bill. I think that some of the problems have arisen from statements that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has made in answers to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills rather than anything Senator Gareth Evans said when he was speaking on the previous occasion on behalf of the Attorney-General. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly happy to accede to that suggestion. I think that most of the emotion has now drained out and we are back to having a reasonable debate.
—Yes, we are all warm and friendly. Isn't that nice?

—The honourable senator must acknowledge that there was a degree of provocation. I do not want to try to quantify that. While acceding to that suggestion, might I just respond to one of the points that Senator Michael Baume made, because it might be useful if it is in our minds when we are thinking about this matter. The first point I make is really to repeat something that I said on 13 March when we were last debating this issue. It is really picking up the theme that Senator Durack has indicated. I acknowledged when I earlier spoke that I did not see that a court would be likely to find against a defendant unless the evidence was pretty strongly biased toward a finding of predatory intent and the objective circumstances were such that the force of the evidence was pretty overwhelming. I maintain that point of view. As a practical matter, I do not see it as either desirable or likely that a court would reach an adverse finding on a section 46 litigation unless the evidence really did stack up in a pretty compelling way. I am just concerned to ensure that we do not have a situation created, as I think it would be created by Senator Short's amendment in its present language, where an essentially technical approach to the litigation could defeat what, on the merits, was stacking up pretty overwhelmingly as a case of predatory purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not really want to get into what the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) might have said or what he might be construed as having said in reply to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I think it is more constructive just to focus on what the section really is about and what the Government's intent is all about. Clause 55 of the explanatory memorandum is an accurate statement of our approach to this question.

Let me just put the point in another way before I sit down. On the whole question of drawing inferences from the effects of conduct, it would not be appropriate for a court to be drawing adverse inferences from effects which are highly ambiguous in their character and which could be construed as having a number of different explanations of which predatory purpose was simply one. But-I think this is the sort of thing that some of these other commentaries and responses are getting at-if a corporation, for example, which had previously been pricing its goods at a profitable level suddenly cut its prices so that it did not even recoup its average variable cost, and this happened at the same time as a potential competitor entered the market and there was no other compellingly reasonable explanation for such conduct, all that this proposed new section would provide, as it now stands, is that the court on the material before it could then, under proposed new section 46 (7), draw an inference as to the corporation's purpose. That really is a pretty long way from drawing an inference from a mere effect.

Everything depends on the context. Everything depends, I strongly argue, on the balance of evidence. There are various degrees of reasonableness with which explanations can be put forward. In a price cut situation, even though, on the face of it, there might be other reasonable explanations of the behaviour in question, if one started getting into a domain of actually under cutting one's own average variable costs, there would need to be a pretty compellingly reasonable alternative explanation before a court under those circumstances found otherwise than that there was a breach.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might have a marginal cost approach. That is quite justifiable.

—One might. This is a matter for proper argument in the circumstances of the particular case. I repeat that all we are concerned to do is to ensure that an argument of that kind is not defeated merely by someone coming in and saying: `Here it is. I have got a reasonable alternative explanation; therefore, under Senator Short's charter on section 46 (8), you can no longer possibly weigh in balance my explanation against the other explanation and find against me'. That is what I am concerned to avoid. I am not sure whether it is a matter of finding other language to express these concepts or whether we already have good language in proposed new section 46 (7) that needs only to be better explained. I guess that is something that we can usefully talk about outside the chamber and come back to it. So, after all of that, I accede to Senator Durack's request and hope that Senator Haines might be minded to do so as well.
