The Scrutiny of Bills Committee is very alert to that matter and has drawn attention to it for the reasons that it always does in these cases. It quotes comments from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on the matter. The Committee's report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee drew the clause to the attention of the Senate . . . in that by imposing the persuasive onus of proof on the defendant it might be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights.

That has been somewhat modified by the amendment that has just been agreed to the Bill. However our concern about this clause goes further than that particular question which arises under proposed new sub-section 51a (2). The reason why this amendment has been made at all is said to be as a result of a decision that was given in the Federal Court in the Mastertouch case. The effect of that decision was that it was thought that statements or predictions about the future do not come within the wording of sub-section 59 (2) of the Trade Practices Act. The decision of Mr Justice Franki in the Mastertouch case has been virtually reversed by a number of subsequent decisions of the courts. Sub-section 51a (1) says:

. . . where a corporation makes a representation with respect to any future matter . . . and the corporation does not have reasonable grounds for making the representation, the representation shall be taken to be misleading.

It has always been the case that representations about the future as such do not amount to representations on which action can be taken, but of course if that representation about the future is not one which the person making that representation believes to be the case, that itself is actionable because it is a false representation about the person's state of mind.

Again, we have the situation where this particular amendment is raising the very serious question of whether it is intended that there should be an alteration of the common law rules about representation so that in fact representations about future matters rather than representations of existing fact may themselves be actionable regardless of the representor's state of mind. Whether he was honest or dishonest would seem to be irrelevant. That is one of the most serious questions which arise under this new section.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee-or perhaps it was the Attorney-General-noted that there had been some further decisions in relation to this matter which apparently added to the concern caused by the Mastertouch decision. In fact, there have been further decisions on this matter which indicate that the actual decision in Mastertouch has not been adopted in subsequent cases. In the case of Jones v. Glenhoun Holdings Pty Ltd, a statement as to the expected return of the video franchise was held to be misleading. In that case the judge, Mr Justice Neaves, found that the statements would be misleading if the person making them did not believe that the forecast or prediction would be satisfied or if he believed that it was recklessly different. In the case of Reardon v. Aquajet Holdings (SA) Pty Ltd., the judge in that case, Mr Justice Fisher, held that the statement as to expected future earnings was misleading. He said that in the circumstances the statements were all misleading in that any person reading the advertisements would be led into the error of believing that there were sound reasons for anticipating that he would earn the stated remuneration. As a result of the decisions of judges Neaves and Fisher, it seems that we now have a proper understanding of the meaning of `misrepresentation' and a proper interpretation application of the Trade Practices Act.

Clause 21, in the terms in which it appears in the Bill, raises all sorts of new and additional problems. It may well be that the earlier decision in the Mastertouch case was wrong and indeed the view referred to in the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, that of Mr Justice Keely, may not have been followed as a result of the subsequent decisions to which I have referred. It may be quite unnecessary to do anything about the Mastertouch case. Even if it were felt that something should be done about that case, there are some very trenchant criticisms that can be made of the way in which the Government proposes to go about this with its proposed new section 51a. I have already raised the matter of whether it is intended to be worded in the way it is; whether it is intended to make any difference to the existing common law as to what may be held to be a misrepresentation. It refers to a person who makes representations about the future. Where it says `representations with respect to any future matter' and `the corporation does not have reasonable grounds for making representation', it may suggest that it is not intended to make any change. On the other hand, it may be that we are back to the same sort of problem as we had with clause 46, which we have been debating recently. As a result of the wording, it may well be that representations which turn out to be true would be caught by the provision, because even though it is a representation on a future matter and the person did not at the time have reasonable grounds for making a representation, it just says `the representation shall be taken to be misleading'. In fact it may not end up to be a misrepresentation, but on that definition it would have that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised a couple of matters in the second reading debate, but I will not go over them now because the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) is well aware of them and said at that time that it would be more appropriate to respond to them in the Committee stage. I must say that to an extent the discussion of the case of Thompson v. Mastertouch TV Services Pty Ltd reminds me a little of the discussions at great length about whether section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was meaningful or not. It is curious now to see that section resurrected as meaningful in a different environment, when it was thought not to be meaningful.

SPEECH.PARA: One faces the risk when in government of introducing legislation in some kind of kneejerk reaction to the view that the courts are not holding a view that one would like them to hold, but the legislation may trespass on people's personal rights and liberties quite unnecessarily, because there is only a temporary problem emerging within the legal system relating to interpretation. For example, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in correspondence to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, referred to a particular case and pointed out that one judge had held the view that even if the defendant were an incurable optimist who believed that incomes could be earned in circumstances where most other people with the same knowledge would not have had the same belief, in his opinion the statements did not contravene section 59 (2).

That clearly leads us to discuss the meaning of the words `recklessly indifferent'. It seems to me quite proper that the courts should establish what is recklessly indifferent. In the Mastertouch case, for example, on which the Government is relying for its assertions that something drastic such as a reverse onus of proof has to be introduced-or a more modest position, after the Australian Democrats moved their amendment which we supported, that an evidential burden be imposed-the judge in that case said that unless it could be shown that the defendant did not believe that the forecast or prediction would be satisfied or was recklessly indifferent concerning the forecast or prediction, the matter would not be caught under section 59 (1).

It is interesting that in the Attorney-General's advice to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee he did not mention those particular cases to which I referred in the second reading debate, which were Wild v. Menville Pty Ltd, Ducret v. Colourshot Pty Ltd and Reardon v. Aquajet Holdings (SA) Pty Ltd, all of which were subsequent to the Mastertouch case in 1977. As I mentioned at the time, it may well have been that some of those cases involved findings by the court following a guilty plea, in which case it would be natural that this matter had not been tested. I am unaware of the other case Senator Durack mentioned, but I am concerned that the Attorney-General did not act properly with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee by not referring to the decision in the case of Reardon v. Aquajet, which was several years subsequent to the Mastertouch case on which he relied in his correspondence to us rebutting our concerns.

In the case of Reardon v. Aquajet a manu- facturer of carpet cleaning machines sold the machines to persons answering employment advertisements for cleaners, which stated that the position offered a return of approximately $400 to $800 a week. The manufacturer was found to have breached section 59 when the earnings of the persons who purchased those machines proved to be substantially less than the advertised figures, and fines totalling $51,000 were imposed. Senator Durack mentioned this matter. Justice Fisher dealt with the matter of being recklessly indifferent and having a blameworthy state of mind attributable to the project. It seems to me that there is a real prospect within the existing law of coping not only with people who do not believe that their forecasts are attainable, but also with those who are recklessly indifferent. I think that is a most important point.

I regret that any Attorney-General, when responding to proper concerns by a Scrutiny of Bills Committee, should find himself capable of avoiding mention of such a finding by a court on a matter that is so material to the matter under debate. I would appreciate the assistance of the Minister, particularly on the other matters, but also on this question of whether or not the Attorney-General has treated the Senate in less than a proper way by not referring to this case which bears so heavily on the meaning of `reckless indifference'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to respond to the concerns that have been expressed by Senator Durack and Senator Michael Baume about this clause. The essence of the problem-to restate it-is that by virtue of the judgment of Mr Justice Franki in the Mastertouch case, a representation as to a future matter cannot be taken to be misleading within the meaning of the Trade Practices Act unless it is a false or misleading statement as to an existing fact; in particular, if it falsely represents the state of mind of the person making the statement. Where a person makes a prediction, that statement is actionable only if either of two conditions are satisfied-either that the person making the statement does not believe that the prediction will be satisfied, or if he is recklessly indifferent about whether it may be satisfied. The problem is that it is only if one can clearly get proof of non-belief or clear satisfactory proof of reckless indifference that one can get these actions going.

SPEECH.PARA: That statement of the law has been affirmed on numerous subsequent occasions. There is no ground for any suggestion that that statement of the law has been somehow countermanded by any future case. For example, it has been affirmed in the cases of Brown v. Jam Factory Pty Ltd (1980) 35 ALR 79 per Fox J.; Lyons v. Kern Constructions (Townsville) Pty Ltd (1983) 5 TPR 98 per Mr Justice Fitzgerald; and Walter v. Viney (1982) ATPR 40-31 per Fisher J. The practical problem that flows from that statement of the law in the Mastertouch case, back in 1977, is that it is virtually impossible to prove that the defendant did not believe, or that he was recklessly indifferent regarding, the prediction in question, unless one gets an actual admission of guilt from the defendant.

It is the case, to come directly to Senator Durack's and Senator Michael Baume's point, that there have been cases where, nonetheless, these actions have succeeded. It seems to us that there are only two sorts of circumstances under that existing statement of the law in which actions have been successful, and they fall into two categories: The first category is cases where the defendant has pleaded guilty. This was acknowledged by Senator Michael Baume a moment ago. The case of Wilde v Menville Pty Ltd in 1981 is a clear example of such, and that, I think, was one of the cases that Senator Michael Baume mentioned in his last contribution to this debate. That is straightforward. As he acknowledges, if the defendant pleads guilty, that does not say anything about the utility or otherwise of the present law.

The other category of cases in which actions have been successful, notwithstanding the rather formidable difficulties presented by the statement of law in the Mastertouch case, are those in which the prediction was held to have been not believed by the predictor, or alternatively made in a recklessly indifferent way, because there was evidence in those cases which did constitute clear proof of either of those states of mind and the particular evidence in issue-certainly this was so in the case of Reardon v Aquajet Holdings-was evidence of a previous history of persons who had taken up the promoter-defendant's offer of a franchise or whatever but had not earned anything near the earnings predicted, and there was evidence, presumably, that that was known to the promoter-defendant at the time that he made his further representation on the basis of which the action was sustained. So having had a long previous history of disappointed franchisees, all of whom were not in any way satisfied with what originally may have been merely optimistic predictions, it was held appropriate in those cases to find against the defendant.

It is the case that the Trade Practices Commission has reported that it received some 100 complaints regarding predictions during 1984-85 upon which it was unable to act because it could not get any evidence of the defendant's state of mind, either direct evidence, which is always hard to get, or the kind of compelling indirect evidence based on a past history that was in issue in the Aquajet case and I think also the Jones case, which was a similar story of past transactions. That, I think, is the situation as a practical matter that is extraordinarily difficult, and it is in order to overcome that kind of difficulty that this section 51A has been written. I am not sure that I have addressed in that response all the points that have been made by the Law Council but I think I have addressed the most important points that were made by the Opposition. If there is anything more it wants to raise, I will be happy to reply to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not dealt with the point that is made that the representation may turn out to be true. The Law Council of Australia has suggested that that ought to be overcome by an amendment to the effect that a representation, if incorrect, shall be taken to be misleading. It also suggested that if it is to remain in, it should be restricted to section 52 and should not be extended to section 53 or other sections because statements as to future conduct which are no more than reckless should not give rise to criminal prosecution. The point about the reverse onus of proof has been attended to by the amendment that has already been agreed to, but there are still other problems that the Law Council sees in this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to address this particular question as to whether the section should continue to have bite where a prediction turns out to be fortuitously true. The situation is that that is the case under the present law, that whether or not a prediction turns out to be satisfied is irrelevant to the question as to whether or not it was false or misleading at the time that it was made. That, on its face, might sound a somewhat bizarre state of affairs, but when one thinks through the logic of it, it is fairly compelling. That is why the present law is as it is. The crucial time is the time when the statement was made, not the time about which the statement makes a prediction.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, a surfboard franchisor might represent that a franchisee could expect to make $30,000 per annum and that prediction may prove to be satisfied even though at the time it was made the franchisor had no expectation whatsoever, perhaps by virtue of the fact that a whole series of people had gone broke previously. It might be recklessly indifferent or it might be quite deliberately falsely made, but nonetheless turn out to be true because, quite fortuitously, someone who purchased one of the wretched surfboards might be such a good rider that he wins a championship the following week and all the kids on the beach see this particular brand name and rush off to buy it, leaving the franchisee with a killing, much to the surprise of the franchisor. That is the sort of situation that can arise. It is a rather common experience in the law that expectations which turn out to be not satisfied are simply irrelevant.

Another example of this kind of principle at work is that a burglar who mistakenly steals a copy of a Ming dynasty vase, even though he thinks he is stealing the original, is guilty of no less a crime even though the expectation of the proceeds of his work is simply not satisfied. It must be right that one looks at the state of affairs at the time the statement is made, otherwise everyone would, even in the face of a breathtakingly dishonest statement being made which is quite properly the subject of action by the Commission or whatever, have to wait around to see whether some fortuitous state of affairs might arise which would result in the wildly implausible prediction turning out to be true. The fact that that principle is embodied in the present law is, I think, the best answer to the Law Council's concern that something has gone wrong in the drafting of this particular clause.

The last point that was made was why the section extends to criminal provisions and is not confined simply to section 52, that is to say civil actions. The reason why the Bill has been drafted in this way and extends in this way is that the Trade Practices Commission was unable to act on numerous complaints because of the law as it found it, and as I have already spelled out. If new section 51a was restricted in its application to civil actions in the way that the Law Council has suggested, effectively the Trade Practices Commission would be unable itself to take prosecutions except in the very extreme situations which I have already noted, that is to say where there is compelling evidence from some other source of the satisfaction of one or other legs of the Mastertouch rule. It is thought to be the case, I think accurately, that prosecutions have a salutary effect in this area, and that one or two strategic exercises by the Trade Practices Commission, with an appropriate criminal sanction being attached to that action, can have a significantly deterrent effect in the community as a whole and be a more effective way of ensuring that the principles of the legislation are upheld than simply relying on private civil actions. I think that is the character of the response that the Government would want to make to that query.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am still very concerned indeed about the Government's response to the reality that where reckless indifference is established, not as the result simply of someone pleading guilty but as a result of court action, such as cross-examination and so on, that there are clear opportunities available within the present law for these sorts of matters to succeed. The response of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) opens a door to me, I must say, to an understanding of something that I had thought was inexplicable because in the response of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is virtually impossible in most cases to obtain conclusive proof of lack of belief or recklessness from surrounding circumstances and without an admission of guilt from the defendant.

I had thought that in most cases that had in fact been tested. I find that in fact this is not so. For example, the Minister, having conceded that there are a couple of cases in which reckless indifference was established, then went on to say that in 100 complaints to the Trade Practices Commission it had been unable to act because it could get no compelling evidence on the matter. It seems to me totally inappropriate to suggest that the failure rate to get evidence to bring a matter on simply relates to the number of complaints, if you like, to the number of cases brought to the Commission, not cases that in fact have been tested. Certainly I would like to see some evidence from the Government to the effect that it is virtually impossible in most cases that have been tested in the courts to establish this point.

It may well be that the 100 complaints the Minister talks about were in fact complaints that did not deserve to succeed. I simply ask him what is the failure rate in tested matters and whether there is any indication, in the more up to date results such as Reardon v Aquajet Holdings (SA) Pty Ltd, that courts may be taking a softer view in terms of reckless indifference or a softer view in terms of benefit to the prosecution than was established in Thompson v Mastertouch TV Services Pty Ltd. I do not think it would be right for the Committee to accept the proposition that these things are always static and that the courts do not change their position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — One of the characteristics of intelligent species is that they act on the basis of reasoned forethought and reasoned judgment as to the outcomes of likely causes of action rather than immediately plunging into the action in question, crashing against a brick wall, bouncing back again and then regrouping their forces and crashing their heads against the same brick wall again and doing it 50 or 100 times in a row.
—You will tell us the history of the Bill of Rights in a minute.

—Yes, I think that interjection is worth recording. In this particular instance the judgment has been made, as it would be made by any intelligent prosecutor be he a director of public prosecutions or a State police prosecution officer, about what the law is on the one hand and what kind of factual evidence is required to meet the criteria set out in the law on the other hand. We are back to the kind of issue we were debating earlier this morning. It is essentially a subjective matter-a person's state of mind that he did not believe something. It is still essentially subjective as to whether someone was recklessly indifferent. For example, we may have someone who makes what are, on the face of it, fairly crazily optimistic predictions but made on the basis that the person is, as Mr Justice Keely said in the Miller case, an incurable optimist rather than that that person is recklessly indifferent to the outcome. That person may not be recklessly indifferent at all but may have made some sort of considered assessment of the risks and just built in a factor which no other rational human being would but which is very deliberately thought through as far as that individual is concerned. We have some in politics who behave that way. I really think that that is the point that is being made.

SPEECH.PARA: One has to establish by some sort of objective evidence that either of these two mental states of mind have in fact been in issue. When we have a whole history of past events which we know have been brought to the knowledge of the person then that is susceptible of no other interpretation, at least that was held in Aquajet and so on, other than that the person did not believe it or if he did think that it might have been believable was recklessly indifferent to the consequences of it. That is the reason, not because there is any need to go on establishing a pattern of knockbacks in these matters. Rational, legal analysis leads one to that conclusion. That has been the position adopted by the Trade Practices Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is whether the Aquajet case had in fact pushed the borders a little further.

—I do not believe so. I do not believe that the statement of the law, as I am advised, was any different at all in the Aquajet case than in the others. It just so happened that the particular factual circumstances there in issue made it possible for that law to be satisfied in a way that has not, in the judgment of the Trade Practices Commission, been able to be the case in all the other complaints that I have referred to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not just the case of Aquajet of course but there are other recent decisions such as that of Mr Justice Neaves in Jones v. Glenhoun Holdings. My advice as to what Mr Justice Neaves said seems to be quite impeccable. In other words, he interpreted the existing Act as meaning:

SPEECH.PARA: Statements would be misleading, even where they are a statement about the future.
This was as to the expected return of the profits of a video franchise business. He continued:
. . . would be misleading if the person making them did not believe that the forecast or the prediction would be satisfied, or was recklessly indifferent concerning them.

That seems to me to be a correct statement of the law which is the same as Mr Justice Fisher has done. That is the latest decision on this matter of which I have been advised. There may be others. If that is the case I would have thought that the Trade Practices Commission could now start to take heart. The problem I come back to in relation to the proposed new section 51 (a) is that if the test in relation to the representation about a future matter is different then a corporation presumably only has to prove by some objective methods that the person making representation did not have reasonable grounds for making it, even though the person himself may honestly have held that view and may be able to prove that under the more modest burden of proof that is now required under the proposed new sub-section (2). However he would still be liable to what are criminal sanctions even though he honestly believed or could not be said to have been recklessly indifferent to it.

It seems really that there is a major change in the law being contemplated here. It is not simply a matter of overcoming what appears to have been some rather limited judicial views as is exemplified by the Mastertouch case and one or two other cases which have been referred to. It seems as though there is a very major change in what are criminal liabilities imposed on people under the Trade Practices Act. It may be difficult at times to prove these things but, if in fact there is evidence that there were simply no grounds for a person holding a view-as has been the case in the Aquajet decision and in the decision of Mr Justice Neaves in the Glenhoun Holdings case-by passing this particular provision we may well be creating a situation in which people in future will be held liable for making statements which they really honestly believed to be true or were not reckless or indifferent as to whether they were true or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want simply to repeat myself but to the extent that a couple of other cases have been adverted to-Jones v. Glenhoun Holdings Pty Ltd and I think another case involving the same defendant, both of which were held to have satisfied the Mastertouch criteria-I think again it needs to be acknowledged that there are somewhat special circumstances in both those cases which made it relatively easy for the reckless indifference criterion to be satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: Those cases concerned video franchise. In the Jones case the respondent in question failed to give any evidence as to the basis upon which the representations to the question were made. He simply failed to turn up. At the same time, which is more or less equivalent to a plea of guilty although it was not so regarded, the court had not only to go through the motions but also to get sufficient evidence upon which he could then be held to be either non-believing or recklessly indifferent, and the evidence it did have was from a highly reputable retailer in the same area who gave lengthy and compelling evidence to the effect that it would have been absolutely impossible to double an investment of $17,000 in eight weeks in the retail shop of the kind in question. It was possible, under those circumstances, for the court not to hold that there was no belief but that there must have been at least reckless indifference as to the truth or otherwise of the assertion in question.

As I understand it, the other case of Geale and another against the same defendant, Glenhoun Holdings Pty Ltd, was based upon very similar facts and the case was run the same way, again without in either case any change to the statement of the law. All we are trying to do in this particular amendment, of course, is to create a situation where a representor can be made liable under the Trade Practices Act on the basis of having no reasonable grounds to make the representation in question. It is just a more easily satisfied criterion. It is not one that does violence to any basic principle of law of the kind with which the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was naturally concerned, particularly since, as has been said, the amendment by the Australian Democrats to change the character of the proof on the evidentiary onus has been accepted. I suppose we can go on arguing this all day as to the merits of different legal formulae, but the law is perfectly clear. There are very few cases in which the present law has been able to be satisfied. There is a compelling need that the law of false and misleading statements be able to be satisfied if consumer protection is to mean anything at all, and the Government strongly believes that these particular clauses ought to be supported.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the rural community is again out protesting its plight. It is a crisis which is largely due to overseas protectionism and domestic cost pressures. Both to varying degrees can be sheeted home to the ineptitude of this Government. First, I wish to deal with the issue of protectionism. One aspect which did not come out in the Government's rural statement was the major diplomatic failure of the Government in relation to the United States Farm Bill, another significant piece of international rural protectionism which has the potential to further severely harm Australian agriculture. Rural Australia is besieged by poor international commodity markets, due in no small part to the European Economic Community's common agricultural policy. That precedent was before the eyes of government: How the major economies of the world, when they determined to put their diversified economic wealth into subsidising rural production, can cause major harm to our rural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The CAP has resulted in a food mountain currently standing at more than $11 billion, including 17 million tonnes of grain, more than one million tonnes of butter, 790,000 tonnes of beef, 3.3 billion litres of wine and 487,000 tonnes of skim milk powder. Enough skim milk powder was surplus in 1983 to fill 33,500 railway wagons or form a train some 500 kilometres long. In many commodities, I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that the European Economic Community has not only supported its farmers but has made the EEC a net exporter in many cases where it used to be a net importer.

The costs to Australian agriculture are enormous. They are estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics as follows: Wheat growers, $290m; coarse grains, $100m; beef and veal, $220m; sheep meat, $40m; dairy products, $115m; and sugar, $80m. The costs, put down in terms of a cost per Australian farm, have been calculated by the BAE to be a total of $1 billion dollars or some $6,800 per farm. So a prudent government, one would have thought, would have been on guard. That was not the case with this Government. We know that because, shortly after the passing of the United States Farm Bill, we had the pleasure of meeting with a number of United States parliamentary delegations-congressional delegations were in this country-and none, I can advise the Senate, had any idea that the Bill that they had just passed detrimentally affected Australia. They claimed to have received no communications or lobbying from either our foreign affairs or trade missions. All claimed that they would have weighed the interests of Australia, obviously a close friend and ally and, more important in this debate, a country that does not significantly subsidise its agriculture-we are, therefore, not seen as the economic enemy-had they been made aware of the consequences to this country.

The United States Farm Bill is a $US76 billion package of price support and acreage restrictions, to be spent in just five years. The two most worrying aspects, I remind the Senate, of the Farm Bill are the export enhancement program, where $US1 billion-it was to be $US2 billion-is to be spent over three years to 1988-89, and commodity credits, where some $US325m is to be spent over each of the next three years also to 1988-89. The likely losers from the Farm Bill include sugar producers Brazil, the Philippines, the Dominican Republic and Australia-I remind the Senate that Australia is the fourth largest exporter-meat producers, New Zealand, Canada and Australia; rice producers, particularly Thailand and Pakistan; and wheat producers, Argentina, Australia and Canada. World wheat prices, for instance, are very sensitive to United States action as the United States is the largest single exporter whilst Australia is a price taker with a relatively small market share.

The Australian Wheat Board estimates that returns to wheat farmers could fall by $220m in 1986-87. The Farm Bill measures will bite harder in the following years as the United States price guarantee levels decline and, with them, world wheat prices. The fall could double or treble the Australian Wheat Board's original estimates. The success of United States' wheat sales to Egypt and the Yemen Arab Republic may be foretastes of what is to come. As we know, Egypt is a major wheat market for Australia, taking some 13 per cent of our exports, and we obviously cannot afford to be complacent. This is in addition to the existing food aid programs of the United States, such as the food for progress, where a minimum of 1.9 million tonnes of surplus food must be dispensed annually.

To put the United States Farm Bill in perspective, the $US76 billion involves a cost of some $US34,000 per farm over five years. An equivalent scheme in Australia would cost some $48,500 per farm over the same number of years, a cost of $8.4 billion. The cost per annum in Australia would exceed more than the Federal Government spends on any of industry assistance and development, housing, labour and employment, and foreign affairs and overseas aid. The Australian equivalent of $US76 billion-$109 billion-would virtually buy the world's annual production of wheat of some 500 million tonnes. So the assistance is obviously enormous, and all of this while the Australian Government apparently stood by with blank faces. Certainly there has been grandstanding since with trips by Mr Dawkins and Mr Hawke to the United States, but far too late. Once there is legislation in place in the United States, as there is, the farm lobby in that country is of such strength that, to suggest that the legislation would not be implemented, is to be extremely politically naive.

This new hurdle for rural producers is placed on a course which, I suggest, is already beset with domestic cost pressures which have been the result largely of government policy. How is the Australian rural producer who sells on a world market supposed to compete when he must produce in a cost environment where inflation is twice that of our trading partners, where interest rates are at their highest real level since the Great Depression, where additional taxes are forecast, where-despite the world crude oil price situation-fuel prices continue to rise in remote areas, where the burden of tariffs on his farming equipment has to be supported, with rising government charges which have dramatically escalated in the last few years, and with infrastructure deterioration of roads, in particular? In other words, he must exist with a cost structure originating from this Government-sheltered world of fantasy, the Australian accord, the unique accord, the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions axis, which has saddled Australia with an incomes policy uniquely at odds with some of the more successful incomes policies elsewhere in the world. Regrettably, the sinking dollar's benefits have been largely illusory due to what I have said to be poor commodity prices and the rising and rising import prices.

What is, therefore, to be done? With rural Australia producing 40 per cent of Australia's exports, the sector obviously cannot be allowed to fail. On the other hand, we could never afford to match the subsidies of economies with the size and diversity of the European Economic Community or the United States. On protectionism we must, therefore, work through diplomatic and political channels, through seeking to extend the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and by all other means to keep Australia's markets open and free from export subsidies. We must do better than this Government has done in its diplomatic endeavours in the recent past. Domestically the Government should scrap its accord which, as I have indicated, entrenches inflation. It should scrap the productivity claim, recognising that we now have a world ranking of No. 21 per capita in the gross domestic product stakes, an all-time low. We obviously cannot afford the productivity claim. The Government should end all its additional tax promises, not some of them. It should complete the process of removing tariffs from the farmers' means of production. It should reverse the trend of ever-growing government with continued pressure for higher taxes and charges and the competing demand for money forcing interest rates up. It should revise its fuel tax regime, and I suggest that the BAE proposals would be an interesting start for it to consider. It should reform an industrial relations policy which unfortunately detrimentally affects many of the processes ancillary to agriculture-transport, coastal transport, port practices and sometimes meat processing-with the effect that they are uncompetitive and therefore make our agricultural industry as a whole uncompetitive.

There is obviously much that industry itself can do-I suggest paying more attention to improving the value added of our rural exports by processing and presentation improvements and seeking out specialised markets. It is not all there for government; the whole industry can play a part. What I have tried to do in this short presentation is to end the myth that is promulgated by this Government that much of the plight of rural industry is beyond the resources of government to solve. That is not so. Much of it is a result of government policy or government ineptitude and there is an enormous amount that government can do if it was not hamstrung by its failing policies, if it was not subservient to the union movement and if it was prepared to show a little more courage and initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter that concerns me; that is, the extent to which the Senate was misled yesterday by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) relating to the very serious loss of over $12m that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation suffered as a result of being refused permission to get forward cover for its foreign exchange exposure until, belatedly, Senator Walsh's Department allowed that to take place in January of this year. The request initially was made in a tentative way by the ABC in November or December 1984, but then firm requests were made in May 1985 after there had been some devaluation of the dollar but before, of course, there was some further devaluation pressure. That request by the ABC was not acceded to by Senator Walsh's Department, for reasons which I believe should be revealed to this place because there was a substantial cost to the taxpayer involved in that failure by Senator Walsh's Department to act in what I believe was a responsible and proper manner.

SPEECH.PARA: When I raised this matter here Senator Walsh took the view, in fact actually said, that the cost of forward cover may well have exceeded the loss of $12.8m that the ABC suffered. If Senator Walsh did not know that was bunkum, as Minister for Finance he is incompetent. If he did know it was bunkum, he deliberately misled this place. The reality is simple: The cost of forward exchange cover in general relates to the interest differential between the rates of interest that exist in the home nation of the currency involved and Australia's. In other words, we know for a fact that the bulk of the ABC's television film commitments, for example, related to the United Kingdom because that was stated in the Senate Estimates Committee. We know for a fact that the basic original commitment was for $20m worth of film. That is revealed in the Forward Estimates. Of course, we do not know whether that commitment existed throughout that period-it may well have, on average, been much less than that-but we do know that that commitment increased significantly by $6.4m.

We are also aware of the fact, from the market-place, that had that commitment existed all that time until January, and had that exposure all been of course in United Kingdom pounds sterling, the cost would have been something like 2.4 per cent, because the annual rate would have been about 5 per cent, being the differential between interest rates in both nations. I have been advised by Sydney forward exchange operators, that the cost at the maximum would have been $500,000 for covering that particular commitment, a commitment that clearly should have been covered. Instead of suffering $500,000 cost in protecting the currency, we had this enormous loss to the public purse which is having to be replaced by taxpayers in these Supplementary Estimates.

I do not mind if Senator Walsh and his Department, or Senator Walsh in particular as a member of the Government, have a determined policy view that one should not forward cover. I do not mind if that is his view. I object that it should be his view, but I do not mind him holding it. What I do mind is his attempting to mislead this Senate about the cost involved in forward cover; and that cost can be clearly and properly identified. Of course, we might not be within a few dollars and a few cents or even a few thousand dollars and a few cents, but it is not beyond the wit of man, nor beyond the wit of a Minister for Finance, to find out what the costs of covering are.

I express my grave concern about this, as I have established that the cost of forward cover against the pound sterling over the 15 months of the Australian dollar's 53 per cent fall against the pound sterling since January 1985 would represent only about 5 per cent, had it all been on pound sterling, which of course would be about one-tenth of the loss that the ABC has been forced to suffer as a result of currency variations over this period. That is revealed in the Estimates. Okay, some people might say: `Yes, but there were some elements that were not in fact pound sterling but were American dollars'. There, as I understand it from my informants in the forward exchange market, the cost, being interest differential, was about 7 per cent-once again a tiny fraction of the sort of cost that the ABC has been forced to suffer because of the inappropriate and/or inefficient manner in which the Department of Finance has conducted itself in this respect.

I was very disappointed indeed to see the devious way, it seemed to me, that this matter was avoided when I raised it in the Senate Estimates Committee. It would have been quite easy for the people involved to have provided a ballpark figure, as in fact I was able to obtain from money market operators, instead of being told that it would depend upon particular circumstances. Of course, it would depend upon particular circumstances. Of course, it would depend upon particular circumstances at the time, but the average figures are readily available and if the ABC had not in fact been able to get something like the average figure, I would be massively surprised.

The figures quite clearly indicate that the $12.8m extra bill does not relate to any increased costs other than increased costs relating to devaluation. I want to stress then that, at the outside, the cost of covering this appears likely not to have exceeded something like $800,000, perhaps up to $1m, depending on two matters: Firstly, whether the full amount of the exposure existed throughout the whole of that seven-month period from 1 July until January, when belated approval was given, and, secondly, where in fact the exposure lay-did it lie in pound sterling, or other currencies where there was a greater cost of covering?

I believe this Senate is owed an explanation. When Senator Walsh said quite clearly and uncomplicatedly that the cost of cover may well have exceeded the S12.8m loss, that was-and I say it uncomplicatedly-false. It could not possibly be true. The exposure level is the relevant figure that demonstrates that to be totally false. There is no doubt that the Minister owes this place an apology and that his Department clearly owes the ABC an apology for preventing this instrumentality from covering its exposure.

I also would regard it as unfortunate that neither the ABC's annual report nor its estimates for last year indicate that the cost of foreign exchange losses last year was as a result of the Department of Finance not acceding to its initial response in November 1984. It appears to me that one may well be looking at an even larger loss than the $12.8m reported this year. Here we have the Department of Finance, which is supposed to be protecting the interests of taxpayers, protecting the revenue, if you like, from excessive loss and excessive spending by departments, being a party to a situation in which the Australian taxpayer loses at least $12m this year, by the look of things, and probably as much, if not more, in the last financial year.

I would simply like to add one other point on a totally different issue. It seems to me that this question of retirement for invalidity from the Commonwealth Public Service raises almost as many questions as the compensation scandal that was revealed at the weekend by the Waste Watch Committee. I have already, in another context, referred to the extraordinary fact that more people retired from the Commonwealth Public Service-at least those covered by the Superannuation Commissioner-from invalidity last year than in fact retired because they had reached retirement age. That certainly was curious enough, but what interests me is to look through the departments to see those departments where more people left for that purpose.

We looked at the Australian National Railways Commission when looking at compensation and found that there was something like an effective 30 per cent compensation rate-30 per cent of the staff, of the employees, went off on compensation at one stage or another. Here we see that 27 retired from invalidity and that only 17 retired as a result of age. In the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations 41 last year retired from invalidity; only 21 reached retiring age and retired. In the Department of Finance there was a high rate of invalidity. For example, 60 retired from invalidity as against 72 for age. In the Department of Health, the same number retired-ironic as it may seem-from invalidity as retired from age. Obviously the Health Department does not produce an aura of health. In the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, 39 retired from invalidity and 35 as a result of reaching retirement age. In postal activities, 487 retired because of invalidity; 304 as a result of age. As to the Department of the Special Minister of State, I do not know what impact the presence of Paddington Bear has on that Department, but 68 retired from invalidity and only 13 reached retirement age to retire. I do not know what special aura Mr Young has, but it certainly seems to make his Department sick! We come to Telecom: 1,090 retired from invalidity but only 717 reached retirement age.

There is no doubt a desperate need to examine these figures, just as there is to find out why, for example, in Victoria twice as many people retired from invalidity as retired from age but in New South Wales many more reached retirement age-for example, 975 reached retirement age and only 530 were invalided out. In every other State more were invalided out than reached retirement age. Were it not for this extraordinarily good performance in New South Wales, the figures on invalidity retirements would be far, far higher and, I believe, disgracefully so.

There are also some curious matters relating to the reason for retirement, and the Commissioner's report clearly shows this extraordinary thing: In Victoria 309 people retired from invalidity on the basis of neuroses, as against 95 in New South Wales. I do not know what is specifically neurotic about, firstly, being in Victoria and, secondly, working in the Public Service in Victoria, but these are most curious figures and this Government had better look into them to find out why. Is there something wrong in the work force in Victoria or is this some kind of ramp?

I feel that when figures like this have been presented to the Government, and on which no action has been taken, the Senate has every reason to wonder what on earth is going on. I am determined to keep pursuing this kind of what appears to be questionable expenditure, or at least questionable decisions. It may be that the Government has to use this device to get people out of the Public Service because it cannot sack them. In that case, it would be much better if in fact different kinds of rules were introduced into the Public Service so that this kind of invalidity was not used as a device to cover up other matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Education.
