Following the highly successful experience in Western Australia whereby the Cape Leeuwin lighthouse was opened to tourists, can the Minister say whether there are any plans to extend that policy to other lighthouses, particularly in view of the fact that lighthouses are extremely popular attractions and offer the taxpayer a good example of services the Government is providing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Childs suggests, the opening up of Cape Leeuwin lighthouse in Western Australia is a very valuable experience for the tourist industry. The Government's approach in this respect has been proven to be correct. Lighthouses are very attractive tourist destinations. Not only are they a longstanding part of history and of great heritage interest but also they have an attachment to the romance of the sea and the perils of being shipwrecked which are associated with various regions. Generally speaking, they are located at scenic spots of some interest to the tourist industry. Therefore, the Cape Leeuwin experience has been a very good one and the local tourist authorities have provided guides and collected the nominal entrance fees. This has prompted the Government to examine proposals to extend that experience to many other parts of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is now the Government's intention to extend this facility to other tourist organisations. Negotiations have been conducted in regard to other lighthouses, particularly those on the eastern coast of Australia. The Government has currently under consideration lighthouses at such locations as Byron Bay and Port Macquarie in New South Wales, Cape Schanck in Victoria, Low Head and Bruny in Tasmania and Moreton in Queensland. It is currently considering extending the experience in Western Australia and opening up other lighthouses for public inspection. These lighthouses would then become tourist attractions. This is seen as part of the work being carried out for the bicentennial year in 1988. The proposal that the Government is considering at the moment is how it can give stimulus to the tourist industry, because in most cases those lighthouses are in areas where stimulation will have some attraction for employment and small local industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. How confident is the Minister of the Prime Minister in his role as self-appointed mediator in the current conflict between the United States of America and Libya, particularly in view of his past practice in the Australian Council of Trade Unions of successful intervention after industrial disputation is over?

—One of the most encouraging things about this Government's approach to the very real crisis which has arisen from the action of the United States in Libya is that the public utterances by our representative in the United Nations and by the Prime Minister were couched in very modest terms. That is refreshing and I think it should be welcomed rather than have the sort of snide cynical question which Senator Parer asked. Too often in the past we have tended to adopt a very high profile on some of these issues for what in fact we are, which is a relatively small country. I believe that relatively small countries can exert great influences in international affairs as long as they do not overinflate their estimation of their capacity to exert that influence. I argue, for example, that Sweden-as a small country-in terms of reduction in international tension over many years, has exerted an enormous influence, having regard to its size. Its contribution to the United Nations, to overseas aid and to various peacekeeping forces throughout the world, and so on, has been totally disproportionate to the size of its population. In today's reported statement to the United Nations a role was suggested for this country but, as I said, it was couched in very modest terms. As I understand it, from what I have seen of reports from New York, the Prime Minister has approached the issue in exactly the same way. That approach should be welcomed by all those who are genuinely concerned to see a reduction in international tension and not some knee-jerk tribal loyalty response to what has happened in Libya that has been apparent from some political activists and commentators in this country in the last few days.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that home heating oil prices have risen recently despite falls in crude oil prices? Will the Minister indicate possible reasons for this discrepancy which is of great concern to over 20,000 Tasmanian householders, and, no doubt, to many mainland users? Given that home heating oil is a non-notifiable product and is therefore excluded from the regime of the Prices Surveillance Authority, will the Minister inform the Senate of measures open to the Government to overcome this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a number of representations on this matter over the last few weeks, in response to which I have asked the Treasurer to consider whether the Prices Surveillance Authority should reintroduce formal surveillance over the presently non-notifiable petroleum products-that is to say, heating oil, kerosene, fuel oil, industrial diesel, bitumen and naptha. The question as to the reintroduction of formal surveillance is now being actively considered, but it is not yet finally resolved. In the meantime, however, the Government has received some very useful information from the PSA about present price patterns in those pro- ducts, pursuant to the arrangement which has applied since 1984 whereby the oil companies undertook to continue to provide the PSA with information on costs and prices for those products to enable the Authority to remain generally informed on the range of products and to be able to recommend the reintroduction of surveillance of that should be warranted.

ANSWER.PARA: It appears that five of the oil companies have reduced the wholesale prices of some or all of the non-notifiable products, but including in each case heating oil and lighting kerosene, since the March import parity price adjustment. The price reductions for these products have been broadly in line with the reductions in the maximum wholesale prices for notifiable petroleum products, after allowance for differences in excise rates. In particular, it is the case that Esso reduced its prices for all non-notifiable products except bitumen by 9c per litre, on 15 March. Mobil Oil reduced its prices for heating oil and lighting kerosene by 10.1c per litre on 8 April. Shell came to the party a couple of days ago by reducing its price for all non-notifiable products by around 8 1/2c per litre, on 14 April. Ampol reduced its prices for all non-notifiable products except lubricants by 9c per litre, again on 14 April. BP is to reduce its prices for all non-notifiable products by around 10c per litre today. That leaves only Caltex. Maybe in the light of this information being made public, even though Caltex is more strapped than most of the industry, at least in the volume of its public representations in relation to stock losses, I hope it may be possible as a result for those price reductions to flow there too.

In view of those developments that I have just indicated, it is not clear that the problem is quite as severe as the representations that I have been receiving on this issue and, again, as Senator Tate's question would suggest. Nonetheless, the Government is particularly concerned to ensure that consumers, particularly pensioners who are so often dependent on these products, get the benefit of the lower crude oil prices, in particular with regard to heating oil and kerosene. I have just been advised that the Treasurer has asked the Prices Surveillance Authority formally to advise whether it considers there should be any change in the surveillance arrangements, having regard to the recent price developments and to the established criteria for the exercise of surveillance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the Government's offer of $54m for a sugar price support scheme of $230, $225, and $220 per tonne for each year 1985, 1986 and 1987. Is the Minister aware that on yesterday's London market sugar was $223 a tonne and rising? In view of the rising market, only $17m of the $54m will be required for price support, leaving a residue of $37m. Will the Government add the remaining $37m from the price support scheme to the amount of $46m allocated for rural reconstruction and make the sugar industry package worth $100m, as stated in the rural package and not $63m over three years which is a little over half of the $150m promised--
—Order! The honourable senator is giving too much information. I ask him to bring his question to a close.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear all of Senator Boswell's questions, but I do not think it matters very much. The Government's offer, which has been on the table for more than six months, was to underwrite for the next three years returns at those prices, subject to a matching contribution from the Queensland Government. The offer is what it always was-that is, if there is a deficiency between the market price and those prices of $230, $225 and $220 respectively, then that deficiency will be made up by the joint contribution, with the proviso that there would be a ceiling at all times on the total amount that would be paid. In other words, if the difference between $230 per tonne in the first year and the actual price received-say, for example, it was $100 per tonne-turned out to be $150m or something like that in just the one year, it is the case that the Government's offer never did commit the Government to paying that much money. There was a ceiling on the amount of money. That was done quite deliberately because, regardless of what the price of sugar might have been on the London exchange yesterday, all the expectations in the industry and in the Government are that in the long term world prices will be low.

ANSWER.PARA: Concomitantly, of course, the industry must be restructured so that it can produce at those likely world prices. That restructuring is being sabotaged by the ignorance and prejudice of the Premier of Queensland, who cuts off Mr Turner, the Minister for Primary Industries, at the knees every time Mr Turner comes close to reaching agreement with the Commonwealth Government. That ignorant, bungling, old Otto the Hun cuts Turner off at the knees, prevents the package from being adopted and prevents the restructuring of the industry which is essential for its long term survival.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. It is a pretty rough game, but I do not think there is any need for the sort of adjectives that the Minister used in regard to the Premier of a sovereign State. I find them offensive and unwarranted.

—My attention was temporarily distracted at the time the references were made. But if Senator Collard has taken personal objection to them, I ask the Minister, under standing order 418, to withdraw his remark.
—I withdraw.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations seen a report in the West Australian newspaper of Tuesday, 15 April, and in other newspapers concerning the Australian Bureau of Statistics industrial dispute figures for 1985? What is the Government's reaction to the figures? Do the State figures in any way support the claim that Queensland is continuing to drag Australia backwards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent bulletin on industrial disputes which was issued last Monday, 14 April, shows that in the 12 months ending December 1985 Queensland had by far the highest number of working days lost per 1,000 employees of any State. Queensland lost 417 working days per 1,000 employees, as against a national average of 230. I think the figure for South Australia is 49, which is extremely low, and the figure for New South Wales and Victoria is somewhat over 200. But the important point is that the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees was almost twice as high in Queensland as the national average. It is one of a number of statistics in regard to which the Queensland figures are the highest in Australia. As has been mentioned here previously, the rates of teenage pregnancies, ex-nuptial births and venereal disease in Queensland are also by far the highest, which can be ascribed to the ignorance of sexual matters which the Queensland Government seems to be dedicated to perpetuating.

ANSWER.PARA: In every other respect, the positive economic indicators-that is, the rate of employment, the rate of growth, the rate of investment, and so on-show that Queensland has very close to the lowest figure, if not the lowest, of all the States. It is below the national average in each of those three cases, I believe, and it is indeed so that Queensland is dragging Australia down.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OIL REFINERS: STOCK LOSS COMPENSATION PACKAGE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to Press reports today which indicate that there is some misunderstanding between the Government and oil refiners about tax aspects of the proposed stock loss compensation package. Is the Minister able to indicate what action is being taken to rectify this problem? Will the Minister give a commitment that consumers will not be forced to bear the brunt of full compensation to oil refiners through any further price increases? I noted with interest the response he made to a question asked by Senator Tate a little earlier today.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The context in which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked her question is this: The immediate impact of the 1 March import parity price reduction was to create a situation in which the Australian refiners incurred stock losses-by the downward revaluation of the stock they had already acquired-of close to $600m. There have been subsequent additions to that pre-tax amount, as a result of the further reduction in the import parity price in April. The Government took the view that it was appropriate that a compensation package be put together involving some limited recoupment through the market-place, with the balance to be picked up by the Government, in order to reimburse the refiners for at least that part of their stock losses which they incurred through continuing to lift domestic Australian crude during the month of February; that is, after the world price had tumbled--
—I am sure Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle understands this perfectly.
—I am damned sure I am not persuaded that you do, Senator. For your benefit, if for that of nobody else in this place, I think it is appropriate--
—Order! I ask the Minister to ignore the interjection and answer the question.

—This is a necessary prelude to answering that part of the question which relates to the tax issue. The arrangement that was made with the industry was to put together a compensation package which would fully reimburse the industry for that part of its stock losses accrued as a result of continuing to lift, at government request, high price domestic crude during the month of February at which time, the prices having already come down at the world level, it could have imported crude much more cheaply. In fact, during the month of February the industry, at the Government's request, lifted about 13 million barrels of Australian crude, paying about $16 more for each barrel than it would have had to pay on the world market if it had been able to get cargoes at spot prices. That added up to $210m, $125m of which the Government is proposing to reimburse under this legislation, the other part having been picked up through the market-place.

ANSWER.PARA: The confusion that has arisen about the taxation issue has been because the companies misunderstood-and that is an appropriate description-the Government's original statement that this payment would be tax-free. What we meant to convey by that was that there would be no dilution of the full value of that compensation so far as the February liftings were concerned. The intention was always to fully compensate for the February liftings by reference to the difference between the 1 January and 1 March import parity prices, and not to have that compensation for February diluted by any tax claw-back. It was on that basis that the companies were advised of the original package and it was on that basis that some of them did misunderstand the Government's intentions. The Government's intention was to confine the direct government reimbursement to those February liftings, treating the rest essentially as commercial risk. The intention was not to pay compensation on a basis that would make a contribution to the refiners' remaining stock loss problem, very substantial although that problem is frankly acknowledged to be.

It is a complicated issue. It needs more explanation than that, I suspect, to fill it out. But that is more than enough of an explanation, I also suspect, for this chamber. I sent a detailed telex to the companies last night, explaining the matter. I think most of them now understand the reason why the final dollars in hand are not likely to be quite as many as some of them had originally optimistically thought. As to the latter part of the question concerning further flow-through of prices to the consumer, I am not sure whether Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was referring to the result of further price reductions in the world market or whether she was talking about the consequence of recoupment exercises by the refiners in relation to previous stock losses. The answer varies depending on what she meant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I was referring to the present situation of the stock losses and asking whether the Government would support an application to the Prices Surveillance Authority on the grounds of this lack of compensation for the present problem.

—The Government's estimate is that even after the recoupment efforts that have taken place so far and which were authorised yesterday by the Prices Surveillance Authority, and even after this $125m is paid, the refiners will still face, net of tax considerations, a stock loss burden of about $300m. So there is a very substantial burden for the companies to bear. That is one reason why they are being so vociferous in the media at the moment, and understandably so. It is not the Government's view that that particular already accumulated burden should be recouped through increases in present product prices authorised by the PSA. We have made that clear in public statements. As prices rise again, as they are expected to at some stage in the latter part of this year-goodness knows by how much-perhaps it will be possible by appropriately timed adjustments to the wholesale price ceilings for a good proportion of that already accumulated stock loss to be recouped, but not at the expense of any major new impost that would flow through with additional burdens for consumers and, of course, add to the inflation rate.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister seen a circular letter from the Doctors Reform Society, dated 14 April, which indicates that a decision has been taken to reduce the Medicare rebate to doctors who bulk bill? Is there any truth in this assertion? If so, why has this been done? Surely it will only further disadvantage those doctors in the community who bulk bill all their patients.

—Yes, I have seen the letter which was circulated by Dr John Daniels, who is the President of the Doctors Reform Society of New South Wales. I can assure Senator McIntosh that there is no truth at all in the assertions in the letter. No such decision has been made: no such decision will be announced in the next week, two weeks or any other week. I understand that Dr Daniels has today telegrammed the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, acknowledging that the information is wrong. I hope that in the future Dr Daniels will be much more careful about taking notice of stories like this which are fed to him, obviously by people with malicious intent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to a recent statement by the Treasurer in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia is hooked on imports-or has been-and while we were able to find another deposit of coal or iron ore to pay for it, or another paddock of wheat, that was fine.
How does the Government intend to encourage Australians to kick the import habit, other than by maintaining a credit squeeze through high interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Changing attitudes in this country on fundamental matters like this is like moving tombstones. We, as a Government, are to be congratulated because at least we are trying. The sad thing is that, on the fundamental issue involved in Senator Brownhill's question, previous governments have not tried. I do not blame them for that; I am not seeking to make a political point.
—Yes, you are.

—If you think I am, Senator, then let the cap fit you. I was not trying to make a political point; I was trying to make a point about a nation's capacity for delusion about issues. This was most admirably demonstrated in the political context by the rhetoric which surrounded the resources boom. That was one of the greatest disasters for this country in attitudinal terms, following as it did the comfortable belief that this country could live off the sheep's back forever. If the honourable senator is asking me whether the Government proposes to kick the import habit by adopting some of the bizarre suggestions that have been floating about, such as import quotas and things of that kind, the answer is no. The Government does not propose to adopt those suggestions. We derive some small comfort from the last trade figures which were published earlier this week. We hope that that is indicative of a trend.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Brownhill that the largest item in imports in the last few months has been the category of transport equipment and heavy machinery and so on, which is consistent with a significant degree of investment in manufacturing industry and which, in the longer term, is a source of structural strength and growth and, indeed, a diversification of manufacturing activity. That is a source of an input into the Australian economy by imports which the Government would not seek to discourage in the short term. Mr Keating has offered some colourful comments about this matter in the article from which Senator Brownhill quoted. There are no immediate solutions to those problems, but it is important to be aware of them and to try to address them on a wide range of fronts.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Community Services. Has the Minister seen claims by the shadow Minister for Social Security that welfare cuts will force wives to work? Can the Minister tell the Senate the effects that these outlandish claims are having on Australian families? Is the Government committed to improving the lives of families in need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Government is committed to improving the lives of families in need in this country and we have demonstrated that. Yes, I have seen the claims of the shadow Minister, Mr Blunt. It is one of the many claims that have been made this week by members of the National Party of Australia and it is becoming quite difficult in this place or any other place to understand what they are on about. It seems to me that we have two wings of the National Party-we have the patrician wing, led by Mr Blunt and co., who say that the Government will cut social security expenditure and that it should not do so; then there is the thick wing led by Mrs Chapman from Queensland and Senator Boswell in this place who want to stop all social security expenditure and put all the beneficiaries out into the street.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is about time that the National Party woke up and decided where it stood. It has always had great difficulties with this over the years. I remember that some 10 or 11 years ago in one memorable speech Senator Sheil said that we should cut off all unemployment benefits because the beneficiaries spent all their time fornicating on the foreshores. The only problem with that speech was that, instead of saying those words with indignation, Senator Sheil said them with envy and nobody believed him. It really is a mad situation when a party which claims to have a policy which is concerned with people in difficulties and families in trouble has a Minister in Queensland who says that all this expenditure should be cut off because the beneficiaries are spending all their time having children and doing all sorts of nasty things. Of course, here in the Senate we have Senator Boswell who raves in his usual manner about women taking over the world and particularly taking over his job, I think. Then we have Mr Blunt who says that this terrible Government is going to cut expenditure-apparently it will do exactly what Mrs Chapman wants us to do-and this means that it will send women out to work.

I think the best thing to do is look at the Government's record. Under the previous Government, allowances for guardians and pensioners' and children's benefits all fell in real terms over the time of that Government. Since 1983 we have increased the additional pensioner benefit for children by 60 per cent; we have increased the mothers'/guardians' allowance; and we have increased the family income supplement by 60 per cent, thus making it easier for the women in low income families to stay at home. We have increased the number of child care places, enabling some women to work and other women, in lonely situations in the suburbs, to get some respite from their loneliness and difficulties in bringing up their children.

We will continue to follow that policy. The community knows that we will do that. The community knows the real people who are concerned about cutting assistance to people in need, and particularly families in need, are in the party of which Mr Blunt, Mrs Chapman, Senator Boswell and Senator Sheil are all members. They are all the old troglodytes who would wipe out all welfare expenditure in this country. The people of this country know that and therefore they will take no notice of the ravings of the likes of Mr Blunt.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. Is the Government concerned about the industrial confrontation and arrests which have occurred on construction sites in the Australian Capital Territory in the last few days, particularly on the new Parliament House site for which the Commonwealth has direct responsibility? Does the Minister deplore the decision of the Australian Capital Territory Branch of the Australian Labor Party and the local Trades and Labour Council to support the rogue Builders Labourers Federation against the positions of the Federal Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions on deregistration? Will the Minister publicly dissociate herself from her branch's decision or, as with the ANZUS Treaty incident early last year, is she worried that such a stand might jeopardise her preselection?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give an answer to that part of the honourable senator's question which has to do with housing and construction policy. With regard to the parts of the question concerning the internal affairs of the local branch of the ALP, I will say nothing to him because this is not a matter within the ministerial responsibility of the Minister for Housing and Construction and it is none of his business. Of course we are concerned about the problems on the construction site of the new and permanent Parliament House. We are not only concerned about it; we have taken very brave and radical action to bring about peace in the building and construction industry.

ANSWER.PARA: We have taken action which is more effective than action taken by any of our conservative predecessors. We have taken the unprecedented but successful step of deregistering a union because it would not abide by the proper procedures governing industrial relations in this country. We have taken the further step of properly providing for union membership of members of the former Builders Labourers Federation so that they will not be without the benefits of union coverage. At this point I think we should all commend my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, who has had the carriage of this affair and who has conducted himself with great patience and persistence in an extraordinarily difficult situation.

It is our Government which has re-established the building and construction industry in this country. It was in total disarray at the time we came into government. It is our Government that has had to take the very tough and difficult steps of having the Builders Labourers Federation deregistered because of its illegal activities. It is our Government which will successfully bring about peace in the building and construction industry so that not only the construction site of the new and permanent Parliament House but all construction sites throughout Australia will operate properly, within properly established industrial awards, and offer protection alike to workers on those sites and investors in those projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I draw your attention to standing order 98 about questions which may be put to Ministers of the Crown relating to public affairs, and I ask the Minister, in her capacity as a Minister of the Crown, a question relating to public affairs: Why will she not support the Government of this country against her own branch of the Australian Labor Party?
—Order! I rule that the question is not a supplementary question.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Hawke Government initiatives of introducing in 1984 the management and investment companies program. Now that this program is over two years old, can the Minister give any indication as to whether the program is succeeding in its objectives? What is the future likely to be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Cook's question because it is important that these institutions be accountable to the Parliament and it is important that progress in respect of some of them be reviewed from time to time. Senator Cook is quite right in saying that the management and investment companies program was introduced early in 1984. That program was designed to encourage the development of a venture capital market in Australia and to attract management and financial support for the start up and early growth of businesses which had the potential to grow, which were export oriented and which used innovative technology.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government, and indeed the previous Government in setting up the Espie inquiry, recognised the need to provide a stimulus to the development of a vigorous venture capital market. The MIC program also recognised that it was important for Australia to encourage innovative entrepreneurial businesses which creatively use modern technology as part of our effort to revitalise Australian manufacturing industry. I am generally pleased with the progress of the program so far. It was a very new initiative. So far the progress has been excellent. At the end of March 1986, management and investment companies had 65 actual investments in 54 different businesses. The predominant fields of investment are computer hardware and software, electronics equipment and robotics, biomedical companies, and biotechnological products and services.

About 50 per cent of the management and investment company investments have been in the start up and early stages of businesses. At the end of March actual investments totalled some $32.5m with further plans for a further $10.1m. In the two years of the program significant progress has been made, stimulating both capital and professional manpower. In June 1983, one year before the program started, there was perhaps $5m available for venture capital in Australia. By June 1986, three years later, we estimate that about $247m will be available for venture capital investment in Australia of which approximately a little more than a half will be management and investment company funds. I am confident that the initial promising progress of that kind will continue. I indicate that the Government is committed to ensuring a continuation of this important initiative in the future. The program was announced for a five-year period and it will continue to be supported by the Government as announced when the original announcement was made in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry will no doubt recall the second reading debate of my private members' Bill on horticultural plant variety rights and that the Government would not support the Bill pending the report of Professor Lazenby. Now that Professor Lazenby has reported and, according to the Government's economic and rural policy statement put down on Tuesday, concluded that PVR is the most appropriate means of stimulating plant breeding in Australia and of improving access to overseas plant genetic material, which was also the conclusion of the Senate standing committee that considered the matter, will the Government now cease its delaying tactics and indicate support for my Bill with all the benefits which will follow to Australian horticulturalists?

—The answer to the last part of the question is no. The Government will not support Senator Hill's Bill. I am sure he will be astonished to learn that I do not actually remember his speech in the second reading debate. I certainly have not committed it to memory. On the broader question, this matter did receive some attention a while ago but I am afraid I cannot remember the precise details of what the Government proposes to do. I will find out from the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, and let the honourable senator know as soon as I can.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The visiting United States scientist, Hugh de Witt, from the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California, recently told audiences in Australia that there is no chance of a comprehensive test ban treaty during the time in office of President Reagan, which will last until January 1989. Given that Hugh de Witt has worked in this institution for nearly 30 years, an institution which--
—Order! The honourable senator is giving far too much information and I ask her to confine herself to the question, otherwise I shall have to rule the honourable senator out of order.

—Could the Government inform us what plans it has to continue working for a comprehensive test ban treaty in the face of such total intransigence by the Reagan Administration? Is the Government also prepared to admit that the Reagan Administration's opposition to a comprehensive test ban treaty has nothing to do with verification or testing current stockpiles, but is because it simply does not want one while the current nuclear test program is underway as part of the strategic defence initiative and will not be completed until the 1990s?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The United States Administration has consistently characterised a comprehensive test ban treaty as a long term objective that would be acceptable in the context of broad, deep, verifiable arms reductions, substantially improved verification capabilities, expanded confidence building measures and greater balance in conventional forces at a time when a nuclear deterrent is no longer as essential an element as it is currently for international security and stability. The Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, has acknowledged that under these circumstances and against those criteria Australia has a major difference with the United States in regard to the appropriate context in which a comprehensive test ban treaty can be concluded. However, Australia does share the United States' view that addressing and resolving the outstanding concerns about the verifiability of a comprehensive test ban treaty must be an essential element of the process of achieving this important objective. Australia's efforts, as Senator Vallentine would be aware, have been directed to getting concrete work under way on these verification issues. We certainly intend to persevere in relation to that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to that part of the question which dealt with the strategic defence initiative I simply say that the Government has no evidence which would substantiate the suggestion in Senator Vallentine's question that the strategic defence initiative is the key consideration in the position of the United States Administration on a comprehensive test ban treaty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of days ago Senator Hamer asked me a question, more in hope than in expectation, about the classification of security documents, to which the Attorney-General has now provided me with the following reply:

ANSWER.PARA: The recommendation that Cabinet documents should not carry a national security classification unless their contents justified it has been implemented. Mr Justice Hope, in his Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies Report made a number of recommendations relating to protective security matters. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventy-ninth report of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee on its scrutiny of the Health Insurance Regulations (Amendment).

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report describes our scrutiny of the Health Insurance Regulations (Amendment). By effluxion of time last Thursday, 10 April, amending regulations were deemed to have been disallowed when the Senate rose. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) who was responsible for the regulations, agreed to their disallowance. This is only the second time in the Committee's history that disallowance by effluxion of time has occurred and the first time it has occurred with a Minister's agreement. Because of this the Committee considered that it was incumbent upon it to report on the matter to the Senate as soon as it could.

The Health Insurance Regulations (Amendment) provided that the Secretary to the Department of Social Security was to be a prescribed person to whom otherwise confidential information in the trusteeship of the Health Insurance Commission could lawfully be given. The Commission administers Medicare and as the report indicates it is the recipient and the repository of vast amounts of computerised medical information about the health of millions of Australians.

The Health Insurance Act contains secrecy provisions designed to protect the privacy of this very sensitive material. It is a serious criminal offence for officers acquainted with information to reveal it outside the Commission. However the Minister for Health can suspend the operation of these secrecy provisions to some extent by prescribing persons to whom the information may be given. In the past the Minister has prescribed official medical and medico-legal investigators as appropriate to receive information. These regulations appear to be a major departure in that they prescribe, as a recipient of secret material, a person who has no official involvement or connection with the Health Insurance Commission or the investigation of medi-fraud. In addition, the prescription is totally open-ended in that in theory it makes lawful the release to Social Security of any information held by the Commission. Clearly this could include medical information.

The Commission has such sophisticated computer hardware and software that it would be theoretically possible to compile and release intimate and embarrassing medical profiles on identifiable individuals, families and groups in society. It would be unthinkable that the Minister for Health would allow this, or that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) would wish it. However, a dangerous situation is created when the legal possibility exists that medical information could be released without breaking the Act or the regulations. We would be astounded if the Australian Taxation Office were legally permitted to circulate full details of the tax returns of every Australian to other areas of the bureaucracy. Yet the potential invasion of privacy represented by the power to circulate medical details is much more serious since our state of physical and mental health is a source of our most intimate weaknesses.

Improper revelation of medical information exposes us to humiliation, ridicule, contempt, embarrassment, blackmail and great stress. We have a system of health insurance that for good and honourable reasons is designed to identify, and apply to, every citizen in the nation.

However, when married to modern computer technology and a tendency towards a centralisation of bureaucratic and governmental power, we have a recipe for a potential abuse of privacy that is breathtaking in its scope. I have no doubt that these implications have arisen inadvertently and incidentally from the Minister's genuine concern to assist with the detection of social security fraud.

Fraud on the public revenue, whether through tax evasion or false welfare claims, is a corrosive crime which affects everyone by unfairly depleting our pooled resources. The Committee supports the Minister for Health and the Minister for Social Security in their efforts to tackle fraud. However, the means used is an issue which cannot be ignored. The Health Insurance Regulations were prepared without appropriate regard being given to their legal implications for millions of ordinary Australians who use Medicare and who have a legitimate expectation that the privacy of their medical histories will be respected by a sensitive bureaucracy and powerful legal protections.
It appears that both the sensitivity and the legal protections appear to have succumbed to the imperatives of detecting fraud.

I accept that the Minister and his officials had no intention to release anything but identity details which Social Security could use to check the identities of claimants. The Committee considered that the release of such innocuous material would not be an undue trespass on rights. A balance must be struck between the detection of fraud and the protection of privacy. The drafting of these regulations did not reflect that balance, although the Minister intended, of course, to do so.

The regulations have been disallowed by effluxion of time and the Minister has undertaken to make new regulations which will spell out clearly the kinds of protections which the Committee considered these regulations lacked. He will amend the Health Insurance Act to ensure that these proposed new regulations can be as protective and effective as possible.

It would have been perhaps happier and more protective of privacy rights if that access had been limited to data concerning veterans who had exercised their rights to claim veterans' benefits. I say this in the context where the Minister was asked to re-examine the implications of earlier regulations which permitted the Health Insurance Commission to release all Health Insurance Commission data to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, not just that data relating to veterans.

The Committee asks the Minister to give serious consideration to this matter, as the earlier regulations are also open to much criticism. Finally, I wish to thank the Minister for Health and his officials for the considerable help and advice they gave the Committee. In the final analysis the Minister, in particular, acted decisively and agreed not to oppose the automatic disallowance of these regulations and their removal from the statute book. I commend him for his readiness in this instance to protect rights and allay the Committee's concerns. I look forward with some confidence to seeing his proposed amendments and new regulations in the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The seventy-ninth report of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee which Senator Cooney has tabled is a most significant report. It is possibly one of the most significant put down for some years. As Senator Cooney indicated, it concerns Health Insurance Regulations which, had they been allowed to stand, would actually have made it lawful for all of the private medical information held by the Health Insurance Commission to be given lock, stock and barrel to the Department of Social Security. The Commission's computer records have details of practically all the medical conditions suffered by virtually the entire population of Australia since the Commission was established. Annually, about 113 million medical services are recorded by the Commission in computer systems which can be programmed to break down that material into medical profiles of identifiable individuals, families or other groups.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not referring to the production of statistical material on health patterns and trends for the purpose of medical planning and research, which is quite acceptable. In those cases, the identity of the patients or the insured claimants is irrelevant. I am talking about the technical possibility that physical and mental health profiles on identifiable people in the community can be prepared and could have legally been given to the Department of Social Security for the purposes of that Department. I refer senators to paragraph 9 of the report, which states:

Quite obviously, it is not beyond the technical facilities available to the Health Insurance Commission to produce medical profiles on identifiable individuals, families, members of ethnic groups identifiable by name and place of residence, members of work forces making use of corporate medical officers, and other groups identified by cross-tabulated variables. Accumulated medical information describes an individual's or a community's physical and psychological weaknesses. Thus, it is, for an individual or a group of individuals a source of enormous social and political vulnerability.

The Committee's correspondence with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is described in chapter 4 of the report. I acknowledge that the Minister was helpful and courteous at all times. But senators who read the blow by blow account given in the report will see that it took some effort by the Committee to eventually sheet home to the Minister the full implications of this one line executive instrument. Those implications are described in chapter 5 of the report, and I urge senators to look at that chapter of the report. The implications can be discovered without the exercise of much imagination. Indeed, I am concerned at the lack of sensitivity which allowed regulations with such implications to be made.

The Regulations allowed the Commission to give any of its information to the Department of Social Security. Computer tapes could quite lawfully change hands or a direct terminal-to-terminal computer link-up could have been legal. It would have been perfectly lawful for the Health Insurance Commission to allow Social Security to have access to everything held on the Commission's computers. What is on these tapes? Well, when we pay for our medical treatment, our claim sets out the nature of the medical treatment we have received and the computer records that information. It is quite simple for the computer to deduce from its relevant tapes information about the medical conditions from which individuals suffer.

Indeed, I understand that the computers are deliberately so programmed to enable this to be done, not for any sinister reason, but in order to ensure that medical data can be analysed for planning and research. But, analysed in a particular way, these computer tapes can reveal the most private and intimate details of the physical and psychological illnesses of almost all of us over a long period of our lives. From tapes it could be discovered who suffered from genetic disorders, venereal or other sexual diseases, psychiatric conditions or contagious diseases. It could reveal who had undergone all sorts of sensitive medical conditions. The whole gamut of unpleasant and worrying illness, diseases and maladies, which is so private to us as individuals, could be made available to the Department of Social Security, not just in regard to social security claimants which would be horrifying enough, but in regard to every one of us who is enrolled in Medicare.

Medical information is often the most private information we possess about ourselves. It is difficult to envisage a more offensive bureaucratic intrusion into a person's life than a proposal to give the Health Insurance Commission legal power and authority to hand medical data over to the Department of Social Security. I quote from paragraph 36 of the report and remind honourable senators that the Department of Social Security:

Is the largest investigative arm of the federal bureaucracy. In terms of staff size it is one of the largest departments of state. It is daily an applicant, respondent amicus curiae or witness before the administrative appeals tribunal, the federal court and the family court. It is involved in litigation on a large range of social security matters, employees' compensation cases and family law questions where an unacknowledged use of otherwise privileged medical fact, opinion and innuendo could be of advantage to an unscrupulous advocate.

It is a Department whose views can be canvassed directly or indirectly by Cabinet or other departments on questions of individual's employment and promotion, and in relation to appointments to statutory, judicial or other high office.

Of course, the Committee does not for a moment suggest that there was any sinister intention behind these regulations, now thankfully disallowed. I am quite sure that neither the Minister for Health nor the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), nor the Health Insurance Commission, would countenance a release of medical information at this stage. But, as the Committee kept saying, the problem is that time passes and people forget their promises, and the desire to obtain information becomes overwhelming where some person in a department believes that someone is a cheat or a rogue and would seek to use these tapes to obtain this information. All the best intentions in the world would not be good enough to remove the clear legal powers to hand over private medical information.

It was this lack of real legal control to restrict the type of information to be released which caused the Regulations and Ordinances Committee to take such a firm and insistent stand on this issue. The legal possibility of abuse existed, and this had to be removed if people are to continue to have confidence in the Health Insurance Commission and the Department of Social Security. I refer honourable senators to paragraph 47 of the report, where the Committee quotes a very telling comment from the 1983 Law Reform Commission report on privacy, which states:

When a government department or agency receives information on the understanding that it is to be used for a particular purpose, it might not feel constrained to limit its dissemination to fulfilment of its purpose, if wider circulation seemed to meet the needs of the Commonwealth.
There is a grave and genuine fear behind the sentiment expressed there, a fear which has not been reduced by recent suggestions that all Australians might be required to have an identity card.

The Health Insurance Regulations have been disallowed, and the Minister has undertaken to amend the Health Insurance Act to provide that future regulations will be clearly protective of fundamental rights to medical privacy. I know that those amendments will be carefully examined by the Senate and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to ensure that there is no legal possibility of release of medical information by the Commission.

Finally, part of the report refers to a power which the Commission already has to release medical information to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It may be necessary for some medical information relating to veterans to be released to that Department for the purpose of processing claims. However, it is quite inappropriate that the legal mechanism which allows the Commission properly to release this information on veterans also, incidentally, allows the release of medical information on any one of us. Similar considerations and criticisms apply to these earlier regulations. It is the very strongly held wish of the Committee that those regulations should be amended or withdrawn as soon as possible to prevent the legal possibility of the release of medical information on people who are not claimants for veterans' rights.

Like Senator Cooney, I urge the Minister for Health and his officials to look carefully at the Committee's report. It will assist them-they do not have to worry about it-with ensuring that the Department of Social Security properly has access to Medicare identification data to help combat fraud, but without personal rights to medical privacy being undermined in a fundamental way.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 April, on motion by Senator Watson:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend this report to the Senate. This has been an exciting year in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The report of the Australian Science and Technology Council underlined CSIRO's importance as the primary research organisation in Australia. CSIRO employs about 7,000 people and has a budget of about $380m.

SPEECH.PARA: CSIRO carries out research across all fields of endeavour and is particularly valuable in our mining and rural industries because those industries carry out sufficient research of a practical kind themselves so that they can effectively capitalise on CSIRO's efforts in their own fields. However, in the manufacturing industries there are serious gaps between the research done by CSIRO and other research organisations, and the industries themselves. This reflects on CSIRO's communication with industry and even more so on the failure of Australian industry to invest in research and development on its own behalf. In fact, Australian industry is spending less and less on research and development while technology around it is changing at an ever-increasing pace.

In the 12 years from 1969 to 1981 industry funded research and development fell from 0.48 per cent of gross national product to 0.21 per cent of gross domestic product. Industry has more than halved its research and development effort. Comparatively, industries in similar countries to Australia spend around 0.93 per cent of gross domestic product on research and development; in fact, 10 times as much as has been spent on Australian industry. One reason for this is that Australian traditional manufacturing industries have tended to be protected from international competition. They have tended to limit their activities to domestic markets and have relied on foreign source capital goods and technology. The domination of our manufacturing industry by subsidiaries of foreign-owned corporations has been a major factor. Australia's current exposure to low commodity prices on world markets has exposed our vulnerability in trade balance on the manufacturing front. We can no longer afford to support manufacturing industries which have no will to export. The will to export is not enough. Successful export depends on quality and performance of our products. Technological innovation, based on a solid investment in research and development, is the only path Australia can afford to follow.

CSIRO's role in fundamental research is of vital importance in this process. Whether CSIRO can successfully transfer its results into innovative technology will depend heavily on industry's commitment also to the process of research and development. Alternatively, Australia will have to consider seriously the establishment of publicly-owned enterprises which will not neglect their investment in development, innovation and research into various products and practices.

CSIRO's move to establish contractual links with industry is a major step in the right direction. The setting up of multi-disciplinary groups is one of CSIRO's strategies for problem solving for industry and for speeding up the application of research into new products. I commend CSIRO on the successes it has achieved to date.

Communication has now become a major need in CSIRO's new thrust. Interfaces must be established between scientific disciplines, between technologists and scientists, between industry and technologists, between Australian technologists and the rest of the world. For these interfaces to function properly, three new classes of skills will be required within CSIRO. They all need to be communicators with good lateral thinking skills, who can see connections between the different areas which we have mentioned. We need people with management and industrial training who can take a target product and understand the nature of venture capital, and we need people who can sell the product to industry or set up new industries to exploit the product.
As well as people, a prime necessity for innovation is an innovative environment. Without research, without CSIRO, our industries will wither on the bough.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Australia and Pacific Economic

PROCTEXT.PARA: Co-operation
Debate resumed from 9 April, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no permanent friends or enemies in international relations, just permanent interests. The Pacific region is the fastest growing part of the world economy. Within 15 years, the western Pacific alone is likely to account for more than a quarter of total world production in gross national product terms, whereas 25 years ago its share was only one-twelfth of world production and five years ago it had already grown to one-sixth.

SPEECH.PARA: Trade in the western Pacific is growing even more strongly than production. Within 15 years the Pacific region could account for almost half of the world's trade. This massive growth in trade will require enormous expansion of finance and technology in the region. It is of vital importance to Australia that we establish strong trade links with the countries in our region.

The Pacific Economic Co-operation Conference in Seoul is the outcome of interest amongst the Pacific nations moving towards the establishment of a Pacific economic community, and it was with that long term aim in mind that Australia has been part of this Conference. The Conference confined itself to economic issues. It has established task forces or forums to study the major issues of an economic nature on which agreement must be reached before a Pacific economic community can become a reality. These forums are: Agriculture and renewable resources; minerals and energy; trade negotiations and trade policy; foreign investment and technology transfer; and capital flows between nations. All task forces underlined the need for co-operation between developed and developing nations in the region.

The Task Force on Agriculture and Renew- able Resources concentrated on the need for effective management of fisheries in the region. The United Nations Law of the Sea agreement of 1982 established the 200-mile exclusive economic zones. As a result, many countries in the region suddenly now have vast wealth in the sea off their shorelines. The Task Force on Agriculture and Renewable Resources also examined issues concerning livestock and feedgrains, and put forward a menu for co-operation in the region. This involved price stability and supply availability, aid and investment, technical co-operation and assistance and liberalisation of trade barriers. The Australian Democrats support all of these issues.

Throughout the Conference, concern was expressed about growing protectionism in world trade, and the stresses this imposed on goodwill between countries. In particular, the Conference called on all countries of the Pacific region to unite in a new round of multilateral trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade umbrella, and to seek reform of GATT so that commodity prices can be stabilised in world trade. This will be necessary before we can move into a Pacific economic community. If we are to maintain the Pacific as a zone of peace, we must increase co-operation between all states in the area.

As I stated earlier, there are no permanent friends or enemies in international relations, just permanent interests. The phenomenal rate of growth of trade in the Pacific region has provided a climate where states are prepared to co-operate towards gaining a stronger voice in international negotiations. It is in the interest of Australia that we move towards a regional economic community which will bring peace and stability to our region.
We will only achieve a strong independent Australia through cultivating a stable economic base in our region and co-operating with our neighbours.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1984-85 Norfolk Island annual report points out that the Norfolk Island police force consists of three full time officers seconded from the Australian Federal Police. The Ouvea had been chartered by Dr Xavier Maniguet and had left Noumea on 13 June, sailing from Norfolk Island on 18 June and arriving in New Zealand four days later. It sailed out of Auckland the day before the terrorist sinking of the Greenpeace vessel, Rainbow Warrior, late on the night of 10 July.

SPEECH.PARA: It was eventually established that scrapings from the Ouvea taken while it was at Norfolk Island disclosed traces of explosives. A map found on the yacht led police to an art gallery in New Zealand and established the role of a female agent in reconnaissance for the criminal activities which transpired. There were also links with equipment abandoned after the bombing in Auckland harbour and with matching physical evidence of the crew's New Zealand movements. Yet the four Frenchmen who were on the boat escaped justice. Three of them were released and allowed to sail from Norfolk Island on 16 July. The yacht was presumably scuttled and its crew spirited back to the safety of France. There, New Zealand police were unable to interview the three DGSE agents, even though they briefly surfaced at police headquarters when the Tricot whitewash report was released. Clearly, the French authorities are unwilling to let questioning proceed, let alone extradition on murder and arson charges.

In these reprehensible circumstances, I would expect our Government to make available as much information as possible about what happened on Norfolk Island. The Norfolk Island Newsletter contained this comment in its edition of 20 July last:

On 18 July, Detective Superintendent Allan Galbraith of the New Zealand police was quoted in the New Zealand Herald as saying:
It would be fair to say that we would have liked to have had a longer time to inspect the vessel.

If not, what were the obstacles? What were the lines of communication coming into and emanating from the office of the Administrator of Norfolk Island? What written reports were made to the Administrator or elsewhere? When will these be made public? I include in that Dr Maniguet's statement to the Australian authorities on the mainland. I trust that when Estimates Committee F reconvenes someone will be able to tell us the answers to some of these basic questions. Otherwise, I believe that the misgivings of the Australian public will grow. I commend the report, which in itself is excellent, to the Senate.
