DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN BASES AND INSTALLATIONS IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chipp I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) calls upon the Government to remove all foreign bases and installations from Australian soil unless it can be positively shown that:
(i) the bases and installations do not form any part of the nuclear strategy of the United States,
(ii) the management of the bases is genuinely under the joint and equal control of the Australian and US Governments, and
(iii) all information handled by the bases and installations is shared with the Australian Government;
(b) calls upon the Government:

(i) at least 6 months prior to the expiration of any lease, and in sufficient time to give notice of termination or variation, to establish a Joint Parliamentary Committee to investigate whether the conditions for the continuation of the bases have been met, and
(ii) in any case to complete inquiries into all bases and installations before December 1986; and
(c) calls upon the Government:
(i) to establish whether any Australian defence installations provide information or research for any nuclear weapons or strategies, and
(ii) where it is established that this is the case, to cease such operations forthwith.

This is a very important item at any time, but it is particularly important at the present moment with the Libyan crisis very much in our minds. On 14 April 1986 in the Senate I asked Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Resources and Energy, who represents the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley)-apparently he does not feel that this is an important enough issue to attend in the chamber-a question. I asked:
. . . what is the Government's attitude to Pine Gap's electronic spy satellites being used to spy on Libya as they were used to spy on Greece and Israel last year?
Senator Gareth Evans, with his usual rather flippant response to these serious questions, said:

As to that part of the question concerning Pine Gap, the honourable senator will recognise that I cannot answer his question without being drawn into his speculations about operations of the joint facilities. For very good reasons the Government is quite unwilling to do that, as Senator Sanders well knows.
He then went on to quote from a letter from the Minister for Defence dated 9 April last year which states:
The Government maintains its position that it could not confirm or deny anything that is reported to be associated with an operation at Pine Gap.

He said `could not confirm or deny'. Frankly, in the real world if anybody fails to deny something we can only assume that they confirm it. That is the only prudent course of action. Therefore, I believe that the Minister for Defence confirms the fact that Pine Gap was used to spy on Greece, and is often used to spy on other areas of the world. Senator Gareth Evans in his reply goes on to say:

So if we could manage without some of the more lurid and inaccurate speculations about Pine Gap's operations in the past, we might have a slightly more sensible approach to its operations at present and future within the limits of what it is possible for any government to say about the operations of that facility.

In other words, he skirted around the issue. He failed even to deny that the United States facility at Pine Gap was used in the Libyan operation. By implication he said that that was not so. He states that I am subject to lurid and inaccurate speculations about Pine Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yep.

—Here he is. I welcome the Minister to the chamber. I would like to point out that although he may claim that I have lurid speculations, that august publication, the Canberra Times, this very day said:

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the traffic interception performed by the Americans . . . arises from satellite-borne interrogation systems which can . . . relay the information to ground stations for processing.

We have been told by President Reagan of the United States that they have intelligence information which leads them to believe that in fact the Libyans planned an operation on the nightclub in Berlin. We have been told that the Americans relayed these plans to their operatives in East Berlin from where they were told that the operation had in fact taken place. How did they receive these signals? Probably, almost certainly, through Pine Gap. Pine Gap is the only such station that the United States operates. It operates it here in Australia for two reasons. It operates it, firstly, because of the low electronic interference, and secondly, because it is a secure, stable and isolated place which can be run with some security.

Pine Gap satellites were used last year to spy on Greece. Furthermore, there is other involvement of the United States bases in Australia in the Libyan situation. Although Senator Evans denied it, it is a certainty that North West Cape would have been alerted and in fact would have communicated certain information to United States forces in our region. During the 1973 Middle East war this was done without any consultation with the Australian Government. It should come as no surprise that this facility would be used in the present instance when, in fact, major units of the United States fleet went into action in the Mediterranean. It is only logical that units of the United States fleet in the Indian Ocean would be in contact with their control and command organisations. That contact would be through North West Cape. Was our Government consulted this time? I doubt it very much. West Germany hosts United States bases and military personnel. Those United States bases and military personnel would also have been put on alert. However, Chancellor Kohl was not consulted and only learned of the situation in Libya through news reports. I think the same situation was occurring here in Australia.

This matter raises three reasons for bringing on the motion. One reason is the use of the bases in support of aggressive military strategies, including nuclear war. The second reason is the threat posed to Australian security. The third reason is the lack of Australian sovereignty. We have no control over the use of the bases. Following the Libyan strike it is reported that a United States F111 landed at Rota in Spain. The Spanish people are very concerned about United States bases on their soil. Certainly, this would involve them, at least in the Libyan eyes, in the United States action if a United States plane landed on Spanish soil. There is no way the Spanish Government could forbid that F111 from landing at a United States base on Spanish soil. Therefore, Spain has been dragged into this thing much against its will.

I ask honourable senators to think of what happened in Britain when Margaret Thatcher acted on the basis of certain information. We learn only now that that action was only on the basis of the information which we have all been given that Ronald Reagan had some secret information-information that he is not going to show anybody-which showed that Libya was involved. Maggie said: `Go for it babe, use our bases'. Willy nilly she is pulled into the Libyan operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the people of Britain.

—Yes, as the honourable senator says, the people of Britain against their will have been locked into this situation. They have been put at risk. The Libyans hold them responsible. Their embassies are now under threat. Their homeland is under threat because they have been dragged into this war because of a very broad alliance with the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told that the Libyan attack was a limited strike. We were told that it was a surgical strike-although it was surgery with a broad axe. What happens in time of nuclear war? How would these bases in Australia be used if in fact the world became involved in a nuclear war? Let us refer to the United States strategies themselves. The following scenario is from the United States maritime strategy as described by Chief of Naval Operations, Admiral J. Watkins. This strategy commits the United States to escalate any local conflict with the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics to global war. Watkins stated:

Should war come, the Soviets would prefer to use their massive ground force advantage against Europe without having to concern themselves with a global conflict or with actions on their flanks. It is this preferred Soviet strategy the United States must counter. The key to doing so is to ensure that they will have to face the prospect of prolonged global conflict.

Therefore, as tensions in such a situation rose nuclear armed ships at Cockburn Sound would put to sea. Pine Gap would monitor Soviet military moves by radio message interceptions and by monitoring air defence radars. North West Cape would relay messages to all United States forces in the region, placing them on alert and directing naval operations, especially to bottle up the Soviet fleet in the Sea of Japan. North West Cape is of use not only in the Indian Ocean but also in the Pacific because of the orientation of the receiving antennas on the submarines which apparently are more powerful in a broadside direction than they are end-on, which means that a submarine travelling east-west would not be able to receive the signals from Jim Creek but in fact would have to rely on North West Cape in Australia. Therefore, even in the north Pacific North West Cape could have some value.

When the war broke out, according to Admiral Watkins, the United States would seize the initiative and naval forces would destroy Soviet forces in forward areas and fight their way towards Soviet home waters. As Admiral Watkins has said, the United States would seek to `defeat maritime strength in all its dimensions'. This would involve attacks against Soviet ships and would include the use of Tomahawk cruise missiles. It would attack these ships which in fact would be located by triangulation stations on Australian soil. These triangulation stations constantly monitor the high frequency transmissions of any ship in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. These stations are located at Toowoomba, Perth and Darwin. Also, there is such a station in New Zealand at Tangimoana. This data is collected and sent to Melbourne through what used to be called Watsonia but what is known now as Simpson, a communication station which communicates with United States satellites. These messages would then go to CINCPAC, the Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet. Therefore, the information on location is sent through Australia.

The attacks would continue on Soviet air bases in the north Pacific using Tomahawk cruise missiles and bombers. North West Cape would relay these attack orders. The Tomahawk cruise missiles and bombers would fly through radar gaps identified by Pine Gap. Pine Gap is a gigantic electronic vacuum cleaner. It soaks up signals from over Russia; in fact, from anywhere the antennas of the satellite are pointed. It would be a very important link to find out where the Russian radar was inoperative, thus allowing the bombers to get through. Attacks on Soviet nuclear missile submarines by the United States would be on orders relayed through North West Cape and the attack submarines would navigate using the Omega navigation station located near Sale in Victoria.

Escalation to nuclear war would be highly likely at this time. The Soviets would be very keen to use their submarine-launched missiles before they lost them. If they knew they were subject to imminent attack, they would launch their missiles. The Soviets would believe that any Tomahawk missile was a nuclear missile. They would have to believe this. Therefore, their attack strategy would be altered by this consideration to a full scale nuclear attack. Tomahawk missiles can carry both conventional and nuclear warheads, but one would have to assume that any Tomahawk missile coming in was nuclear armed.

The United States Navy would use its nuclear missiles before it lost them. This can be done at the discretion of ship or submarine commanders with no outside authority technically necessary, so there would be a huge escalation of the situation. Due to the vulnerability of United States and Russian command and control systems to attack, the pre-emptive nuclear attack is a favoured military response on both sides, irrespective of what the politicians have been saying. For the United States, the pre-emptive nuclear attack on first strike is, and has always been, the preferred action. The United States single integrated operational plan-SIOP-has always included the first strike option. Star Wars, Trident II, the MX and the Tomahawk of the United States and the B1 bombers, the SS24s and the SS25s of Russia are all being developed to make first strike more successful but it is already the preferred option.

During a nuclear war all bases used for a conventional attack would be used in a similar way for a nuclear attack. North West Cape would give the first strike orders. Pine Gap data would assist bomber and cruise strikes and monitor the Soviets. Toowoomba, Perth, Darwin and Simpson-Watsonia-would assist naval targeting and Omega would assist submarine navigation. But other bases would also be involved. This is where Nurrungar comes into play. Nurrungar's satellites would give warning of any Soviet nuclear missile attack or, more likely, response to a first strike. With the next generation of satellites, it would assist Star Wars to mop up the Soviet response and to identify surviving Soviet missile silos for destruction. The accuracy of the missiles would depend on data from satellites backed by Smithfield in South Australia, which include Geosat and Navstar.

In summary, the bases would assist in the build up to conventional and nuclear war, particularly with the aggressive United States maritime strategy. They would be directly involved in any United States first strike-the preferred nuclear option-and they would be destroyed by nuclear missiles at the outset of a Soviet first strike, being vulnerable parts of the United States command and control system. This would reduce United States capacity to retaliate.

The Government's policy is that the bases are justified as contributing to deterrence, early warning of Soviet missile attacks and verification of arms control agreements. I will deal with these one by one. Deterrence means not striking first but responding to Soviet nuclear attack. But deterrence is dead. The military policy of the United States, and perhaps Russia, is, and always has been, pre-emptive first strike. Also-I do not think anyone in this chamber can argue with this-United States conventional strategy is becoming more provocative. The United States is becoming more and more bellicose and more and more willing to use its massive strength. The American people demand it. Reagan gives them what they want. They want a Rambo response. All this lowers the nuclear threshold. I am not suggesting that the Soviets are not responsible in their own ways. They are engaged in sabre-rattling at this moment. Perhaps both sides have become more prone to take action since the Libyan crisis. The Australian involvement in the United States nuclear strategy threatens us and the entire world.

Early warning really only involves Nurrungar. Nurrungar would initiate the massive United States retaliation to a Soviet first strike because Nurrungar receives data from infra-red satellites over the Equator which are capable of detecting the initial launch phase of missiles in the Soviet Union. People might say that it is fair enough that we should have ways of detecting the launching of missiles, but it also could lead to accidental war through a misunderstanding of the data which comes in. It could lead to a war because of a mistaken case of a missile launching. This happens quite frequently in our defence systems when the data is not analysed correctly. Any such miscalculation could lead to a nuclear holocaust. Certainly the launching of United States missiles as the result of a Russian missile launch would lead to a nuclear holocaust. This, of course, would then lead to a nuclear winter and could affect the entire world.

We often hear that verification is a major function of the bases. Basically verification involves Nurrungar and Pine Gap monitoring missile tests. It has nothing at all to do with the verification of how many missiles or facilities Russia has, or America has in the case of the Russians. If we are going to worry about the verification of the missile capabilities of a country, Nurrungar and Pine Gap simply cannot do the job. Those bases run satellites which are in geo-stationary orbit over the Equator. The satellites are at such a height-thousands and thousands of kilometres above the earth-that the resolution is very poor. If one wants to be able to photograph, as one can from space, the details of a missile installations one does it from a polar orbiting satellite, which has a very low orbit height. A satellite in orbit around the poles can collect data and then discharge it a few orbits later right to the United States. It does not discharge its data to Pine Gap at all. Pine Gap is not necessary for this and anybody who says it is does not understand the whole operation of satellites. All of these bases are far more likely to cause nuclear war than disarmament. What we really need, if we wish for verification, is an international satellite monitoring agency. That could be run by the United Nations but need not be connected to any military system. It could have its own satellites and bases. None of the bases in Australia is necessary for this system.

The Australian Labor Party, at its National Conference in July, is going to be looking at policies concerning the bases. It will apparently support the bases for their contribution to early warning and verification. It will ignore the offensive role that all bases have and it will certainly ignore the fact that North West Cape, Simpson-Watsonia, Smithfield, Omega and others have no role whatsoever in verification. The Labor Party would do well to look strongly at its policy and decide exactly what the roles of the bases are and eliminate the bases if it finds, as I believe I have found, they are a danger to the Australian nation.

In respect of sovereignty, despite official statements, we have no meaningful control over bases and no influence over the strategies they support-none whatsoever. Almost certainly these bases were used during the Libyan crisis without our consent, but the best example of how the United States treats us as an ally was given recently in this chamber. On 11 February, Senator Gareth Evans said that the strategy of attacking nuclear missile submarines during conventional war was one option amongst many. The day before the United States Defence Secretary, Caspar Weinberger, said that it was the official United States strategy. The Government had not been told about this. The Government read in the newspaper about this major change in United States policy which affects Australia through the bases.

United States control over the bases and our lack of any meaningful control ourselves is made possible by two aspects of our democracy in Australia. The first aspect is that the Parliament cannot ratify or reject agreements with other nations such as the bases agreements. The Prime Minister, the Cabinet and the Governor-General have that power; the Parliament does not have it. The second aspect is that our freedom of information laws are pathetic, and the Government will not acknowledge information that is on the public record in the United States. The Soviet Union's military planners know more about what happens here than the Australian public.

The bases agreements have extremely important implications for our security. They should be subject to a full parliamentary inquiry with at least as much information revealed as is on the United States public record. The bases threaten national and global security and our democracy. The opportunities are coming up to do something about the situation. Nurrungar can be scrapped, if we take action now, at 12 months notice. Pine Gap can be removed at 12 months notice after 19 October this year. North West Cape can be removed at 180 days notice after 31 December 1987.

The Australian Democrats demand that these agreements and those covering the other bases be subject to a full inquiry before any decision is made. It is possible that the Pine Gap agreement has been or will soon be renewed without the knowledge of Parliament or even the Labor Party Caucus. We are contributing to the growing threat of global conventional and nuclear war. We are shutting our eyes to our involvement. It is time that we asserted the right to make our own decisions and to remove ourselves from the nuclear network in the interests of global peace.

The bases destabilise global peace. They are not adding one iota to the preservation of world peace. They make it more and more likely that a first strike will occur by one nation or another. The Government had admitted that the bases also make us in Australia nuclear targets, as does the presence of any nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships in our harbours. The bases also eliminate any chance of Australia being a neutral voice for common sense in the nuclear world. If we are committed to the United States strategy-as we are by the presence of their bases-we cannot possibly act as a neutral force for peace in the world. We have no credibility in that line.

It is time to declare our independence. After all, we are an independent nation. Why do we allow the United States to dictate what happens on our soil? Why did we allow the United States to drag us into conflagrations or wars which we have no desire to enter? It is time to stand on our own two feet on the world stage. We can influence world events in a positive manner if we have the guts to order the bases out of Australia and assert our independence. I commend the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an unfortunate sign of the times that we should be debating today a motion which covers not only much of the ground that we have gone over on numerous previous occasions in this chamber but also, and more significantly, ground which is based, in Senator Sanders's motion, on numerous misconceptions and some quite ill-informed precepts-and this despite the fact that this Government and, to a markedly lesser extent, the one before it, have gone to great lengths to correct these misconceptions about the joint facilities and the areas of ignorance, be they real or feigned.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sanders ranged fancy free over a wide variety of recent events during his speech, most notably, and naturally, the recent action by the United States of America against Libya. But I think that my main responsibility on this occasion is, on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), to respond quite specifically to the terms of the Australian Democrats motion now before us, rather than to try to track Senator Sanders through every extravagant ebb and flow of his stream of consciousness to which we were subjected on this occasion.

When I talk about misconceptions, let me begin, by way of illustration, by referring to the very first section of part (a) of the motion. The Australian Government does not allow permanent basing or the establishment of foreign military bases on Australian soil in time of peace. The simple reality is that there are no foreign bases on Australian territory. The joint facilities are not military bases-there are no combat personnel; no combat equipment; no military stores; and no military warehouses. Under this Government, therefore, the question of foreign military bases in Australia does not arise. On 12 June 1984, in a debate on this topic Senator Chipp said:
The Democrats do not doubt that the bases--
to use his word-
play an important role in arms control.

I am glad that he acknowledges that, and at least acknowledged it on that occasion. But let me explain the purposes of the joint facilities so that we can be quite clear as to where they fit into the international strategic structure. The joint facilities provide the United States with early warning facilities and with independent means of verifying Soviet compliance with arms control and disarmament arrangements. In so doing, they advance not only Australia's interests but the world's interests by contributing to the preservation of peace and the global power relationships upon which the survival of us all on this planet ultimately depends.

Something which, regrettably, Senator Sanders and his Democrat colleagues would appear to ignore is the important fact that the joint facilities provide a framework within which Australia can urge its allies to participate in moves towards reductions in the levels of nuclear armaments. The influence which Australia has in international affairs in the disarmament area-an influence which has been positive and significant, and acknowledged as such in many other countries-would be seriously eroded if the Democrats had their way. If they had their way, the positive and significant role which the joint facilities play in decreasing the likelihood of nuclear war would be dispensed with.

The motion proposes that the condition should be applied that the so-called bases and installations must not `form any part of the nuclear strategy of the United States'. Does this encompass United States strategies and plans to defend itself from the risk of a Soviet nuclear strike? If so, the contribution which the facilities in Australia make to the United States early warning system-and, thereby, to reducing or eliminating the prospect that the USSR might be encouraged to conduct a surprise bolt from the blue first strike on the United States-would no longer be possible.

The proposal would undermine a principal element of the basis on which the system of mutual deterrence operates-the ability of the United States of America to retaliate with its submarine forces in the event of a Soviet attack. Dissociating ourselves, as this motion would require us to, from `any part of the nuclear strategy of the United States' would require that the naval communications station at North West Cape-whose primary role is to provide reliable communications to United States submarines that may be operating in our part of the world-cease operations. This would detract from global security, not add to it. Of course the joint facilities do form a part of United States nuclear strategy. That is no secret, and the Government has explained that part. Let me quote from the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of 6 June 1984. I will quote it again:

Timely knowledge of developments that have military significance is very important and can be critical for the security of the US and its allies, including Australia. Effective deterrence and hence avoidance of conflict depend on this. Similarly, effective measures for military restraint and for the control and reduction of armaments depend upon reliable assessments of military developments. Arms limitation arrangements between the United States and the Soviet Union specifically provide for verification. The general purpose of the facilities that we operate at Nurrungar and Pine Gap with the Americans is to contribute to all of these objectives.
Later on he stated:

The purpose and functions of the joint defence facility at North West Cape have already been made public. It is a communications relay station for ships and submarines of the United States Navy and the Royal Australian Navy and serves as a key element in a complex system of communications supporting the global balance.

As indicated in the statement which the Minister for Defence tabled in Parliament on 3 November 1983, agreement was reached with the United States Government on new arrangements to ensure that the Australian Government would be able to make timely judgments about the significance for national interest of developments involving North West Cape.

As to section (a) (ii) and (a) (iii) of the motion before us, the functions of the joint facilities were, as I have already just said, fully explained by the Prime Minister in his statement on 6 June 1984. But let me repeat that in that statement the Prime Minister said that the joint facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar contribute to arms control verification and early warning as well as effective deterrence. Significantly for this part of Senator Sanders's motion, the Prime Minister also indicated that the Government has full and complete knowledge of what is done at these facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know exactly what goes on at Pine Gap?
—In response to Senator Chipp's interjection, I will repeat that sentence: The Government has full and complete knowledge of what is done at these facilities.
—Who in the Government? Who? Name him.

—Certainly the subject Ministers-Mr Beazley, Mr Hayden and the Prime Minister. I would not claim complete personal knowledge of everything that goes on there, but certainly I have been briefed in general terms and I hope to extend the range of that briefing in the near future. Certainly the Australian Government as a whole and through certain crucial key individuals has full and complete knowledge. We are quite confident of that and I repeat it. Let me emphasise again that these joint facilities are jointly managed and operated by the Australian and American governments. All functions and activities require, and have, the full knowledge and concurrence of the Australian Government. We monitor this and we are satisfied that the operations of the facilities in no way derogate from Australian sovereignty.

SPEECH.PARA: To expand further on this point let me deal with the facilities one by one in more detail. It has been acknowledged for many years that there are separate United States and Australian national rooms to preserve the privacy of national communications relayed through the North West Cape. Australian personnel are involved in all aspects of the operation of the North West Cape station apart from the United States national room and are solely responsible for the operations of the Australian national room.

The Minister for Defence announced in the House of Representatives on 3 November 1983 measures to improve the protection of Australian sovereign interests in the operation of this station. These arrangements establish special access to the US Department of Defence for consultations on strategic policy issues, and an enhanced role for the head of the Australian defence staff in Washington. They provide for improved procedures so that, in future, the Australian Government would be informed as early as possible about developments affecting, or potentially affecting, the operation or use of the North West Cape station. The Government is satisfied that these arrangements ensure that Australia's sovereignty in the operation of the joint defence facilities at North West Cape is adequately protected.

As to Pine Gap and Nurrungar, in his statement of 6 June 1984, to which I have already referred, the Prime Minister said that these joint facilities contribute to arms control, verification and early warning, as well as to effective deter- rence. This statement was agreed by the United States Government and was based on, I repeat, our full and complete knowledge of what is done at these facilities. Australian personnel have access to all the operational areas of the Pine Gap facility and are employed in the key areas. Australian personnel are fully integrated into the operation of Nurrungar. There is a standing requirement that there be at least one Australian service officer on each shift crew in the operations room. As the Prime Minister has said, all functions and activities require, and have, again, the full knowledge and concurrence of the Australian Government. We monitor them closely and are satisfied that the operations of the facilities in no way derogate from our sovereignty. Clearly, therefore, sections (ii) and (iii) of section (a) of Senator Sanders's motion are redundant and part (i) so vague, with respect, as to be meaningless.

In section (b) of the motion there is demonstrated again a certain ignorance of the nature of the joint facilities. The terms of the motion also demonstrate the ease with which some people-I say `some' because I recognise that some people are more misguided than without knowledge-make statements on the joint facilities, completely ignoring the facts. None of the facilities is subject to a lease, to use the terms of the motion, which requires renewal. Let me repeat it so that that is quite clear: Not one of the facilities is subject to a lease which requires renewal. Each is the subject of an appropriate treaty or agreement which includes a non-terminable period. When the non-terminable period expires, the agreement continues in force until either side serves due notice of termination on the other. Senator Chipp may be nodding his head--

TALK.START.PARA: —You may be damn right. That means that they can go on forever without them coming to the Parliament.

—I wish Senator Chipp had acknowledged that when someone on his behalf had been drafting his motion because the motion calls upon the Government at least six months prior to the expiration of any lease to do various things.
—That is legally possible.

—With the utmost respect, I have just described what the legal nature of the relationship is, at least on these particular facilities. The North West Cape agreement came into force in June 1963 for 25 years and will remain in force thereafter unless 180 days notice of termination is given. In the case of Pine Gap, the current agreement entered into force in December 1966 for a period of 10 years and remains in force thereafter unless one year's written notice of termination is given by either of the two parties. In the case of Nurrungar, the treaty entered into force in November 1969 for 10 years and will remain in force thereafter unless 365 days notice in writing of termination is given. All three of the agreements, therefore, will remain in force and there is no question of them requiring renegotiation or re-authorisation. Clearly, therefore, again with the utmost respect, section (b) (i) of the motion is a nonsense as it does not accord with the facts. With regard to section (b) (ii) of the motion, the Government constantly monitors the status and operations of the joint facilities to ensure that they are consistent with Australia's national interest and sovereignty. Again, this section in its present terminology is a nonsense, as the Prime Minister's statement of 6 June 1984 makes clear.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the suggestion that there are Australian defence facilities researching nuclear weapons or strategies-I take it the honourable senator means for Australia-I remind him that Australia has forsworn the nuclear weapons option through its membership of the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The Prime Minister repeated this commitment in his 1984 statement when he announced that the Government categorically rejected the option of acquiring nuclear weapons. Since then, of course, Australia has signed the South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty, which prohibits the acquisition, manufacture, stationing and testing of nuclear weapons within the zone. The maintenance of effective deterrence through early warning and verification-a situation greatly enhanced by the existence of the joint facilities-has as its purpose the avoidance of war between the super-powers.

The Government's position is not one of ignoring the realities of the state of the world and jumping on idealistic, but well-meaning bandwagons. Nor is it one of blind acceptance and the abrogation of Australia's influence, independence and sovereignty. Indeed, as a government, we have taken the tough but realistic and responsible decisions on these issues.

What we have in this motion is, however well intentioned it undoubtedly is, a moralistic and sanctimonious set of exhortations based on a series of misconceptions. Leaving out the loose wording and errors of fact-although this speech was written before Senator Sanders made his speech, it is applicable to the terms of the motion-and looking at the underlying intent of the motion, it is clear that the Democrats would have Australia either opt out of the alliance, or attempt to get full benefits without any appropriate contribution by Australia, while at the same time, and most importantly, leaving Australia isolated and ignorant of the real world. They would leave Australia without any voice in world affairs. They would leave Australia without any influence in areas of crucial importance, such as in nuclear disarmament, arms control and nuclear test verification. Without national technical means of verification which both super-powers support, the prospects for effective nuclear arms control would evaporate. The joint facilities contribute significantly to such verification.

Finally, I should point out that the benefits which accrue to Australia through its alliance relationship with the United States-in terms, for example, of our security, cost of our defence and exchange of information-are balanced by the very real benefits which accrue to the United States through the joint facilities by way of early warning and verification. The joint facilities give us a real influence in international affairs and provide us with detailed knowledge to support that influence. It would be a great error to dispense with these benefits at a time when we all agree that nuclear disarmament is of crucial and increasing importance. We are in a position to provide significant support to the process of nuclear disarmament while protecting fully Australia's sovereignty and independence. That should not be thrown away, either in an attempt to gain cheap political points, an appeal to emotions or in ignorance of the realities of the world, as harsh as they may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Opposition again to restate the Opposition's support for the joint facilities in Australia and also to dissociate the Opposition from the only lightly veiled anti-American sentiment of the Australian Democrats as put today in their motion and as stated in the assertions of their spokesman in this debate. If I might enlarge slightly on that, we heard Senator Sanders say today that it is the Democrats' view that the bases are being used in the build up to an aggressive nuclear war. The Democrats believe that the preferred option of the United States of America is a pre-emptive nuclear strike. These are the sentiments--
—That is true.

—I acknowledge the interjection of Senator Sanders who reasserted the position. These sentiments, of course, are intended to strike fear into the hearts of those who listen to debates such as this one. They are designed to strike fear particularly into the hearts of the young people of Australia. This is an old technique. I would suggest that it is a fairly revolting technique.
—Have you read the United States' documents outlining their policy?

—I have read a lot of documents on this. We sat here and listened quietly and patiently to the contribution made by Senator Sanders and I would appreciate the honourable senator doing the same. This is a fairly below the belt-I do not hesitate to use the word-and revolting method to frighten the electorate into giving support. It is a method from which we would seek totally to dissociate ourselves. We see this again in the wording of the motion that has been put before us by the Australian Democrats. The first line of the motion is misleading in that it refers to foreign bases in Australia. This is one of the occasions on which I can say that I agree that the Government spokesman is correct in that there are no foreign military bases on Australian soil. The Democrats' spokesman has deliberately drafted this motion in a misleading form which again has been designed to frighten people. The motion has been put in a form so as to provide the opt out. The motion calls upon the Government to remove such bases unless certain things can be shown. Of course, the first of those things is that the bases and installations do not form any part of the nuclear strategy of the United States. As Senator Sanders is well aware, the bases perform a role. They perform a role as a deterrent to nuclear attack. They perform a role in the verification of arms control agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting this afternoon to learn that Senator Sanders and his leader, Senator Chipp, disagree on that point of view. Senator Chipp is of the view that they do play a part in verifying arms control agreements. Apparently, on this occasion, Senator Sanders disagrees with him. The motion has been drawn in such terms that it simply cannot be complied with. This again shows the mischief that the Australian Democrats are about in this debate.
Let me make it quite clear-and the Opposition will repeat this again and again-that we support the ANZUS alliance. We know that the Australian Democrats do not support ANZUS.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sham.

—Senator Sanders argues that it is a sham. I do not know why the Democrats do not come clean. Perhaps Senator Sanders will and say why they do not support the alliance and say that they do not want Australia to be aligned.
—Exactly. Stand up as an independent nation.

—Apparently the Australian Democrats' position has now been further clarified. They are advocating non-alignment for Australia in defence matters. This is the first time that I have heard it put in such terms. I hope that that has the agreement of all of Senator Sanders's colleagues as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us contrast our position even more clearly. We support the alliance and we support the deterrent. The deterrent has worked for 40 years and ought to be given more credit than Senator Sanders is prepared to give it. We accept that Australia has to be prepared to pay a price for that alliance. Part of the price is the joint facilities that we have on our soil. The other part of the price-and I submit to the Senate that this is a small price-is being prepared to accept allied naval shipping in Perth and elsewhere and matters of that nature. We accept that that is a reasonable price to pay. It is a reasonable contribution by Australia to an alliance which we believe is in the best interests of this country.

That remains the clear position of the Opposition. The Opposition's position contrasts somewhat with that of the Government because the Government, of course, professes support for the alliance. It professes that Australia should be a full and contributing party to ANZUS. However, the Government does not always give its full support when the alliance is put to the test in a practical way. We have had a number of experiences over recent years to support that that is the case. I remind the Senate of the incident not so very long ago that involved the British ship Invincible. When that ship was damaged and sought entry to Sydney Harbour for repairs this Australian Government was unable to allow it to do so because it could not guarantee its safety while it was in port and it could not guarantee that the unions would allow it to leave the port. That was an absolutely embarrassing position for this nation. Our role within the alliance, when put to the test on that occasion, was shown to be of little value to our allies.

We all remember the MX missile debacle when the Australian Government was asked to do very little to contribute to tests conducted by its ally, the United States. What was Australia asked to do? It was asked to provide little more than refuelling facilities for United States aircraft which were in this part of the world to monitor the tests. Of course, as honourable senators are well aware, when it came to the crunch the left wing of the Australian Labor Party demanded of its Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that Australia should not facilitate in that way. The Prime Minister, in an embarrassing way, had to renege on his undertaking. He had to go to Washington and renege and thereby embarrass not only himself but also this nation in the presence of one of its significant allies. We know that this Government is reducing the number of port visits of United States naval vessels to Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear!' says a Labor Party member of this chamber. This action is being taken obviously as a result of further pressure from the Government's left wing. The most recent example of its attitude in these matters is its attitude to the strategic defence initiative. Whereas many of the allies are prepared to play a part in the research phase of SDI, the Australian Government is not. The position of the Opposition is that SDI is a defence mechanism as opposed to an attack mechanism. That is something that I would have thought Senator Sanders, given his preoccupation with the belief that the United States strategy is one of pre-emptive first strike, would be pleased to recognise-a project that is designed specifically to provide a defence rather than an attack mechanism. What an ideal it is that leading forces throughout the--
—You are going off the rails.

—We have parted company. What an ideal it is that nations in the Western alliance are prepared to play a part in looking for a defence mechanism against an international nuclear attack rather than simply relying on the somewhat immoral and aged principles of mutually assured destruction. The Opposition regrets that the Australian Government is not prepared to support its ally in this way. The Japanese Government is prepared to do so, as is West Germany. Our position is that we regret that the Government, although it states its full support for the alliance, is often found to be somewhat short of its claims when put to the test.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings into vogue what the Labor Party intends to do in relation to these matters at its July conference in which it will reassess its policies on nuclear deterrence and the role that Australia is to play within the alliance. We are pleased that we have been made aware of the Labor Party's intentions in this matter by an article which appeared in the National Times of 28 March to 3 April. That article has not been denied in any way and therefore, no doubt, is somewhat factual. In that article, Geoff--

TALK.START.PARA: —How could that be?

—I will put a few of the statements to the honourable senator. I will put the policy that has been determined by his Party's foreign affairs and defence committee. As the honourable senator knows, under his Party's system, by the time such an issue has been dealt with by all the factions-this issue has already been dealt with by most of them-it will be adopted by the Party at its conference and become the Party's new policy. I thought that, as part of this debate on the alliance and the place that the honourable senator's Party intends Australia to take within that alliance for the future, this policy ought to be discussed briefly. We are advised by Geoff Kitney in his article:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is preparing to take a much tougher position with the Americans on the key issues of the US bases and the ANZUS alliance.
The article expands on that statement:

. . . it proposes that the Labor Party redefine its commitment to the ANZUS alliance to give special emphasis to Australia's relationship with NZ and to exclude any specific commitment to the ANZUS Treaty.
We are advised-it has not been denied-that this is part of the draft policy that will be put to the ALP conference in July, a policy that will exclude any specific commitment to the ANZUS Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—That policy is supported, we find with interest, by the Australian Democrats today. I am sure that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, will be heartened to know that he has the support of the Australian Democrats in this planned policy change.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a belief that Australia should be strongly supportive of the ANZUS alliance. If New Zealand is not prepared to play a reasonable role within that alliance by refusing to allow an ally's naval shipping simply to enter its ports, we can understand the American sentiment, which is to regard the ANZUS Treaty as inoperative as far as it applies to New Zealand. What has been the Australian Government's attitude to this issue? We are aware that the Prime Minister has said that ANZUS as a tripartite treaty is no longer in existence. What does this Government propose to do if it says that ANZUS is no longer in existence? It proposes in its draft policy to establish for itself a new neutral role in relation to New Zealand and the United States. We wish to be distinguished from that policy. We say that what this Government should be doing if New Zealand is not prepared to be part of the alliance and to play a full role is-we do not hesitate to say this-to put all its energy into persuading New Zealand to review and alter its policies and again come back within the family of ANZUS. But if New Zealand is not prepared to do that, it is the responsibility of the Australian Government to go out and renegotiate its alliance with the United States, which is still prepared to be a party to that alliance. Apparently, that is not the approach that the Labor Government is intending to take after the July conference.

It is interesting, because this policy paper has become relevant to this debate, that the article goes on to refer to this new self-reliance defence policy of the Labor Party about which we are starting to hear a lot. The expansion of this Government's isolationist policy might be another way of putting it-a policy, as we have seen, to pull our small commitment out of the Sinai, where we were playing a part at the request of both Israel and Egypt in keeping the only treaty currently existing within the Middle East. We see that policy in the pull back from Butterworth, resulting in an arrangement that will simply be unworkable for the future. We have seen it in the selling off of the Fleet Air Arm and in many other examples.

What we are seeing is a new neutral role by the Government in relation to ANZUS and the United States. Apparently there is a refusal in this policy to give a full commitment to the alliance that we have had with the United States and an emphasis on this new isolationist self-defence policy. What does this leave us with? It leaves us with a typical example. I refer to the Kangaroo '86 defence exercise for this year, a defence exercise with which my colleague Senator MacGibbon is very familiar. It has been in operation since 1974.

On this occasion, for the first time, Australia will have to exercise alone. The last exercise was cancelled because of the mess in which we found ourselves with regard to the ANZUS alliance. Australia is now going one step further in its isolationist, self-reliance policy and we will exercise alone. It thinks that as a small power-a realistically small power-in some way it can play this sole role within the defence aspects of the world scene. On our side of politics, that is a totally naive approach. It is a dangerous approach. It is not putting Australia's security in the light in which it should be put. It is a policy by which we believe Australia is not well served and it is a policy which we oppose.

In conclusion, I reiterate our disappointment at hearing the Democrats again attacking the United States, our allied partner. We actually believe that good faith is the bulwark of a workable alliance. But that is not the view of the Australian Democrats. We regret their attitude as they have put it again today and we reaffirm our position as strong supporters of the Western alliance, both morally and because it is in our self-interest. We assert the importance of deterrence and our willingness to play our part in that alliance by allowing a limited number of joint facilities on our shores.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April 1985, on motion by Senator Mason:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Mason's Bill, the Defence Amendment Bill 1985, that is now before us, proposes that the elected representatives of the Australian people in both Houses of Federal Parliament should be properly involved in decisions to send Australia's military personnel into situations of armed conflict beyond our own territory. While the Government opposes the Bill for reasons which I will spell out in a moment, I make it clear at the outset that we do sympathise with its underlying philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason, in his second reading speech on 18 April 1985, which is nearly a year ago, spoke of our involvement in the tragic and wasteful episode of Vietnam. In the context of this Bill we should remember that the Australian Labor Party at the time spoke out vehemently against the decision taken without proper consultation to send Australian troops to Vietnam. It can be said, of course, that we did so at some political cost. Arthur Calwell said that involvement in an Asian war was the worst mistake Australia had ever made in foreign affairs, and that conscription for service in Vietnam was `immoral, unjust, and a violation of human rights'. We were embroiled in Vietnam as part of a strategy for defence that aimed to stop the supposed downward thrust of communism-a theory which I have often described as a kind of gravity theory of international politics; the notion that what is up must come down, but which, as Senator Mason pointed out, is not only misguided and historically naive, but also substantially aided the firm establishment of communist regimes throughout Indo-China.

This Government has a much more practical and inherently logical defence strategy which concentrates our scarce resources in the most cost effective way for the direct defence of Australia and its territories. Our strategy is one of defence self-reliance. It aims to defend the fundamental democratic and humane values of our society, and does not seek to involve us in other people's wars on other people's territory. In implementing this strategy we must, of course, allow for the proper defence of our continent and territories and this may involve in certain circumstances defensive action outside Australia's territorial limits. In our current strategic circumstances there is no identifiable military threat to this country. It is lower level challenges to our sovereignty such as harassment, sabotage and small scale raids that are regarded as most credible. Strategic guidance concludes that such threats would develop, at least initially, in the maritime environment and in the northern approaches to Australia.

It is unlikely, therefore, that in the event of hostilities the military defence of Australia and its territories would be limited to Australian forces serving within Australian territory or territorial waters. Our ships and aircraft could be expected to operate outside Australian sea and air space. The Bill before us would allow for this only after either resolutions by each House of the Parliament, or a proclamation by the Governor-General. It is difficult, however even after hostilities have begun, to decide, in advance, the limits of required deployments. In practical terms that responsibility lies with the Government's management of the defence situation.

To require the proclamation of a state of emergency and the recall of Parliament to enable effective countering of low level threats is not, I suggest, a practical basis for defence planning. Further, situations may develop where there is a need to determine measures to be taken without the publicity associated with debate in the Parliament; situations where public knowledge could limit our strategic options and indeed put our forces at risk. Internationally, declaration of a state of emergency could be interpreted at least as over-reaction, alarmist or aggression; the latter more likely by a potential aggressor who could react by escalating his military preparedness and thus bring about the situation where, in fact, a state of emergency exists.

There are other practical problems. The provisions of the Bill would preclude defensive activity such as protection of Australian shipping. They could also severely constrain the operational effectiveness of the Defence Force in such routine circumstances as hot pursuit in the Australian fishing zone beyond territorial limits. They could also complicate arrangements for the employment of Defence Force personnel in other countries under the defence co-operation program and in other instances where the Australian defence forces may be involved in providing humanitarian or disaster relief assistance. These and other circumstances are not covered by the exceptions in the Bill. While the list could no doubt be expanded, it would be difficult to arrive at a list in the legislation which is both comprehensive and clear in its coverage of routine peacetime activities. There are also somewhat more technical difficulties-for example, the operation of the amendment when Parliament has been dissolved.

I recognise the motivation that our shameful involvement in the Vietnam conflict has provided to Senator Mason in his proposing of this Bill. The Labor Party, as I have said, spoke out vociferously against this overseas commitment of our armed forces at the time, and nothing in our history or traditions suggests that Labor would ask our servicemen to participate in operations outside our territory unless this involved the direct and immediate defence of fundamental democratic and humanitarian values of Australian society, and with our actions being subject to full public accountability through the people's elected representatives in parliament. The Government commends Senator Mason on the motives which form the basis of this Bill but the practical difficulties inherent in its application are such that it cannot be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of the Opposition. We are totally opposed to the Defence Amendment Bill 1985. I listened with interest to what the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, had to say. I was astonished at the fundamental inconsistency of his case. He was arguing for self-reliance, and at the same time preaching the case for fortress Australia and continental defence. The inconsistencies there are irreconcilable. But that is properly a matter for debate on another day, as is his treatment of the Vietnam war. He is entitled to his views on that matter, and so is his Party. But he should reflect on the fact that if the United States and its allies had not entered the Vietnam war, we would have certainly seen the loss of Thailand, and probably Malaysia as well. The great achievement of the Association of South East Asian Nations, the economic growth of those nations which will lead ultimately to some sort of defence union between them, and a great force for stability in the area which is absolutely vital for Australia's defence, has been achieved as a consequence of the effort we made in Vietnam. The Vietnam war gave ASEAN the breathing space it needed to organise its affairs. But as with the concept of fortress Australia, that is properly a matter for debate at another time.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to Senator Mason's Bill. This Bill in essence seeks parliamentary approval before Australia's forces are committed overseas in any way. It requires the approval of both Houses. In the event of an emergency it requires the Governor-General to call together the Houses of the Parliament at least within 48 hours to ratify that committal. In so doing, it attempts to do two things: It attempts to graft onto the Westminster practice under which Australia is governed, in a clumsy, ill-thought out way, the procedures of the American presidential system. They are two different ways of governing and one cannot pick and choose the good bits out of one system and run them with the other. I find it very strange that someone like Senator Sanders, who is an American and who spent most of his life in the United States, should come in here and vilify the American nation at every opportunity, yet everything he does in this Senate chamber seeks to introduce American practices into our system of government. He tries to recreate the very thing that he has fled to the other side of the earth to avoid. He seeks to build the new Jerusalem here and the new Jerusalem is going to be a new Washington DC.

The second thing that Senator Mason's Bill tries to do is put into the hands of minority groups in the Senate the control of the defence and foreign affairs of Australia. Could anyone imagine Senator Chipp, or Mr Chipp as he was then, when he was Minister for the Navy of this country-a position which he discharged with great distinction, dedication, diligence and responsibility-seeking approval for the actions of the government of the day from the ratbag element in the Senate? Does anyone really believe that Senator Chipp would support a proposition like that? To state it in those terms is to expose the basic and fundamental fallacy of this argument.

One of the most serious and difficult decisions that any government ever faces is the committing of Australian forces overseas. Whether war has been declared or not, those troops are being committed in a wartime situation. One is taking the ultimate decision and that decision self-evidently has to be made after the most careful examination of the arguments for and against. That is a decision that can be made only in the full knowledge of all the circumstances-knowing the diplomatic circumstances that are involved, the strategic involvement and all the military and economic factors. These must be weighed up in the light of a careful assessment of all the options that are open to the government of the day. That simply cannot be done in open debate in any chamber of this Parliament. Senator Mason's legislation would, in effect, arrogate to the Senate the right to countermand a decision which has been made by the Executive Government, having full access to all this information. As I said in relation to Senator Sanders and Senator Chipp when he was Minister for the Navy, we are giving the ultimate decision on the security of Australia to minority groups or parties which might have the balance of power in the Senate at the time. These are the points that I will seek to develop in my speech.

There is another point I wish to raise. Senator Mason sees this Bill very much as a means of ensuring what he wishes to do; that is, keep Australian defence forces within Australia and not permit them abroad. But he fails to realise that that is very much a two-edged sword because it could work the other way round. It is not straining the bounds of credulity to imagine a very emotional incident occurring. For example, suppose that a Qantas airliner was blown up and 400-odd Australian nationals killed in some country and the Parliament, under the umbrella of Senator Mason's legislation, resolved to commit Australian forces overseas. It might be that more reasoned counsel available to the Executive government of the day would counsel very much against that and would take alternative courses of action. If honourable senators think that illustration is far fetched, perhaps they should cast their minds back 10 years to the situation that existed at the time of the East Timor troubles. Had the Left of the Australian Labor Party been numerically stronger-and that is something that could have happened then or could happen in the future-and had this legislation of Senator Mason been on the statute book, Australian forces would have been committed to Timor. That would have had consequences that we simply could not foretell.

This legislation is based on a false assumption. The assumption made by Senator Mason is that the Parliament has no control of the Australian defence forces and that is blatantly untrue. The Parliament does control the Australian defence forces and all it needs is the courage to exercise its rights, if it has to. The Australian Government consists of three arms-the Parliament, the Executive and the judiciary. The Parliament is the legislature and it is in the business of making the laws of the country. The Executive is the Ministry which is answerable to the Parliament, but it is the Ministry which governs the country and makes the decisions. One of those decisions is that which relates to national security and which is very germane to Senator Mason's Bill. The final arm is the judiciary which is there to enforce the laws impartially. I come back to this business of parliamentary control. The Parliament controls the Australian defence forces because all defence forces need money. If one is fighting a war one needs a great deal of money and continuing access to money. If the Parliament does not approve the actions of the executive government, the remedy is very simple-the Parliament simply refuses to grant money to those armies.

The Bill itself is a product of some very muddled thinking in relation to the United States system. There is no parallel between the Westminster system and the United States presidential system and regrettably the Democrats fail to understand that. Most of the business that the Democrats bring up is characterised by its sheer superficiality and opportunism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you have to be offensive in a sensible debate? You were making a good speech but you are now being personal and offensive.
—This point is very real to my argument, Senator Chipp, because if the Democrats had thought this through they would not have--
—That is still no reason to be offensive and personal.

—If I have been personal, I apologise. I had no personal intent at all. However, I guess this has got under Senator Chipp's skin a bit because I have come to the superficiality of the argument. In the United States Constitution, Article 1, section 8 states very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: The Congress shall have power to declare war . . . to raise and support armies . . . to make rules for the government and regulation of the land and naval forces.

In the light of the Vietnam war that power was altered in November 1973. The Congress passed the War Powers Resolution, which set out to fulfil the intent of the framers of the Constitution of the United States and to ensure that the collective judgment of both the Congress and the President will apply to the introduction of the US armed forces into hostilities or into situations where imminent involvement in hostilities is clearly indicated by the circumstances and to the continued use of such force in such hostilities or in such situations. In effect, it required the President to consult with Congress before military forces were committed and if they were committed, he had 60 days to meet Congress and another 30 days in which to withdraw the troops if Congress did not approve. Interestingly enough, despite this resolution, it did not solve the legal problems on the commitment of forces by the United States Government, and it did nothing at all to resolve the intense moral and psychological issues that are always associated with the commitment of armed forces.

We do not have that system in Australia. In Australia the Governor-General is the Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces and section 68 of the Constitution vests that authority in him. The Governor-General is advised by the Executive government which, in turn, is responsible to the Parliament of the nation. It is simply not possible for the Democrats to move by simple parliamentary resolution or take unto the Parliament powers which are properly vested in the Constitution.

The basic principle on which armed forces are committed in Australia is that the citizens control the forces. I submit that it is a gross perversion of that argument to suggest that the Parliament should directly control them. The Parliament should control them by controlling the Executive which is in a position to make a much more informed decision as to the deployment of those forces. If we do not have that sort of commitment we end up with muddled command. In a situation where we have to commit forces, if we have blurred lines of command we will have disasters and failures on our hands. The basic doctrine is that one cannot separate administration from command and what Senator Mason tries to do here is to separate the administration of the defence forces from their actual command. As every commander knows that is a formula for disaster. The way the Department of Defence is set up at present, the administration of the defence forces is effectively hived off from those who control the defence forces. The Secretary of the Department of Defence ranks parallel with, and in practice seems to take precedence over, the Chief of the Defence Force. The heavy civilian component in the Department of Defence seems to outweigh the decision-making capability of the uniformed services. That is a matter which we will have to address in the future; we need to reform the administration of the Department of Defence. It is absolutely untenable to suggest that we go one step further and take Senator Mason's proposition that we take the administration of the defence forces out of the hands of the executive government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a military dictatorship you are describing.

—I would like to pick up that point. Had Senator Mason any powers of recall he would have remembered that a few moments ago I said that it was a fundamental tenet of Australian democracy that there is civilian control of the Army. To take his line, by affecting the administration of the Australian defence forces and placing that administration on an uncertain path we would be very much moving down a path of military dictatorship.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to reflect on what has happened in the last 40 years. No one wants war and nothing I am going to say here in any way condones war, but we have to recognise the fact that to resort to war is the ultimate method, or resort, that a national government has to protect the security of its nationals and to protect its essential interests when all else fails. World War II was a total war. In other words, there were no holds barred. It was a war between the Allies and the Axis powers. It was a war that was fought with the clear intention of fighting to a stage of unconditional surrender by the loser. The horrors of World War II, in which over 50 million were killed, made such an impact on the consciousness of the world that people tend to think of all wars in terms of total war and unconditional surrender.

Since the advent of the nuclear age in 1945, people have equated war with nuclear war and they realise that a nuclear war is both unthinkable and unwinnable. World War I and World War II were total wars fought with the aim of unconditional surrender of one party or the other. They in a sense were very much aberrations. Of the millions of wars that have been fought since mankind began, most of the wars have been fought for limited objectives. They usually have been fought over a border area that is in dispute, over an island off the shore, or some small issue, and they are fought to redress a wrong that has happened. Involving all of mankind in a war and fighting to an unconditional surrender is not part of the great majority of wars. It may well be that this is the sort of situation that Australia will face; it may be that to prevent a war breaking out in the future Australia would need the ability to deploy forces within the region.

The other point I would like to make about control of the Australian defence forces and the ability of the Parliament to commit them turns very much on public support. We simply cannot have soldiers overseas fighting-or defence forces of any nature fighting-without public support in the nation. The public, if it does not approve of a war, can very effectively exercise disapproval by voting the Government out of office.

Let us look at the effect of this legislation. The prime duty of any national government is to protect its people and the essential national interests. That turns, in the case of Australia, on having a deterrent posture in defence. One of the fundamentals of having a credible deterrence is to have effective mobilisation. We need to be able to demonstrate that we have effective mobilisation. It is a fact that Israel has demonstrated repeatedly that while it has a small standing army it can very rapidly, within a matter of hours, mobilise a very large, fully-trained reserve.

I relate this to Australia because in the past we have always had allies who have bought time for us, time that extended into years, while we mobilised and got our forces ready. But we no longer have this. Without the support of those allies that we have had in the past we might have to deploy some of the permanent Australian defence forces. For example, it might be a requirement that we use the Operational Deployment Force overseas to buy some time while we mobilise our own forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Because of the arrangement with the Whips this morning it was understood that I would be given 10 minutes to speak. I have already canvassed that it was nobody's fault that I could not have that time. I have a speech here of about four minutes. I have canvassed the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and they have agreed that, if the Senate so chooses to give me leave, I can have this speech incorporated. I seek leave to have this very short speech incorporated in Hansard.
—I just make the point that this will not preclude Senator MacGibbon from being in continuation when the debate is resumed.
—That is understood.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I warmly support Senator Mason's Defence Amendment Bill 1985. This Bill would place the responsibility for a decision to send Australian troops abroad squarely on the two Houses of Parliament. The Bill provides for exceptions covering the movement of personnel in the normal course of their activities and the possible need to take quick action in an emergency. In the case of such an emergency being declared, parliamentary approval would need to be sought within 48 hours.

Provisions for parliamentary approval exist in Canada, constitutional prohibitions exist in Germany, Japan, and even the United States of America. This Bill would provide a check on the executive arm of government. It would ensure that Australia would not be drawn into a Vietnam, an Afghanistan, or a possible United States defence of its bases in the Philippines. What is there now to prevent the Executive-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Cabinet-committing Australia to a disastrous course of action without the Parliament and Australian people knowing what the arguments for and against were, and what the potential hazards might be? Nor would the approval of the House of Representatives be sufficient, but merely a reflection of the Executive's opinion. The very least such an important step would require is a full and free debate in both Houses of Parliament. The Senate could raise questions which the Australian people would want answered before they would consent to becoming involved in an act of war, which involves every person and affects the lives of everyone, perhaps for many years after the formal involvement has ended.

This Bill would restrain the application of ANZUS in Australia's favour in the way United States law restrains any of their responses. It would mean that Australia would not automatically jump to America's assistance when they decide to invoke it. They have the restraint of constitutional processes even if they do no more than consult, responses would need Congressional approval. Since it is far more likely that the United States would invoke ANZUS to get Australian military support, surely, we as a nation need to have appropriate processes to assess any Australian military involvement, in particular to assess whether this involvement would be in Australia's national interest.

In February-March this year while the situation in the Philippines was still unclear, on two separate occasions, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) floated the awesome possibility of the United States under ANZUS calling for Australian troops to defend US bases in the Philippines. The instability of the region could quite easily drag us into a bloody war just as Mr Hayden speculated. Nor can we say that the possibility of Australian troops being sent to defend United States bases in the future has been ruled out by the Aquino victory. What will happen if her Government decides to get rid of them? It is precisely in such a way that yesterday's friends become today's enemies, for reasons apparently beyond our control. But they are within our control. This Bill, if passed, would put them within our control.
