DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I am pleased to now move the introduction of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. It represents yet another milestone in this Government's record of improving the status of women and is evidence of our firm commitment to enhance women's job opportunities.

This Bill will require certain employers to have an affirmative action program for women and to report their progress to the Government, through the Director of Affirmative Action. The objects of an affirmative action program will be to eliminate discrimination against women and to promote equal employment opportunity for women.

This legislation is necessary to ensure that all large employers take seriously their obligations to their women employees. The changing role of women in our society is reflected, to a large extent, in the changing patterns in the workforce. The Government is determined that women should be able to enter and compete in the labour market on an equal footing with men and that outdated prejudices or conventions should not prevent them from fully participating. Neither individual employers nor the nation can afford to waste the valuable contributions which women can, and do, make to our economy.
Affirmative action programs are designed to ensure that any existing discrimination is identified and removed, and that equal opportunity is a reality in the large workplaces in this country.

The policy which is reflected in this legislation has been developed in full consultation with all groups affected by it, in particular the trade union movement, employers and women's organisations. We developed the policy in a gradual and realistic way to ensure that it was fully understood and to give those affected the opportunity to influence its final shape. I am confident that the result, which I present to you today, Madam Speaker, represents a workable and practical way of assisting women to pursue work opportunities to the best of their abilities.

Soon after coming to Government, we passed the Sex Discrimination Act-an important reform which provides for the resolution of individual and group complaints of unlawful discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy. Affirmative action programs are designed to complement anti-discrimination legislation by eliminating any rules or practices which may unfairly disadvantage women in the workplace and by promoting equal opportunity.

In June 1984, the Prime Minister tabled the Policy Discussion Paper Affirmative Action for Women. To test the Government's proposals as outlined in that Paper, we established the Affirmative Action Pilot Program and 28 large private sector companies and 3 higher education institutions accepted the Prime Minister's invitation to participate. The Pilot Program ran for 12 months, concluding in July last year, and the contribution of those employers has been invaluable in the development of the legislation I am introducing today. I would like to express my appreciation of their efforts, and of their willingness to take part in such an innovative scheme.

The Government also established a representative Working Party on Affirmative Action Legislation. Its members came from government, business, trade unions, higher education, women's organisations and the Opposition and it was chaired by me as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Its tasks were to monitor the Pilot Program and to advise on the form and content of the legislation the Government had committed itself to introduce.

In November 1985, the Prime Minister released the Working Party's Report. Its major recommendation was for the introduction of legislation to require all higher education institutions and private sector employers with 100 or more staff to develop and implement affirmative action programs for women. I am very please that, despite the differences of opinion on the need for legislation expressed by some members and on the content of the recommended legislation expressed by others, the Working Party was able to agree on an approach.

The views of all Working Party members are outlined in the Report, and let me acknowledge the difficult job members had in reconciling their very different views. I thank them for their dedication: the legislation I present to the House today reflects their willingness to work hard to achieve a result that was, in the end, acceptable to all.

The other recommendations of the Working Party have also been adopted by the Government. A conference will be held later this year to reach agreement on how to remove legislative restrictions to women's employment while not, of course, jeopardising the safety or health of any worker. Many of these restrictions are within the jurisdiction of State Governments, but this initiative by the Commonwealth, I trust, will facilitate the establishing of new standards which will be acceptable to all parties.

The Prime Minister has written to State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory asking them to look at whether some current building and fire regulations are unnecessarily complex or reflect out-moded standards and inhibit employers establishing child care facilities for their staff.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission is currently undertaking detailed consultations with State and non-government education authorities and relevant community organisations on a draft National Policy on the Education of Girls. The Policy is expected to be finalised later this year. Progress is being made towards the development of a co-ordinated initiative to encourage women to undertake engineering. To this end, proposals are currently being considered for funding under CTEC's Equity Program.

Mr President, I will now outline the major components of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill. The Bill will cover Australia's 19 universities and 46 colleges of advanced education and all private sector organisations which employ 100 or more staff.

The implementation of the legislation will be phased-in over several years. It will apply first to higher education institutions. They will be required to commence their affirmative action programs on 1 August 1986 and to make their first reports to the Director of Affirmative Action 1 August 1987. Many institutions already have begun programs to improve women's employment opportunities. The legislation will ensure that same employment standards exist in our national system of higher education.

The Bill provides for co-operative arrangements to be made by the Minister with an appropriate State Minister for the exchange of information between the Director and a State officer relating to the development and implementation of affirmative action programs and for the development of guidelines in higher education institutions.

Turning now to the private sector, I want to stress that the legislation does not cover small business. While the Government believes that in areas such as advertising and recruitment, small business should be non-discriminatory, it recognises that small business does not have the capacity to undertake the full import of the legislation. The Bill provides that an employer whose staff numbers fall below 100 will still be covered unless and until the number of employees falls below 80.

Organisations employing 1000 or more employees will be the first to comply and will be required to commence their affirmative action programs on 1 February 1987 and to report to the Director of Affirmative Action on 1 February 1988. There are approximately 510 employers with more than 1000 staff. They are Australia's major employers and the Government has accepted the Working Party's recommendation that it is appropriate that they should meet these legislative obligations first. Some of them were involved in the Pilot Program; others sought assistance from the Office of the Status of Women and began preparing programs. The timetable proposed means that these very large employers have almost two years from today before they are required to report. We believe that this phasing-in will allow employers adequate time to meet the obligations proposed in the legislation. It is a reasonable timetable.

The definitions in the Bill require employers, when counting their employees for the purposes of determining whether they are covered by legislation, to include all subsidiaries. The Bill follows the Companies Act definitions of subsidiary companies' relationships to parent companies.

The second period of the phasing-in will be for employers with between 500 and 999 employees. Approximately 520 employers will be required to commence affirmative action programs on 1 February 1988 and report first on 1 February 1989. Employers employing between 100 and 499 employees will commence on 1 February 1989 with their first reports being due on 1 February 1990. This final stage will cover approximately 3430 enterprises.

The Government is determined that this important new reform for working women will not become unnecessarily bureaucratised. We do not want to burden employers with unnecessary paperwork; nor do we want the small agency we intend to create to administer the legislation to become bogged down with an unmanageable and superfluous paper burden. The phasing-in of the legislation will help us to achieve a streamlined operation.

Employers covered by the legislation will be required to provide two reports each year. The public report will be short, providing a breakdown of employees by sex and job classification and a description of the progress of the Affirmative Action program. The confidential report will provide greater detail to the Director of the progress being made under the eight steps of the program.

The Bill provides that information from this report cannot be released without the employer's consent. Employers will have total control over the use of confidential information they provide to the Director. It will be an offence for any person to release this report or other confidential information provided to the Director, with a penalty of up to $2,500 or imprisonment for up to 3 months or both. The penalty reflects the seriousness of the undertaking being given by the Government that these reports will, in fact, be confidential.

We do not intend that the compilation of these reports will pose an onerous task on the employer. Mostly, they will entail forwarding to the Director information and data on staffing and personnel procedures which most progressive companies already collect. The Government has accepted the Working Party's recommendation that there be two separate reports in order to provide an acceptable mix of some public accountability while protecting from public gaze any information companies wish to keep confidential.

Employers will be required to allocate some staff and resources to the program, particularly in the initial phase. We would expect that those initial costs will become insignificant when spread over the time scale required to integrate affirmative action activities into usual personnel practices. During the Pilot Program, the participants agreed that affirmative action made `good business sense' and is `sound personnel practise'.

The Australian Commissioner of Taxation has ruled that the expenses incurred by employers in implementing affirmative action programs would be deductible under section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. If the expenditure involves plant or equipment, the normal depreciation provisions would apply.

Mr President, let me go to the heart of our legislation-the program whose progress employers will report to the Government each year. There are eight steps to such a program and I will quickly run through them. The employer will issue a policy statement and give appropriate staff members responsibility for the program. Consultations will be held with trade unions where they have members in the workplace and with employees, particularly women employees. A statistical analysis of the workforce will be produced to develop a profile of the workforce by job classifications and sex. A review of all personnel policies and practices will be undertaken, to ensure that these are not disadvantaging women. Finally, employers will set objectives and forward estimates and will monitor and evaluate these annually.

The setting of objectives and forward estimates is an essential part of an Affirmative Action program. On the recommendation of the Working Party, we have adopted this terminology to replace the earlier terms `goals' and `targets'. The Bill ensures employers are not required to take any action which is incompatible with the merit principle.

I want to stress that the Government's Affirmative Action legislation does not propose positive discrimination or reverse discrimination. We are totally opposed to the use of quotas, and this legislation, by stating that all actions are to be based on merit, makes this clear. Those opponents of equal opportunity for women who try to discredit our legislative approach by claiming that we are proposing quotas are wrong. The Bill clearly demonstrates that. It is also clear from the definitions of objectives and forward estimates contained in the legislation, that these are to be determined by the employer and not imposed by the Director of Affirmative Action.

The Director will be required to make an annual report to the Parliament, through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Director also has the power to make other reports to the Parliament, also through the Minister. The Director could use this provision to prepare special reports on the employment of women in particular industries or occupations or to provide information on successful approaches and methods for effective affirmative action programs.

The Director will be a statutory officer, appointed by the Governor General, for a period of up to 5 years. The position will be within the portfolio of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, and the office of the Director will be situated in Sydney, and not isolated in Canberra away from the businesses and institutions affected by the legislation.

The Director will have a number of statutory functions and powers, including the primary one of advising and assisting employers on their affirmative action programs and monitoring and evaluating the reports lodged.

There is a considerable amount of work to be undertaken prior to the commencement of the legislation, to ensure it operates in an orderly and productive fashion. The Prime Minister has therefore decided to establish a small interim agency in his Department until the permanent agency can be established. This interim agency will begin the preparatory work of assessing the potential information needs of employers and methods of meeting those, and of devising the form of the reports which will eventually be required. The agency will report to the Prime Minister at the commencement of the legislation on the preparatory work and on its recommendations for the operation of the permanent agency.

The Bill provides for the establishment of representative advisory committees, to provide advice to the Minister and the Director. The members of a committee would be appointed by the Minister, after consultation with the Director. It is envisaged that the Minister might appoint committees to provide general advice or a committee might be established to advise on a particular industry or occupation. I believe that the consultation process which has been used to develop this legislation should be continued. Both the Director and the Minister would benefit from the views of those closely involved with the relevant issues.

The Government's approach in this important area of women's employment has been based on extensive consultation with all parties. It is not a punitive approach. Rather, it seeks to foster the development of affirmative action programs in an atmosphere of consensus and co-operation between Government and employers. This approach is also reflected in the only sanction provided in the Bill: the Director's power to name in a report to be presented to the parliament any employer who fails to lodge either report or who fails to provide further information on request. The Bill provides for employers with a reasonable excuse for such failure to escape the proposed sanction and it provides that, where the Director proposes to name an employer in a report, the Director must give the employer at least 28 days written notice of this intention and the reasons. The Bill also provides for an employer to apply to the Director for an extension of time of up to six months in which to lodge the reports. The Director may grant such an extension where there are reasonable grounds for the request. The Government intends the Director to continue the harmonious relationships built up between Pilot Program companies, employers' representatives, the higher education sector, the trade union movement and the Office of the Status of Women.

In selecting the Director, the Government will be looking for a person able to maintain this harmony and to be sensitive to private sector and higher education ways of operating. I give the assurance that this legislation will not be administered in a heavy-handed fashion. I am confident that the vast majority of large employers in this country wish to co-operate with the Government's aims of ensuring that Australian women who wish to work are not denied any opportunity for which they are qualified.

The Government is of the view that there is a need for all employers, whether in the private or public sector, to conform to the principles of equal opportunity in employment. The measures in this Bill are similar to those measures required to be undertaken by Commonwealth Government departments. I might add that consideration is currently being given to the appropriate legislative mechanisms for the coverage of Commonwealth Government statutory authorities.

Other interested parties have been doing their own work in this important employment area. The ACTU has prepared an Affirmative Action Manual to assist trade union members and officials to make a useful contribution to the development of affirmative action in Australia.

Last year, the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry announced the establishment of the Council for Equal Employment Opportunity to actively promote equal opportunity throughout the private sector. They propose to establish a formal register of participating companies and a Board to oversee the staff working with the companies. I expect the Director of Affirmative Action to work in close co-operation with this venture when it is established. The Business Council also intends to publish a book, based on the experiences of the Pilot Program companies.

Mr President, the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill is a major Government initiative which is designed to remove any existing obstacles to women fully participating in the Australian workforce. It is a forward looking and imaginative approach to improving women's job opportunities and I am sure the result will bear out the Government's commitment to this policy. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

I am not sure whether every honourable senator is aware of it but, on the figures that have been pulled out by the Clerks at the table, the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and the accompanying Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bills have now been debated in the Senate for what is a record time for the whole period since Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they don't make that claim. They go back only to 1970.
—We are now up to 35 hours and two minutes.
—That is since 1970.

—My understanding was that it was since Federation. The second longest debated Bill is that National Health Bill in 1970, which took 31 hours and 49 minutes, and the third longest the Family Law Bill, which took 28 hours and 29 minutes in 1974. The Freedom of Information Bill was a positive hare by comparison, taking only 13 hours and 22 minutes.
—What about the ASIO Bill in 1979?

—I do not know. I am just relying on the information from the Clerks. If there has not been a filibuster by Senator Durack and his colleagues on this matter, it has been a pretty fair imitation of one. This is important legislation. The Government wants it. The Government is disposed to press on with it.
—What about proposing a referendum?

—Clearly, we shall need some understandings, and a little more sensitivity than that which is currently being demonstrated in this chamber by Senator Durack, if this legislation is to pass. Finally, I acknowledge what has been said about the difficulties of sitting for a four-week period straight, or for even more than four-week periods, in terms of everyone's stamina and morale in this place. We must acknowledge, however, that both the weeks of sitting and the hours of sitting are still relatively short by any international standard-Britain, the United States, Canada or elsewhere. That is a pretty horrendous prospect to contemplate when we have a minority party with only six or seven members having to deal with a whole range of Bills. It is also a horrendous prospect to contemplate sitting for these sorts of overseas session times when we have only six Ministers in this place responsible, between just six of them, for the entire legislative program and, indeed, having a presence in this chamber for the entire duration. No similar system operates anywhere else in the world in those chambers which sit for longer hours. If we get very ratty towards the end of a session, as well as--
—You are ratty at the beginning of the session.

—That might be true for some of us, Senator. Some of us get stirred into life by inanity rather more easily than others. All of these things are considerations with which we must at some stage come to grips. There has been an ever-escalating legislative load upon this Parliament. It has been for good reason. Life gets ever more complex. I do not think that simplistic solutions in terms of shortened speaking time will solve the problems. I simply acknowledge in response to what has been said in this debate that there is a sequence of interrelated problems here with which we must deal. Let us try to deal with them in good faith and with some element of mutual tolerance and understanding in the hope that we can get this legislative program through by the time we get up.
—We need leadership from the Government on that exercise. We will co-operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —When progress was reported today, the Committee was about to consider clause 22. INTERJECT.PARA: Clause 22.-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 11, clause 22, proposed new section 52a, at end of proposed section, add the following new section:
``(7) A reference in this section to the supply or possible supply of goods or services includes a reference to the purchase or possible purchase of goods or services.''.

The Government has put forward a very important piece of legislation for business and for consumers. They need this legislation to get a fair deal. I want to go a little further and appeal to honourable senators' senses of justice and equity. What I am asking in this amendment is: Why should we allow large economic interests, especially those in a monopoly or cartel position, to engage in unconscionable behaviour when selling or when buying? Basically, the Government's current clause handles the unconscionable behaviour during the process of selling goods, and this particular amendment is aimed at extending that to apply to the buying of goods.

If we want a market-place that is free and open in practice and not just in name, we shall have to restore some balance between the relative weights of various parties who are involved in the transactions of commerce, and that is exactly what I am trying to do with this amendment-make an even handling of buyers and sellers. Monopolies that have cartel powers can be used to impose conditions that are in the short term interests of only the monopolies or cartels. These conditions can be totally against the public interest. These conditions can shore up economic inefficiencies and managerial incompetence in the cartel or monopoly itself. So I believe that it is also an advantage to the monopoly or cartel to have this type of legislation, which sets the boundaries of good corporate citizenship on both buying operations and selling operations.

I should like to look, at a later stage when we have more time, at the sorts of distortions that can occur in the market-place because of large buying cartels. The obvious distortion is where a small business contractor is supplying goods to a large conglomerate, and that is one of the situations in which it is possible for the large conglomerate to indulge in unconscionable behaviour, and it is because of this that I urge the Senate to support my amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer briefly to an article last Thursday on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald. It was written by David Jenkins, the Foreign Editor. It was entitled `After Marcos, now for the Suharto billions'. I seek leave to incorporate this article in Hansard.
—Has it been shown to the Minister?

—No, I will show it to him. While I believe strongly in the freedom of the Press, I also believe equally strong that this freedom should be exercised responsibly and not in a manner wantonly negligent of Australia's national interest. One fair and essential test of Press responsibility is that a newspaper should be able to sustain its reporting with evidence. A second test is the benefit or otherwise that would be expected to arise from any Press initiative. I refer to these important issues in response to the scandalous impact of last Thursday's article in the Sydney Morning Herald alleging misconduct in the business dealings of Indonesia's President Suharto. The Australian Parliament has no evidence to verify any of the allegations that have been made. But what is known in Parliament is the enormous and constructive contribution President Suharto has made to the benefit of the Indonesian people and the whole region since his leadership began 20 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly the author of the article, David Jenkins, has not sought to document the allegations. The allegations are not new and have surfaced from time to time in the form of gossip. I object strongly to any journalist or publisher printing material based on gossip that does not cite hard evidence. The author, David Jenkins, is a very experienced journalist with an extensive knowledge of Indonesia. He also has a detailed knowledge of the positive developments in Australian-Indonesian relations over the past year. He also knew details of the fourth annual Australian-Indonesian consultative conference held in Jakarta last week, which was disrupted by last Thursday's article. Mr Jenkins, with his thorough knowledge of Indonesian affairs, must have known what the reaction to his article would be.

May I add with regard to other interested Australian journalists that I have considerable sympathy for the editor of the Australian Financial Review, who was at the conference, and his colleague, Michael Byrnes, who has one of two temporary work visas held by Australian journalists in Indonesia. They have been directly embarrassed by the Jenkins Press initiative and their good work is now likely to be severely disrupted. In fact, it is already severely disrupted.

I support the Australian Financial Review's constructive approach over the past six months to ensure there is independent Australian reporting of events in Indonesia, which has now been put in jeopardy by a senior journalist of another Fairfax newspaper. It is easy for us to speculate as to what David Jenkins's motivation may have been in writing the article. It appears his intention may have been to cause a stir simply to gain widespread Press coverage through the reverberations that would inevitably follow.

It has been my conclusion, and it gives me no cheer to observe this, that the article was deliberately designed to upset the growing good relations emerging between Australia and Indonesia. Certainly that has been its effect. It may also have been intended as some kind of payback for the tragic deaths of five Australian journalists in Timor more than 10 years ago. Of course, we must look for and encourage a more understanding response by Indonesian leaders to the nature of the Australian Press and hope for Indonesian acceptance that a Press event such as was created by the article in the Sydney Morning Herald is completely unconnected with the Australian Government and the Opposition and is unrepresentative of the Australian people. We will not be moved by this totally unhelpful and apparently unsound Press event to fetter in any way our Press freedom, but we cannot escape from the political repercussions of Jenkins's article. It is our resolve to continue to strengthen the basis for friendly and constructive relations between Australia and Indonesia.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Earlier Senator Teague sought leave to incorporate in Hansard an article which has since been shown to the Minister.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
AFTER MARCOS, NOW FOR THE
SOEHARTO BILLIONS
By DAVID JENKINS,
Foreign Editor

As Philippine investigators peel back the covers on the hidden Marcos millions, Indonesians are asking new questions about assets of between $US2 and $3 billion piled up by the family and business associates of President Soeharto.

Though the president's name does not appear to be inscribed on any stock holdings or land deeds, the names of his brothers and half-brothers, his sons and daughters and assorted other relatives and business associates are listed prominently on the share registers of some of Indonesia's most profitable companies.

Overnight tycoons, they have waxed fat on government capital, credit and concessions. And when, as on at least one occasion, their businesses have faltered, they have been bailed out, some Indonesians charge, by government aid.

President Soeharto has little in common with former President Marcos, he has rebuilt a nation which was on the verge of bankruptcy and given it a new direction and sense of purpose. He has built schools-tens of thousands of them-and hospitals and roads, given the nation huge new oil refineries and hydro-electric power plants and more than doubled rice production, from 9 million to 23 million tonnes. He has ruled a large and complex nation with skill and subtlety, notching up any number of important achievements.

But corruption is the Achilles heel of his regime. And over the past two decades many of those around him have been almost breathtakingly successful in the business world, often with little or no prior experience.

The President's wife, Madame Tien Soeharto, has participated in so many questionable business dealings that she has long been known as ``Madame Tien Per Cent.'' (Some Indonesians, despairing of what they see as her increasingly acquisitive tendencies, have dubbed her ``Fifi''-short for Madame Fifty Per Cent.) Jokes about the Indonesian First Lady being in the mining business (``that's mine, that's mine'') were around long before they were told about Mrs Imelda Marcos.

Amongst other things, Mrs Soeharto chairs several large charitable foundations. In theory, these are private non-profit bodies. However, it is widely believed in Jakarta that they serve not just as an instrument for the carrying out of good works but as vehicles for the enrichment of those associated with them, and as slush funds which launder money and sustain semi-official patronage network. Mrs Soeharto is also said to have extensive logging interests in Irian Jaya.

The President's son, Sigit, and daughter, Siti, have acquired a one-third interest in the nation's largest domestic private bank, an institution with assets of $US277 million. Sigit is also said to have made handsome profits on the lucrative spot oil market.

The President's long-time financier, Indonesian-Chinese businessman Liem Sioe Liong, has built up a business empire which is conservatively valued between $US2 and $US3 billion. Mr Liem, who has been handed an extraordinary range of government monopolies in such key industries as flour milling and cement manufacturing, is described by the Indonesian press as one of the six richest men in the world, far outstripping the Rockefellers.

The President's brother, Probosutdedjo, has shared with Mr Liem, a government monopoly in importing cloves, a virtual licence to print money in a country where cloves cigarettes are a national addiction. He also has interests in a building company, a glass factory, a bag company, a compost plant, a hardboard company, a cooking oil company and a chicken farm.

Sigit and his brother, Bambang, have become so bitterly competitive in the grab for business spoils that Mr Soeharto has had to step in and separate them. According to a well-placed Indonesian source, he has suggested that Sigit go to London, ostensibly to seek medical help for a sick child, but actually to cool his heels.

The President's foster brother, businessman Sudwikatmono, has acquired a 4 per cent stake in the giant Liem company which has been awarded a monopoly in flour milling and a 5 per cent stake in a $US1 billion cement company managed and half-owned by Liem. Sudwikatmono has also gone into partnership with Mr Liem in the film-making business.

Yet another relative, Sukamdani Gitosardjono, has become involved in a $US300 million investment in a cement factory and has extensive interests in hotels, timber, textiles, publishing, and fertiliser distribution.

That some individuals should have become so spectacularly wealthy in a nation with a per capita annual income of barely $US500 is deeply troubling to a growing number of Indonesians, even if few dare openly question the fact.

That Mr Soeharto has virtually created such a system and permitted his relatives to profit from it so handsomely, is to them not just a sign of political miscalculation but a serious blot on an otherwise impressive presidency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 6 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the stated intention of the Government of the Philippines to contravene the moratorium on commercial whaling imposed by the International Whaling Commission, to which both the Philippines and Australia are signatories.

(2) What action will the Australian Government take to indicate its disapproval of this decision of the Philippines, and what action will the Australian Government take to attempt to influence the Government of the Philippines to alter its decision.

(3) Does the proposed `pirate' whaling operations by the Philippine Government entail a breach of the Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species, which prohibits trade in whale meat and whale products.
(4) What action will the Australian Government take to persuade the Governments of the Philippines and Japan from permitting this illicit trade in whale meat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 26 September 1985 the previous Government of the Philippines presented a statement to the Secretary of the International Whaling Commission outlining why the Philippines consider it ``appropriate to continue its whaling of the western stock of Bryde's Whale until 1988.'' At its 34th Annual Meeting in 1982, the International Whaling Commission (IWC) agreed to a moratorium on commercial whaling to commence in the 1985/86 pelagic and 1986 coastal seasons. The Philippines attended that meeting and did not subsequently lodge an objection to the moratorium decision. Under the terms of the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling (ICRW), the Philippines is therefore bound to abide by the amendment to the Schedule which set the zero catch limits of the moratorium.

(2) Australia has expressed, through diplomatic channels, serious concern to the Government of the Philippines with regard to its intention to carry out commercial whaling operations during the moratorium. Australia has also expressed its dismay that the Philippines, not having lodged an objection to the moratorium, intends to whale in breach of the ICRW. Australia reiterated its concern to the Philippines Government most recently on 12 March 1986. In stating its opposition to all forms of whaling, Australia has asked that the Philippines Government take no further action to resume commercial whaling pending consideration of the matter at this year's Annual Meeting of the IWC. Australia will remain in consultation with the Philippines on this important issue.

(3) The Bryde's whale, Balaenoptera edeni, which the Philippines intends to take, is listed on Appendix I of the Convention on Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). However, the provisions of CITES which might apply to trade in whale products between the Philippines and Japan are complex, particularly as Japan has lodged reservations to the listing of cetaceans in CITES appendices. Australia is seeking further advice on the application of CITES to such trade.
(4) Australia will endeavour to dissuade the Governments of Japan and the Philippines from authorising trade in whale products between the two countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have 2 Australian citizens been forced to nominate the Queensland Tropical Rainforests for World Heritage Listing on behalf of the Australian people.
(2) Is the Government prepared to support the people of Australia who wish to preserve this unique rainforest area.
(3) In what ways will the Government support this nomination.
(4) Why has the Government itself not initiated such nomination, in light of the Report commissioned by the Australian Heritage Commission and submitted in June 1984, which concluded that:

``the wet tropics region of north-east Queensland is one of the most significant regional ecosystems in the world. It is of outstanding scientific importance and natural beauty and adequately fulfils all four of the criteria defined by the World Heritage Convention for inclusion in the `World Heritage List'.''
(5) What studies has the Government undertaken to ascertain its legal rights and obligations in this matter.
(6) Do these studies show that the Government is legally obliged to take action to place the Queensland Tropical Rainforests on the World Heritage List.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Dr Aila Keto, President of the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland and Mr Michael Rae, Campaign Director of the Wilderness Society sent a document to the Director-General of UNESCO on 5 December 1985. The document related to possible inclusion of Australia's wet tropical rainforests on the World Heritage List. However, this document did not constitute a nomination for World Heritage listing, as it was not authorised by the Commonwealth Government which is the State Party to the World Heritage Convention. This fact is recognised by both Dr Keto and Mr Rae. The last page of their document says:

``In presenting this nomination, we realise that the World Heritage Committee will not be able to accept the wet tropical rainforests for World Heritage listing as the nomination does not come from a State Party.''
This situation has also been confirmed by UNESCO. On 18 December 1985 the Director of UNESCO's Division of Ecological Sciences wrote to Mr C. S. Harris of the Wilderness Society, noting that:
``this nomination is not receivable for the World Heritage Secretariat since it has not been endorsed and submitted by the Australian Government.''

(2) The Government is firmly committed to the preservation of both Australia's cultural and natural heritage, including rainforests. It is considered, however, that these aims can best be achieved through cooperation and consultation with State and Territory Governments rather than through conflict and confrontation. The recently released report on `Rainforest Conservation in Australia' which was prepared in collaboration between groups holding strong and diverse opinions on a complex environmental issue, exemplifies the value of this approach.
(3) There is no nomination for the Government to support.

(4) Under an agreement reached by the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM), the Commonwealth Government has written to State and Territory Governments inviting them to submit suggestions for places to be examined with a view to possible future nominations to the World Heritage List. Queensland has responded and advised that it does not wish to have any places in Queensland nominated for the World Heritage List. In this connection, the Commonwealth Government has indicated that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage listing.
(5) to (6) The Government believes that its policy and actions in relation to this matter are in conformity with its rights and obligations under the World Heritage Convention.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Kalkadunga Tribal Heritage Aboriginal Association Corporation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How did the Registrar of Aboriginal corporations establish the authenticity of the background of the Kalkadunga Tribal Heritage Association Aboriginal Corporation (KTHAAC) and what information was supplied to cause him to believe that all the members were of Kalkadoon heritage when the Registrar received the application from the KTHAAC to be incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976.

(2) Why would the Department of Aboriginal Affairs consider registering the KTHAAC as a body to receive Government funds, since the KYHAAC has the same aims, objectives and a similar constitution to the Kalkadoon Tribal Council, thus duplicating funding, when it is known that the Kalkadoon Tribal Council are the recognised and funded body representing the Kalkadoon people.
(3) Do several directors of the KTHAAC live and work in Brisbane; if so, how much does it cost for them to attend monthly meetings of the KTHAAC.
(4) Does the Chairman of the KTHAAC live and work in Katherine, Northern Territory; if so, how much does it cost for him to attend the monthly meetings of the KTHAAC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The decision to incorporate the KTHAAC was one for the Registrar, or Acting Registrar, acting pursuant to sections 43-49 of the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs was consulted, but the decision was not its decision. Nor is the decision in any way related to any question whether the incorporated body would receive funds from the Department.

(1) While the Registrar made inquiries of the Department as to whether the members of the KTHAAC were believed to be descendants of the Kalkadoon tribe, no attempt was made by the Registrar to establish the `authenticity of the background' of members.

No genealogical assessment of applicants is required of the Registrar under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act. Indeed, in cases where records have not been kept, such assessments would not be possible.

(2) The Department did not register KTHAAC for the purpose of receiving funds. Kalkadunga Tribal Heritage Association applied to the Registrar and was granted incorporation because the association satisfied the provisions of the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. The Act does not preclude proposed objects being similar to those of another corporation.

The fact that the Kalkadoon Tribal Council is at present in receipt of Government funds in no way implies that it is the only body recognised as representative of Kalkadoon people. In fact, the constitution of the Kalkadoon Tribal Council-unlike that of the KTHAAC-does not restrict membership to Kalkadoons; membership is open to any Aboriginal or Islander.

(3) and (4) The Minister has been informed that two of the members at present live in Brisbane and that the Chairman at present lives in Katherine. As their organisation is not in receipt of Government funding, the activities of any members and the expenses these may entail are the office-holder's own private concern.

Since 1979 the Northern Territory Government, with the agreement of the Commonwealth Government and Aboriginal groups, has approved the release during the wet season of runoff water from outside the mine's restricted release zone subject to, amongst other things, the water meeting quality criteria. Such controlled releases continue to be made with the agreement of the supervising authorities. In 1985, in the course of monitoring an authorised release, staff of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region observed short term breeding impairment of mussels in the vicinity of the discharge point and some avoidance of the area by fish. The significance of these events is unclear. No such effects have been observed this year.

(5) No. The Report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry recommended that the water management system be established initially as a no release system and that this system be maintained until it was shown that releases of contaminated water would have to be made. The Report also made recommendations as to the manner in which water should be released and proposed the broad principles to be applied in the development of water release standards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the negotiations on revised contractual arrangements between Australia Post and the 2 major domestic airlines now been concluded; if so, under precisely what circumstances will penalty provisions apply should Express Courier or Priority Paid mail not be uplifted to destination on flights nominated by Australia Post.
(2) Can penalty provisions be applied for failure to uplift ordinary Air Mail articles on either specified flights, or within a certain period of time.
(3) What resources does Australia Post intend to apply on-the-spot at various airports in order to achieve better uplift and on-time delivery rates.
(4) What has been the cost to Australia Post of the services provided by the domestic airlines in each of the past 5 financial years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Australian Postal Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A penalty, in the form of substantially reduced rate of payment, applies to any failure to uplift Express Courier mail and convey it to its destination within time parameters nominated by Australia Post, except in circumstances beyond the control of the airline concerned (for example, where a flight is delayed by adverse weather). There is no penalty provision in respect of Priority Paid mail.

(3) Australia Post has its own staff based at airports in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth. These staff liaise closely with airline representatives and play a major role in monitoring the performance of the airlines and securing timely uplift and conveyance of mails to destination. They also initiate action to apply the penalty provision in cases of Express Courier uplift failures.
Source: Australia Postal Commission Annual Report for the year ended 30 June 1985 (Page 56, Table 2).

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders: Television and Radio Services

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 February 1986 (Hansard, page 603), Senator Macklin asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the report of the Task Force on Aboriginal and Islander Broadcasting and Communications, which was tabled in October 1984, which recognised the desperate need for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to control radio and television, and to the Government's response in November 1985 endorsing the urgency of that framework. I ask
(1) Why was the meeting with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Minister for Communications and senior representatives of the Island Co-ordinating Council planned for this Friday cancelled?

(2) Why were the Aboriginal people and the Torres Strait Islanders on the islands of north Queensland not given the opportunity to involve themselves in the inquiries into the commercial television licence issue, as were the Aboriginal people in Alice Springs?
The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) Senior officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Communications have received a number of requests for a meeting between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Minister for Communications and senior representatives of the Island Co-ordinating Council from a Mr R. Cantley claiming to represent the Council.

The Chairman of the Island Co-ordinating Council wrote to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs suggesting a meeting on 19 February. The letter requested that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs pay the air fares for the representatives to travel to Canberra.

The Minister replied advising that 19 February was not convenient because senior officers of his department and the Department of Communications would not be available in Canberra as they were participating in the official opening of the High Frequency Inland Radio Service transmitter in Alice Springs. Mr Cantley had been advised of this when he spoke to the Minister's office.

The Minister also advised the Chairman of the Council that most of the matters he wished to raise had been addressed in the Task Force Report on Aboriginal and Islander Broadcasting and Communications. He said that he would welcome a meeting with the chairman during one of his regular visits to Canberra.
There was no meeting planned for 19 February.

(2) The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has advised the Minister that the following steps were taken in relation to advising groups and communities about the north east region Remote Commercial Television Service licence hearings:

``The Remote Commercial Television Service (RCTS) Inquiry for all four regions, including the north-east region which covers Queensland, was announced by the Minister for Communications on 10 October 1984. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) published a notice dated 24 October 1984 in all major metropolitan and regional newspapers seeking Expressions of Interest, Applications and Submissions for all four regions. These papers included the Country Life in Queensland, the Courier Mail in Brisbane and the Daily Bulletin in Townsville.

On 31 October 1984 the Tribunal wrote to Federal members of the House of Representatives covering remote constituencies asking them to bring the RCTS Inquiry to the attention of their constituents, particularly those who could be affected by the establishment of such services. The Queensland MPs contacted by the Tribunal represented the constituencies of Nambour, Mackay, Dalby, Rockhampton, Cairns, Mt Isa, Townsville, Toowoomba, Maryborough and Southport.

In addition, copies of all applications were lodged in Municipal and Shire Council offices throughout Australia, as well as with District Radio Inspector and State Australian Broadcasting Tribunal offices, to enable the public to examine them. There were 18 locations in Queensland where copies of the RCTS Applications were available for public inspection.
A notice for the north-east region hearing, dated 4 July 1985, was published in the Courier Mail inviting the public to attend the hearings.

The Tribunal made several attempts to contact the Torres Strait Aboriginal and Islander Media Association by telephone to invite their participation in the north-east region hearing. No one answered the phone on any of the five occasions an attempt was made to ring through.

However, the applicant (QSTV) for the licence did call Mr Robin Yarrow, Executive Officer with the Queensland Department of Community Services (which includes Aboriginal Affairs). Mr Yarrow gave evidence on Aboriginal needs in the north-east region. In addition, QSTV is currently undertaking research into the needs and interests of Aboriginal communities in the State.

Throughout the Inquiry process, the Tribunal heard a lot of evidence relating to Aboriginal needs. The Tribunal had regard to the evidence presented by the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs to it during the General Hearing, as well as that of the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association. This was reflected in the Report of the North East Regional Inquiry''.
